question_text: A 21-year-old man comes to the emergency room because of a 2-hour history of swelling and severe pain in his left lower leg. He has no history of serious illness or trauma. His father had a pulmonary embolism at the age of 30 years. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 3 years. He appears distressed. He is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 92 kg (203 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m^2. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 130/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a tender and mildly swollen left lower leg; dorsiflexion of the left foot causes severe pain in the calf. Laboratory studies show a platelet count of 184,000/mm^3, prothrombin time of 11 seconds, partial thromboplastin time of 26 seconds, and positive fibrin split products. Ultrasonography of the left leg shows incompressibility of the popliteal vein with a hyperechoic mass and absent blood flow. The patient is administered a 5000 IU intravenous bolus of unfractionated heparin followed by a constant infusion. Six hours later, the partial thromboplastin time is 28 seconds. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 21-year-old man comes to the emergency room because of a 2-hour history of swelling and severe pain in his left lower leg. He has no history of serious illness or trauma. His father had a pulmonary embolism at the age of 30 years. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 3 years. He appears distressed. He is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 92 kg (203 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 130/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a tender and mildly swollen left lower leg; dorsiflexion of the left foot causes severe pain in the calf. Laboratory studies show a platelet count of 184,000/mm3, prothrombin time of 11 seconds, partial thromboplastin time of 26 seconds, and positive fibrin split products. Ultrasonography of the left leg shows incompressibility of the popliteal vein with a hyperechoic mass and absent blood flow. The patient is administered a 5000 IU intravenous bolus of unfractionated heparin followed by a constant infusion. Six hours later, the partial thromboplastin time is 28 seconds. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This young man presents with deep vein thrombosis (swollen, tender leg with positive Homan sign, positive D-dimer, positive ultrasonography signs). Despite receiving a therapeutic dose of heparin, his partial thromboplastin time (PTT) hardly increases and remains within normal limits, suggesting a defect in the protein targeted by heparin.
learning_objective: Recognize antithrombin III deficiency.

answers.explanation_why: Protein C deficiency is an autosomal dominant hypercoagulable disease caused by overactivity of factors V and VIII, which are normally inhibited by protein C. Heparin, on the other hand, acts on thrombin and factor Xa, not on factors V and VIII, so its anticoagulant action is unaffected by protein C deficiency.

Antiphospholipid syndrome is an acquired hypercoagulable disease caused by antiphospholipid antibodies (e.g., lupus anticoagulant, anticardiolipin antibodies, anti-β2-glycoprotein antibodies). This condition would not prevent an increase of PTT because antibodies play no role in heparin's mechanism of action, so it is not a likely cause of this patient's symptoms.

Elevated levels of homocysteine can be seen in patients with mutations in enzymes that metabolize homocysteine (autosomal recessive), vitamin B12 deficiency, and vitamin B6 deficiency. Hyperhomocysteinemia is considered a risk factor for thrombosis as it alters the function of thrombomodulin, factor VII, and factor V. Excess homocysteine also damages the vasculature leading to decreased endothelial antithrombotic activity. However, this patient has no evidence of anemia due to vitamin B6 or B12 deficiency (fatigue, pallor, tachycardia) or a family history of metabolic disease (enzyme deficiency). Moreover, homocysteine plays no role in heparin's mechanism of action and, therefore, does not affect the efficacy of heparin.

The altered factor V in Factor V Leiden is immune to the regulatory effect of protein C. Overactivity of factor V results in excessive activation of prothrombin, leading to a hypercoagulable state. Because neither protein C nor factor V interacts with heparin, its efficacy is unaffected in patients with Factor V Leiden.

Antithrombin III deficiency (AT III deficiency) is an inherited autosomal dominant hypercoagulable disease. AT III inhibits coagulation by binding to and inactivating the coagulation factors II (thrombin) and X. Heparin works by potentiating the binding of AT III to thrombin and factor X. This patient's PTT remains normal despite heparin administration because heparin requires AT III to achieve its effect. Patients with AT III deficiency can tolerate higher doses of heparin (also known as heparin resistance) without showing any changes in PTT. If therapeutic goals are not achieved with heparin (1.5 to 2.5 times the upper limit of the normal range of PTT), additional antithrombin concentrate may be needed.

See “Pathophysiology of hereditary thrombophilia” table.

images.title: Procoagulation-anticoagulation balance
images.description: Clotting homeostasis is maintained through a balance of procoagulation (purple) and anticoagulation (gray) processes. The procoagulation pathway ultimately results in the enzymatic conversion of fibrinogen into fibrin, which is an integral part of blood clot formation. The procoagulation pathway is physiologically inhibited through two distinct anticoagulation pathways, using either antithrombin III or the APC complex.Antithrombin III inactivates factors IX, X, and thrombin. This process is accelerated in the presence of heparin. Additionally, antithrombin III indirectly increases the activation of plasmin through the action of tissue plasminogen activator (tPA), resulting in the degradation of both fibrinogen and fibrin.The APC complex pathway involves the activity of thrombomodulin, a membrane protein expressed on endothelial cells that activates protein C. Activated protein C then binds to protein S to form the APC complex, which inactivates procoagulation factors V and VIII. The procoagulation factor thrombin can also activate protein C, which results in a negative feedback loop on the procoagulation pathway.

question_text: A 43-year-old man with HIV comes to the physician because of fever and night sweats over the past 15 days. During this period, he has also had headaches and generalized weakness. He has no cough or shortness of breath. He has hypertension controlled with lisinopril and is currently receiving triple antiretroviral therapy. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 15 years and drinks one to two beers on weekends. He is a known user of intravenous drugs. His temperature is 39°C (102°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Examination shows several track marks on the forearms. The lungs are clear to auscultation. A holosystolic murmur that increases on inspiration is heard along the left lower sternal border. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 12,800/mm^3 and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 52 mm/h. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 450/mm^3. This patient is at greatest risk for developing which of the following?
content_preview: A 43-year-old man with HIV comes to the physician because of fever and night sweats over the past 15 days. During this period, he has also had headaches and generalized weakness. He has no cough or shortness of breath. He has hypertension controlled with lisinopril and is currently receiving triple antiretroviral therapy. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 15 years and drinks one to two beers on weekends. He is a known user of intravenous drugs. His temperature is 39°C (102°F), pulse is 115/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Examination shows several track marks on the forearms. The lungs are clear to auscultation. A holosystolic murmur that increases on inspiration is heard along the left lower sternal border. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 12,800/mm3 and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 52 mm/h. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 450/mm3. This patient is at greatest risk for developing which of the following?
hint: In an individual who injects drugs, the combination of fever, night sweats, weakness, increased inflammatory markers, and a heart murmur characteristic of tricuspid regurgitation suggests right-sided infective endocarditis (IE).
learning_objective: Recognize right-sided infective endocarditis, and recall its complications.

answers.explanation_why:
Septic pulmonary embolism is a common and severe complication of right-sided IE and is caused by bacterial thromboemboli that form on the affected heart valve and dislodge into the lung. Patients present with cough, pleuritic chest pain, and nodular pulmonary infiltrates. While tricuspid valve IE is rare, nonsterile injections (e.g., in individuals who use IV drugs) leading to bacteremia as well as indwelling intravascular devices increase the risk for this condition.

Peripheral disease manifestations (e.g., Roth spots, Janeway lesions, embolic arterial occlusion of the kidney, brain, and spleen) are not typically seen in right-sided IE.

images.title: Septic pulmonary emboli
images.description:
X-ray chest (supine) of a 24-year-old patient with history of intravenous drug use and septic emboliNumerous pulmonary nodules are present in both lungs (examples indicated by green overlay). Some nodules have lucent centers indicating cavitation (examples indicated by red overlay). Air-space opacities, which were better appreciated on a subsequent CT scan (not shown), obscure the margins of some nodules.
The cardiac silhouette appears prominent as a result of rotation of the patient to the left.The differential diagnosis of causes of multiple cavitary lung nodules includes bacterial, tuberculous, fungal, and parasitic infections as well as several noninfectious causes (e.g., rheumatic diseases and malignancies).Arrowheads: thoracic spine spinous processes; dashed lines: medial clavicles; yellow overlay: right central line

answers.content: Painful nodules on pads of the fingers
answers.explanation_why: Painful nodules on the pads of the fingers (i.e., Osler nodes) as a result of circulating immune complex deposition in the skin are a relatively rare but highly suggestive finding of IE. When they are seen, peripheral manifestations such as Osler nodes are more likely in patients with left-sided rather than right-sided IE. Moreover, Osler nodes typically occur in protracted cases of IE; this patient presents with acute IE.

images.title: Osler nodes
images.description: There are multiple raised nodular lesions on the palm and palmar aspects of the first and second digits. The lesions appear dark brown, indicating subcutaneous hemorrhages.This is the typical appearance of Osler nodes.

answers.explanation_why: Hemorrhages underneath the fingernails (i.e., splinter hemorrhages) are a common finding in IE and are caused by septic microemboli from infected heart valves. However, they are more often seen in patients with left-sided rather than right-sided IE.

images.title: Splinter hemorrhages in endocarditis
images.description: The vertical hemorrhages (arrowheads) underneath this patient's fingernails are most commonly caused by trauma but can also occur as a result of immune complex deposition or microthrombosis in subacute, infective endocarditis, SLE, or rheumatoid arthritis.

answers.explanation_why: Acute kidney injury (AKI) leading to hematuria is a possible complication of IE and can be caused by immune complex glomerulonephritis or septic embolization leading to renal artery occlusion. However, AKI is more commonly seen in patients with left-sided rather than right-sided IE.

Retinal hemorrhages with pale centers (i.e., Roth spots) are highly suggestive of IE. However, they are a rare finding and when they are seen, they are more commonly present in patients with left-sided rather than right-sided IE. Moreover, Roth spots typically occur in protracted cases of IE, while this patient presents with acute IE.

images.title: Roth spots
images.description: Fundus photography of a left eyeThere are multiple red, white-centered lesions, which reflect small retinal hemorrhages with central accumulation of leukocytes or fibrin thrombocyte emboli (examples indicated by arrowheads).Although these findings were formerly considered to be associated almost exclusively with infective endocarditis, they may actually occur in a variety of conditions, including hypertensive, diabetic, and HIV-related retinopathy; leukemia; and intracranial hemorrhage.Circle: optic disc; M= macula

answers.content: Asymptomatic hemorrhages on palms and soles
answers.explanation_why: Asymptomatic hemorrhages on the palms and soles in IE are also known as Janeway lesions and most commonly occur in left-sided IE, not right-sided IE.

images.title: Janeway lesions
images.description: Multiple erythematous macules are visible on the thenar eminence and the base of the thumb.These Janeway lesions are typically caused by septic microembolisms secondary to infective endocarditis.

question_text: One day after undergoing left carotid endarterectomy, a 63-year-old man has a severe headache. He describes it as 9 out of 10 in intensity. He has nausea. He had 80% stenosis in the left carotid artery and received heparin prior to the surgery. He has a history of two transient ischemic attacks, which occurred two and four months ago, respectively. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypercholesterolemia. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. He drinks 1–2 beers on weekends. Current medications include lisinopril, metformin, sitagliptin, and aspirin. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 111/min, and blood pressure is 180/110 mm Hg. He is confused and oriented only to person. Examination shows pupils that react sluggishly to light. There is a right facial droop. Muscle strength is decreased in the right upper and lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ on the right. There is a left cervical surgical incision that shows no erythema or discharge. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of creatinine, electrolytes, and glucose are within the reference range. A CT scan of the head is shown. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
content_preview: One day after undergoing left carotid endarterectomy, a 63-year-old man has a severe headache. He describes it as 9 out of 10 in intensity. He has nausea. He had 80% stenosis in the left carotid artery and received heparin prior to the surgery. He has a history of two transient ischemic attacks, which occurred two and four months ago, respectively. He has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypercholesterolemia. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. He drinks 1–2 beers on weekends. Current medications include lisinopril, metformin, sitagliptin, and aspirin. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 111/min, and blood pressure is 180/110 mm Hg. He is confused and oriented only to person. Examination shows pupils that react sluggishly to light. There is a right facial droop. Muscle strength is decreased in the right upper and lower extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 3+ on the right. There is a left cervical surgical incision that shows no erythema or discharge. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of creatinine, electrolytes, and glucose are within the reference range. A CT scan of the head is shown. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?
hint: This patient has clinical features of a stroke (e.g., facial droop, right-sided hemiparesis, hyperreflexia, headache) and a CT scan of the head that shows intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH; hyperdense lesion surrounded by hypodense edema) in the left hemisphere.
learning_objective: Recognize intracerebral hemorrhage, and recall its strongest predisposing factor.

answers.explanation_why: Carotid artery stenosis is a risk factor for embolic (through carotid plaque emboli) and thrombotic (through carotid plaque thrombosis) ischemic stroke. Carotid stroke and intracerebral hemorrhage also share multiple risk factors. However, patients with early signs of ischemic stroke on noncontrast CT typically have hypodense parenchyma and loss of grey-white matter differentiation; this patient has a hyperdense lesion surrounded by hypodense edema, which indicates ICH.

images.title: Subacute posterior cerebral artery infarct
images.description: CT head (without contrast; axial plane)A hypodense occipital infarct (green) in the distribution of the left posterior cerebral artery is accompanied by a loss of normal gray-white matter differentiation. The density of the lesion is greater than that of CSF. There is no mass effect or hemorrhage. Choroid plexus calcifications in the lateral ventricles are physiologic.

answers.explanation_why: Aspirin inhibits platelet aggregation, theoretically predisposing patients to bleeding such as intracerebral hemorrhage. However, aspirin therapy only minimally increases the risk of intracerebral hemorrhage, if at all.

The risk of intracerebral hemorrhage is directly correlated with the degree of anticoagulation (e.g., by heparin). However, anticoagulation is not the strongest risk factor for intracerebral hemorrhage.

Arterial hypertension is the single most important predisposing factor for atraumatic intracerebral hemorrhage. Chronic hypertension results in lipohyalinosis of the arterial walls, leading to microaneurysm formation and elevated risk of rupture. Acute hypertension then leads to rupture of the weakened vessels, which likely was the mechanism of rupture in this patient.

Management of intracerebral hemorrhage depends on the intracranial pressure (ICP) of the patient. If ICP is normal, blood pressure should be decreased to < 160 mm Hg through labetalol or nicardipine administration. If intracranial hypertension is suspected (as is likely in this patient, given his altered mental status and sluggishly reactive pupils), blood pressure should be lowered more cautiously, as cerebral perfusion must be maintained. Finally, if herniation is suspected (e.g., uncal herniation), emergency craniotomy is required.

images.title: Basal ganglia hemorrhage
images.description: Hemorrhage in the region of the left basal ganglia causing a midline shift to the rightThe basal ganglia are supplied by the lenticulostriate arteries, which arise from the middle cerebral artery. Hemorrhage from a lenticulostriate artery (e.g., due to poorly controlled hypertension or rupture of a Charcot-Bouchard microaneurysm) leads to a basal ganglia hemorrhage.

answers.explanation_why: Smoking does increase the risk of intracerebral hemorrhage in a dose-response relationship. The mechanism is likely multifactorial and includes both increased blood pressure and arterial wall damage associated with smoking. However, it is not the strongest risk factor for intracerebral hemorrhage.

images.title: Basal ganglia hemorrhage
images.description:
CT head (without contrast; axial plane) of a patient with a history of chronic hypertensionHyperdense hemorrhage in the left basal ganglia is surrounded by hypodense perifocal edema (red overlay).The location is typical for hemorrhage from the lenticulostriate arteries as a result of long-standing hypertension.1: head of caudate nucleus; 2: putamen; 3 and green overlay: internal capsule; 4: thalamus
Arrowheads: calcified pineal gland; white circles: calcified choroid plexus

question_text: A 26-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which she was a restrained passenger. On arrival, she is lethargic and incoherent. She is in respiratory distress. Her pulse is 130/min, respirations are 29/min, and blood pressure is 88/58 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 70%. Examination shows multiple facial lacerations. There is dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds over the left lung base. Abdominal examination shows diffuse tenderness with no guarding or rebound. Bowel sounds are normal. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Her hemoglobin concentration is 8.1 g/dL. An x-ray of the chest shows a fractured left second rib, depression of the left main bronchus, deviation of the nasogastric tube to the right, left pleural effusion, and a widened mediastinum. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 26-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being involved in a high-speed motor vehicle collision in which she was a restrained passenger. On arrival, she is lethargic and incoherent. She is in respiratory distress. Her pulse is 130/min, respirations are 29/min, and blood pressure is 88/58 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 70%. Examination shows multiple facial lacerations. There is dullness to percussion and decreased breath sounds over the left lung base. Abdominal examination shows diffuse tenderness with no guarding or rebound. Bowel sounds are normal. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Her hemoglobin concentration is 8.1 g/dL. An x-ray of the chest shows a fractured left second rib, depression of the left main bronchus, deviation of the nasogastric tube to the right, left pleural effusion, and a widened mediastinum. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This condition should always be considered in patients presenting with respiratory distress and signs of developing shock after trauma from rapid deceleration (e.g., high-speed motor vehicle collision). The x-ray findings are highly suggestive of the diagnosis.
learning_objective: Recognize thoracic aortic rupture.

answers.explanation_why: Flail chest can manifest with respiratory distress. However, paradoxical chest movement is not present in this patient. Additionally, the chest x-ray shows only one fractured rib, and a widened mediastinum is not associated with flail chest, making it an unlikely diagnosis.

images.title: Pathomechanism of flail chest
images.description: Paradoxical movement of a separate chest wall segment that moves inward during inspiration and outward during expiration. Caused by detachment of a segment of the rib cage from the chest wall due to fracture of three or more adjacent ribs in at least two places.

answers.explanation_why: Diaphragmatic rupture commonly results from blunt or penetrating trauma and occurs more often on the left than on the right side (as the liver protects against a rupture on the right). The condition can manifest with respiratory distress and decreased breath sounds. However, x-ray findings typically show herniation of abdominal organs like the stomach and colon, causing an “hourglass” appearance rather than a widened mediastinum.

images.title: Diaphragmatic rupture
images.description: AP chest X-ray of a 29-year-old patient with chest trauma after a motor-vehicle crash: the tip of the central venous catheter on the right side (black arrows) projects onto the right atrium. The left hemidiaphragm (black dotted line) is much higher than the right one. The stomach is located within the thorax, as can be seen by the circled gastric bubble. The lung tissue shows streaky densities, which hints towards intraparenchymal hemorrhage. The combination of these findings most likely indicates a ruptured diaphragm with a stomach herniated into the thoracic cavity.

answers.explanation_why: Pulmonary contusion typically occurs after blunt trauma and can manifest with tachycardia, respiratory distress, and hypoxia. However, it does not commonly present with dullness on percussion. Additionally, the chest x-ray typically shows patchy alveolar infiltrates and not a widened mediastinum, as described above.

images.title: Pulmonary trauma
images.description: CT chest (axial plane; lung window) following trauma to the chestAreas of ground glass and consolidation in both lungs are the result of pulmonary contusion (green overlay). Ovoid traumatic lacerations in the left lung contain opaque blood (red overlay). Two of the lacerations also contain air, producing air-fluid levels (dashed line). A pneumothorax is present anteriorly in the right hemithorax (blue overlay).

answers.explanation_why: Traumatic bronchial rupture often results from high-velocity blunt chest wall trauma and can manifest with respiratory distress. However, it is typically associated with pneumothorax and subcutaneous emphysema – features not present in this woman.

images.title: Traumatic pneumothorax and pneumomediastinum with subcutaneous emphysema
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view)Extensive subcutaneous emphysema is seen as linear lucencies throughout the soft tissues of the thorax, neck, and upper abdomen (examples indicated by green overlay). A small residual right pneumothorax (arrowheads) is visible and pneumomediastinum is seen along the trachea, main bronchi, and cardiac silhouette (red overlay and arrows). A chest tube (yellow overlay) is in place, with its tip in the apex of the right hemithorax.Pneumomediastinum and pneumothorax can result from blunt or penetrating thoracic injury and various other conditions (e.g., lung disease, intestinal perforation, medical procedure). Air that escapes from the lungs, airways, or bowel can track into the mediastinal and subcutaneous soft tissues.

answers.explanation_why: A widened mediastinum, esophageal deviation, depression of the left main bronchus, and hemothorax (suggested by left pleural effusion) are consistent with thoracic aortic rupture (TAR). TAR can be traumatic (e.g., due to high-velocity blunt chest wall trauma) or spontaneous (e.g., following aortic dissection). Only around 20% of patients with blunt traumatic aortic injuries survive long enough to reach the hospital; therefore, immediate resuscitation and prompt surgical repair of the thoracic aorta is required in patients with suggestive findings (e.g., symptoms of respiratory distress, features of hemorrhagic shock).

images.title: Nontraumatic rupture of the thoracic aorta
images.description: CT chest (with contrast; axial plane)There is extravasation of contrast (red overlay) from the nonaneurysmal atherosclerotic descending thoracic aorta (bright green overlay), with surrounding hematoma (green striped overlay).

answers.explanation_why: Cardiac tamponade results from conditions such as pericarditis, chest trauma, malignancies, or kidney dysfunction. Cardiac tamponade can manifest with respiratory distress. This patient has hypotension, but she does not have the jugular venous distention or muffled heart sounds that would be expected in an individual with cardiac tamponade (Beck’s triad). Additionally, in contrast to this vignette, x-ray findings of cardiac tamponade would typically include an enlarged cardiac silhouette.

images.title: Enlarged cardiac silhouette
images.description: Chest X-ray (PA view) of a patient with a history of pericarditis and clinical findings of tamponadeThe cardiac silhouette is enlarged (globular water bottle-shape; enlargement highlighted by green-hatched overlay) due to pericardial effusion.

answers.explanation_why: While a tension pneumothorax can manifest with tachycardia and hypoxia, the lung is typically hyperresonant and not dull to percussion. Additionally, although mediastinal shift is seen on the chest x-ray of tension pneumothorax, absent lung markings would also be expected and there would not be a widened mediastinum.

images.title: Tension pneumothorax
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view)A large pneumothorax (green overlay) has resulted in collapse of the right lung along the mediastinum (edge marked by white dashed line). No bronchovascular markings are seen in the right hemithorax. Additionally, the mediastinum has shifted to the contralateral left side (blue line and arrows), the right hemidiaphragm is depressed (red line and arrow), and the right intercostal spaces are widened (example indicated by white arrows).These findings are characteristic of tension pneumothorax.

question_text: A 59-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 10-month history of a nonhealing ulcer on her left ankle. During the past 14 years, she has had multiple ulcers over the same ankle that have subsided with wound care and dressing, which she gets from a local pharmacy. The patient has not been evaluated by a physician in 15 years. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and gastroesophageal reflux disease. Current medications include metformin, sitagliptin, and omeprazole. She is 162 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 89 kg (196 lb); BMI is 34 kg/m^2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a 7.5-cm (3-in) ulcer with elevated, indurated margins and a necrotic base above the left medial malleolus. The skin around the left ankle appears darker than the right and there are multiple excoriation marks. There is 2+ pretibial edema of the lower extremities. Peripheral pulses are 3+ in all extremities. Sensation to pinprick, temperature, and vibration is normal over the lower extremities. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 59-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 10-month history of a nonhealing ulcer on her left ankle. During the past 14 years, she has had multiple ulcers over the same ankle that have subsided with wound care and dressing, which she gets from a local pharmacy. The patient has not been evaluated by a physician in 15 years. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and gastroesophageal reflux disease. Current medications include metformin, sitagliptin, and omeprazole. She is 162 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 89 kg (196 lb); BMI is 34 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a 7.5-cm (3-in) ulcer with elevated, indurated margins and a necrotic base above the left medial malleolus. The skin around the left ankle appears darker than the right and there are multiple excoriation marks. There is 2+ pretibial edema of the lower extremities. Peripheral pulses are 3+ in all extremities. Sensation to pinprick, temperature, and vibration is normal over the lower extremities. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: A nonhealing wound in an area of chronically damaged skin (e.g., long-standing venous ulcer) should raise concern for a Marjolin ulcer.
learning_objective: Recognize a nonhealing wound suspicious for Marjolin ulcer, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic procedure.

answers.explanation_why: Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) is the most accurate test for diagnosing peripheral arterial disease (PAD), which can manifest with ulcers in the lower extremities. However, arterial ulcers are typically found on pressure points of the foot such as the lateral malleolus. Moreover, despite having risk factors for PAD (e.g., diabetes, obesity), this patient does not have other characteristic findings, such as absent or diminished peripheral pulses, intermittent claudication, or rest pain. Finally, DSA is an invasive and expensive procedure, and ankle-brachial index is the first-line diagnostic test for PAD.

answers.content: Provide topical wound care and schedule follow-up in 3 weeks
answers.explanation_why: Topical wound care and follow-up may be the initial approach in the treatment of certain ulcers (e.g., ulcers due to venous insufficiency or diabetic neuropathy). This patient's nonhealing skin lesion raises concern for a Marjolin ulcer, for which further management should not be delayed.

answers.content: Perform sharp surgical debridement and improve glycemic control
answers.explanation_why: Sharp surgical debridement of the ulcer and improved glycemic control, both of which promote healing and decrease the risk of bacterial infection, are the initial therapy for diabetic ulcers. Diabetic foot ulcers are typically caused by peripheral neuropathy, which is unlikely in patients with a normal neurological examination of the extremities. This patient's nonhealing skin lesion raises concern for a Marjolin ulcer, which requires different management.

This patient presents with peripheral edema, skin hyperpigmentation, pruritus (indicated in this case by excoriation marks), and an ulcer that is located above the medial malleolus, all of which are typical features of chronic venous disease. Endovenous thermal ablation is a definitive treatment option for patients with chronic venous insufficiency (CVI) who do not respond to conservative management. Before initiating treatment for CVI, a different measure is indicated in this patient who presents with a nonhealing skin lesion that raises concern for a Marjolin ulcer.

answers.content: Perform a punch biopsy of the lesion
answers.explanation_why:
Marjolin ulcer is a rare but aggressive form of cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC) that arises from chronic wounds or scars. The progression of a chronic wound to a Marjolin ulcer is slow, with a latency period of several years to decades until malignant transformation occurs. Marjolin ulcers have a poor prognosis and require prompt diagnosis (using a punch biopsy or a wedge biopsy in patients with larger lesions) to determine further management. In addition to histologic confirmation, patients require grading and staging of the tumor.

Surgical excision of the lesion along with a margin of normal skin is the primary method of treatment; radiotherapy and/or chemotherapy may be used as adjuvants.

question_text:
A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after falling 16 feet from a ladder. He has severe pain in both his legs and his right arm. He appears pale and diaphoretic. He is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m^2. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 120/min and weak, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg. He opens his eyes and withdraws in response to painful stimuli and makes incomprehensible sounds. The abdomen is soft and nontender. All extremities are cold, with 1+ pulses distally. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:

pH
7.29

PCO_2

33 mm Hg

PO_2

65 mm Hg

HCO_3^-

15 mEq/L

A CT scan shows displaced fractures of the pelvic ring, as well as fractures of both tibiae, the right distal radius, and right proximal humerus. The patient undergoes emergent open reduction and is admitted to the intensive care unit. Which of the following best indicates inadequate fluid resuscitation?
content_preview: A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after falling 16 feet from a ladder. He has severe pain in both his legs and his right arm. He appears pale and diaphoretic. He is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 26 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 120/min and weak, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 80/50 mm Hg. He opens his eyes and withdraws in response to painful stimuli and makes incomprehensible sounds. The abdomen is soft and nontender. All extremities are cold, with 1+ pulses distally. Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows: pH 7.29 PCO2 33 mm Hg PO2 65 mm Hg HCO3- 15 mEq/L A CT scan shows displaced fractures of the pelvic ring, as well as fractures of both tibiae, the right distal radius, and right proximal humerus. The patient undergoes emergent open reduction and is admitted to the intensive care unit. Which of the following best indicates inadequate fluid resuscitation?
hint: There are many ways that physicians monitor volume status, but some are more reliable than others in the absence of confounding medications or illnesses.
learning_objective: Recognize indicators of inadequate fluid resuscitation, and recall the expected urine output for adequate end-organ perfusion.

answers.explanation_why: High pulse pressure is usually caused by an increase in stroke volume (e.g., normal exercise, aortic regurgitation) or a decrease in arterial compliance (e.g., atherosclerosis) and would likely increase following fluid resuscitation. However, pulse pressure is an indicator of stroke volume and not a direct indicator of end-organ perfusion. Fluid resuscitation aims to achieve adequate end-organ perfusion, so a change in pulse pressure is not the best indicator to evaluate fluid resuscitation.

answers.content: Urine output of 25 mL in 3 hours
answers.explanation_why:
The goal of fluid resuscitation is to maintain adequate end-organ perfusion and to restore intravascular volume. Since renal blood flow (and therefore GFR) is highly sensitive to changes in blood pressure and intravascular volume, urine output can serve as a surrogate measure to determine if fluid resuscitation is adequate. Ideally, urine output in adults should be greater than 0.5 mL/kg/hr. Therefore, a 70-kg man should have a urine output of 35–70 mL/hr. A urine output of 25mL in 3 hours suggests that his kidneys are not receiving adequate blood flow and therefore that he has not received adequate fluid resuscitation.

With adequate fluid resuscitation, an increase in some of the other indices, such as pulse pressure and Glasgow coma scale, might occur before a change in urine output is apparent. However, these parameters are not specific indicators of end-organ perfusion. Other parameters, such as lactate and a base deficit, are more useful for determining the prognosis than for guiding fluid therapy.

Confusion, lethargy, and even coma can be seen in patients with severe shock. However, a low Glasgow coma score (GCS) following trauma may be caused by a number of factors, including hypotension, hypoxia, and intracranial hemorrhage. Therefore, the GCS should not be used as a guide for fluid therapy.

An increase in serum lactate (> 4 mEq/L) may indicate tissue hypoxia due to inadequate tissue perfusion. However, serum lactate levels are not used to determine whether fluid resuscitation is inadequate because, even after adequate fluid resuscitation and correction of tissue hypoperfusion, lactate levels may not reach normal levels (< 2 mEq/L) for a few hours. Lactate clearance may take even longer in critically ill patients as a result of a prolonged lactate half-life (due to hepatic and/or renal dysfunction) and/or increased glycolysis. In trauma patients, elevated lactate levels are associated with increased mortality and are used to evaluate the prognosis.

A prolonged capillary refill time (≥ 3 seconds) is seen as a result of peripheral vasoconstriction in patients with hypotension. However, capillary refill is not the most direct measure of organ perfusion and adequate volume resuscitation, as it can be affected by confounding factors (e.g., ambient temperature, lighting, physical exam techniques, peripheral artery disease, blood viscosity).

This patient has an increased base deficit (> 2 mEq/L), which indicates metabolic acidosis (most likely due to lactic acidosis from inadequate perfusion and fluid resuscitation). Normalization of the base deficit (< 2 mmol/L) following fluid resuscitation would suggest an improvement in tissue perfusion and a more favorable prognosis, not inadequate fluid resuscitation.

question_text:
A 63-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of severe abdominal pain that started suddenly 1 hour ago while he was having a barbecue with his family. The pain is located in the middle of his abdomen, and he describes it as 10 out of 10 in intensity. He feels nauseated and has vomited twice. He has also had a loose bowel movement. He was diagnosed with hypertension 2 years ago and was started on hydrochlorothiazide. He stopped taking his pills 1 week ago because of several episodes of heart racing and dizziness that he attributes to his medication. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the last 40 years. He is in severe distress. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 130/90 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows an irregularly irregular rhythm. Bowel sounds are normal. The abdomen is soft and mildly tender. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
16.8 g/dL

Leukocyte count
13,000/mm^3

Platelet count
340,000/mm^3

Prothrombin time
13 seconds

Partial thromboplastin time
38 seconds

Lactate (venous)

2.4 mEq/L (N = 0.5–2.2)

Serum

Urea nitrogen
15 mg/dL

Creatinine
1.2 mg/dL

Lactate dehydrogenase
215 U/L

CT angiography is performed, and the diagnosis is confirmed. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

The pain is located in the middle of his abdomen, and he describes it as 10 out of 10 in intensity. He feels nauseated and has vomited twice. He has also had a loose bowel movement. He was diagnosed with hypertension 2 years ago and was started on hydrochlorothiazide. He stopped taking his pills 1 week ago because of several episodes of heart racing and dizziness that he attributes to his medication. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the last 40 years. He is in severe distress. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 130/90 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows an irregularly irregular rhythm. Bowel sounds are normal. The abdomen is soft and mildly tender. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 16.8 g/dL Leukocyte count 13,000/mm3 Platelet count 340,000/mm3 Prothrombin time 13 seconds Partial thromboplastin time 38 seconds Lactate (venous) 2.4 mEq/L (N = 0.5–2.2) Serum Urea nitrogen 15 mg/dL Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL Lactate dehydrogenase 215 U/L CT angiography is performed, and the diagnosis is confirmed. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient has severe abdominal pain disproportionate to his unremarkable abdominal examination. This finding, along with leukocytosis, increased serum lactate and lactate dehydrogenase concentrations, irregularly irregular rhythm suggesting atrial fibrillation, and acute progression of symptoms, are most consistent with acute mesenteric ischemia due to embolic occlusion of the mesenteric arteries.
learning_objective: Recognize acute mesenteric ischemia, and choose the most appropriate revascularization technique.

answers.explanation_why: Explorative laparotomy is reserved for acutely ill patients who are at risk for rapid deterioration, including patients with acute mesenteric ischemia who are hemodynamically unstable or have evidence of peritonitis (rebound tenderness and involuntary guarding). Because this patient has stable vital signs and a benign abdominal exam, explorative laparotomy is not the preferred treatment at this time.

Anticoagulation with warfarin should be considered in all patients with atrial fibrillation (AF), as AF increases the risk of thromboembolic complications, especially if rhythm control is unsuccessful. However, anticoagulation with warfarin requires bridging therapy with heparin because of the initial risk of warfarin-associated hypercoagulation. In addition, warfarin therapy is a long-term measure to treat underlying AF but is not indicated in the management of acute mesenteric ischemia.

Although colonoscopy is used to diagnose large bowel pathologies (e.g., lower gastrointestinal bleeding, inflammatory bowel disease, diverticulosis, colon cancer), it is not indicated for patients with acute mesenteric ischemia. Poor patient preparation will likely lead to poor visualization of the colon, and the diseased bowel is more prone to perforation when insufflating while advancing the scope.

MR angiography can be used to identify blocks in the mesenteric vessels. CT angiography is usually preferred over MR angiography because it is faster and more sensitive for nonocclusive mesenteric ischemia and for distal thromboembolism of the mesenteric arteries. MR angiography may be used in patients with acute mesenteric ischemia who are allergic to contrast agents used with CT imaging. Because this patient has already received CT angiography to confirm the diagnosis, he does not need further imaging.

Cefazolin is a narrow-spectrum antibiotic that is commonly used perioperatively to prevent surgical site infection. Antibiotic prophylaxis should be considered in all patients with acute mesenteric ischemia to decrease the risk of sepsis. This patient, however, should receive treatment with a broad-spectrum antibiotic.

Endovascular revascularization is the preferred treatment for hemodynamically stable patients with acute mesenteric ischemia who do not present with signs or symptoms of advanced intestinal ischemia (e.g., peritonitis, sepsis). This procedure is minimally invasive, and studies suggest similar efficacy to open surgical treatment. Reassuring vital signs and benign abdominal examination findings in this patient suggest acute bowel ischemia without permanent infarction, which is likely to resolve with the restoration of blood flow. This patient should also receive supportive measures (e.g., intravenous fluids, nasogastric decompression, broad-spectrum antibiotics) as well as anticoagulation, preferably with unfractionated heparin.

question_text: A 68-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of an oozing, red area above the left ankle. She does not recall any trauma to the lower extremity. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and ulcerative colitis. She had a myocardial infarction 2 years ago and a stroke 7 years ago. She has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 48 years and drinks 2 alcoholic beverages daily. Current medications include warfarin, metformin, aspirin, atorvastatin, carvedilol, and mesalamine. She is 165 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 67 kg (148 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m^2. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 135/90 mm Hg. Examination shows yellow-brown spots and dilated tortuous veins over the lower extremities. The feet and the left calf are edematous. Femoral, popliteal, and pedal pulses are palpable bilaterally. There is a 3 cm (1.2 in) painless, shallow, exudative ulcer surrounded by granulation tissue above the medial left ankle. There is slight drooping of the right side of the face. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's ulcer?
content_preview: A 68-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of an oozing, red area above the left ankle. She does not recall any trauma to the lower extremity. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and ulcerative colitis. She had a myocardial infarction 2 years ago and a stroke 7 years ago. She has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 48 years and drinks 2 alcoholic beverages daily. Current medications include warfarin, metformin, aspirin, atorvastatin, carvedilol, and mesalamine. She is 165 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 67 kg (148 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m2. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 135/90 mm Hg. Examination shows yellow-brown spots and dilated tortuous veins over the lower extremities. The feet and the left calf are edematous. Femoral, popliteal, and pedal pulses are palpable bilaterally. There is a 3 cm (1.2 in) painless, shallow, exudative ulcer surrounded by granulation tissue above the medial left ankle. There is slight drooping of the right side of the face. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's ulcer?
hint: This patient has risk factors for several types of lower extremity ulcerations. The key findings in this patient are edema, yellow-brown spots, and dilated tortuous veins in the lower extremities.
learning_objective: Recognize venous insufficiency as a cause of lower extremity ulcers.

answers.explanation_why: Decreased arterial blood flow due to peripheral arterial disease (PAD) may lead to arterial ulcers. These typically painful ulcers are commonly located on the lateral surface of the ankle and the tips of the digits. This patient has many risk factors for arterial disease (stroke, myocardial infarction, smoking, type 2 diabetes mellitus), but does not have other manifestations of PAD like pallor and atrophy of the extremities or claudication. Additionally, she has a normal pulse status, making this diagnosis unlikely.

images.title: Ischemic ulcers
images.description: Photograph of left footNumerous ulcers are visible on this patient's foot.This appearance is suggestive of ischemic ulcers in peripheral arterial disease.

answers.explanation_why: Peripheral neuropathy (perhaps due to diabetes mellitus) often leads to neuropathic foot ulcers, commonly occurring on the bottom of the foot at sites of undetected injury or pressure. While this patient does have diabetes, her ulcer does not fit the typical description of a neuropathic ulcer.

Neutrophilic dermatosis (pyoderma gangrenosum) is a condition that causes deep ulcers, usually on the legs. This patient has ulcerative colitis, which is a risk factor of pyoderma gangrenosum, but the lesion generally begins as a small papule at the location of prior trauma (pathergy) and may progress to a large necrotic wound. It is not typically associated with edema and the skin changes seen in this patient.

images.title: Pyoderma gangrenosum
images.description: A purulent ulcerative lesion with central necrosis and erythematous borders is visible on this patient's shin. The surrounding tissue appears to be swollen.These findings are consistent with pyoderma gangrenosum, which most commonly affects the lower extremities.

answers.explanation_why: Chronic venous insufficiency often leads to venous ulcers or mixed ulcers, classically appearing just above the medial ankle and associated with skin changes and unilateral edema. The location of this patient's ulcer, as well as the accompanying varicosity, skin color changes, and lower extremity edema make venous insufficiency the most likely primary etiology of this ulcer. This ulcer is likely a mixed ulcer because of this patient's cardiovascular history, diabetes, and smoking.

images.title: Features of arterial, venous, and neuropathic ulcers

answers.explanation_why: Chronic pressure may lead to a pressure ulcer. Pressure ulcers typically occur in immobilized patients and present as a painful loss of skin and subcutaneous tissue (e.g., over the sacrum, heel, or occiput). Diabetes, smoking, and cardiovascular disease, as seen in this patient, are also risk factors. The location of this patient's ulcer as well as the fact that she is ambulatory make a pressure ulcer unlikely.

images.title: Stage 3 decubitus (pressure) ulcer
images.description: A decubitus ulcer with loss of all skin layers and subcutaneous involvement is visible to the right of the intergluteal cleft.

answers.explanation_why: Warfarin-induced skin necrosis is a subtype of drug-induced microvascular occlusion. It is caused by warfarin initially causing a procoagulable state, typically 3–5 days after initiating therapy. It manifests with pain and redness and may lead to hemorrhagic bullae and eventual necrosis. This condition is not associated with slowly progressive chronic skin changes as described in this patient, who has been taking warfarin for a longer period.

answers.content: Vasculitis of small and medium-sized vessels
answers.explanation_why: Thromboangiitis obliterans (Buerger disease) is a recurring progressive vasculitis of small and medium-sized vessels of the hands and feet that is strongly associated with smoking tobacco and typically affects men. While this patient is a smoker, she does not have other symptoms of arterial insufficiency (claudication, ischemic ulcers at the toe tips and lateral ankle), making this diagnosis unlikely.

question_text: A 53-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of severe pain in her right leg while walking. She used to be able to walk a half-mile (800 m) to the grocery store but has been unable to walk 200 meters without stopping because of the pain over the past month. The pain subsides after 5 minutes, after which she can walk again. She has hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 32 years. Current medications include metformin, enalapril, aspirin, and warfarin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows an irregularly irregular pulse. The right lower extremity is cooler than the left lower extremity. The skin over the right leg appears shiny and dry. Femoral pulses are palpated bilaterally; pedal pulses are diminished on the right side. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 53-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of severe pain in her right leg while walking. She used to be able to walk a half-mile (800 m) to the grocery store but has been unable to walk 200 meters without stopping because of the pain over the past month. The pain subsides after 5 minutes, after which she can walk again. She has hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 32 years. Current medications include metformin, enalapril, aspirin, and warfarin. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows an irregularly irregular pulse. The right lower extremity is cooler than the left lower extremity. The skin over the right leg appears shiny and dry. Femoral pulses are palpated bilaterally; pedal pulses are diminished on the right side. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The presence of claudication pain, trophic skin changes, and diminished pulses in a chronic smoker should raise concern for peripheral arterial disease (PAD) Fontaine stage IIb (claudication at a walking distance < 200 m).
learning_objective: Recognize peripheral arterial disease, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why: Duplex ultrasonography is appropriate in suspected acute limb ischemia (ALI), which may manifest with coolness and decreased pulses in the leg, and is likely in a patient with multiple atherosclerotic risk factors (hypertension, diabetes mellitus, smoking) and a history of heart disease (i.e., atrial fibrillation). However, the onset of ALI is typically acute, involving severe, acute pain, paresthesia, and weakness of the leg. This patient likely has PAD, in which duplex ultrasonography can be helpful to assess blood flow status; however, a different, quicker, and less expensive test should be performed first to confirm the diagnosis.

Although CT angiography (CTA) is useful to identify atherosclerotic plaques, it is not the first step in diagnosing PAD because it is expensive, invasive, and exposes patients to contrast agents and radiation.

Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) is used for diagnosing PAD and also allows for simultaneous treatment of arterial stenosis through percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA). However, this procedure is invasive and expensive, and revascularization is not the first-line therapy for PAD with claudication symptoms only on exertion. This patient's diagnosis must first be confirmed with a noninvasive test.

Ankle-brachial index (ABI) is the first-line diagnostic test in PAD because it is readily available, noninvasive, as well as highly specific and sensitive. Reduced ABI values between 0.4–0.9 indicate mild to moderate PAD with claudication, whereas values below 0.4 correlate to severe PAD with resting pain and/or gangrene. An ABI > 1.4 in patients with suspected PAD may indicate calcific sclerosis with noncompressible vascular walls (e.g., in patients with diabetes). A low ABI (≤ 0.9) and a high ABI (> 1.4) are associated with an increased risk of all-cause and cardiovascular mortality. In patients with a normal ABI and high suspicion for PAD, exercise testing may be required. Vascular imaging (e.g., with MR angiography) is not required for diagnosis but helps assess site(s) and extent of arterial occlusion or stenosis and collateral blood flow if revascularization is planned.

MR angiography (MRA) can identify atherosclerotic plaques (which lead to PAD). In contrast to other imaging techniques, MRA does not require administering a contrast agent and does not expose the patient to radiation. However, MRA is not the initial step in diagnosing PAD because it is expensive and not readily available.

question_text:
A 78-year-old man comes to the physician for a medical evaluation 5 days before undergoing abdominal hernia repair. Two years ago, he underwent a mechanical mitral valve replacement for chronic primary mitral regurgitation. He has hypertension. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. Current medications include warfarin, hydrochlorothiazide, and aspirin. His temperature is 37.1°C (99.3°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 126/74 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination reveals a mitral click. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
13.1 g/dL

Leukocyte count
8900/mm^3

Platelet count
230,000/mm^3

Prothrombin time
23 seconds (INR = 2.1)

Creatinine clearance
102 mL/min

Results of urinalysis are within the reference ranges. An x-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities. An ECG shows signs of mild left atrial enlargement. Which of the following instructions regarding medication is the most appropriate at this time?
content_preview: A 78-year-old man comes to the physician for a medical evaluation 5 days before undergoing abdominal hernia repair. Two years ago, he underwent a mechanical mitral valve replacement for chronic primary mitral regurgitation. He has hypertension. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. Current medications include warfarin, hydrochlorothiazide, and aspirin. His temperature is 37.1°C (99.3°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 126/74 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination reveals a mitral click. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 13.1 g/dL Leukocyte count 8900/mm3 Platelet count 230,000/mm3 Prothrombin time 23 seconds (INR = 2.1) Creatinine clearance 102 mL/min Results of urinalysis are within the reference ranges. An x-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities. An ECG shows signs of mild left atrial enlargement. Which of the following instructions regarding medication is the most appropriate at this time?
hint: This patient will undergo surgery with a moderate risk of perioperative bleeding in 5 days, and his mechanical mitral heart valve, age, and hypertension increase his risk of thromboembolism. To balance these risks, the Vitamin K antagonist warfarin should be discontinued (VKA interruption), and preoperative bridging anticoagulation should be initiated.
learning_objective: Choose the correct timing for anticoagulant therapy modification before surgery.

answers.content: Stop warfarin now, start dalteparin therapy in 2 days, and discontinue 24 hours prior to surgery
answers.explanation_why:
Preoperative bridging anticoagulation involves the temporary administration of a short-acting parenteral anticoagulant after VKA interruption. Because warfarin has a half-life of approximately 36–42 hours, starting the low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) dalteparin 2 days after discontinuation (or after 2–3 missed doses) allows warfarin to reach subtherapeutic levels. This timing ensures that the patient is not at a higher than necessary risk of hemorrhage from two anticoagulants. Alternatively, INR can be monitored and bridging anticoagulation started as soon as INR is in the subtherapeutic range. Because LMWHs have a short half-life (e.g., 3–5 hours for dalteparin), discontinuing LMWH 24 hours before surgery minimizes the risk of excessive bleeding during and immediately after the procedure. After surgery, VKAs can usually be resumed after 12–24 hours.

Preoperative bridging anticoagulation is recommended for patients at high risk of developing perioperative thromboemboli. Risk factors include history of stroke or transient ischemic attack (TIA) in the past 3 months, presence of a mechanical mitral heart valve with major risk factors for stroke (e.g., hypertension, age ≥ 75 years), atrial fibrillation with a CHA2DS2-VASc score ≥ 7, history of venous thromboembolism (VTE) in the past 3 months, rheumatic valvular heart disease, and active cancer with increased VTE risk (e.g., gastric or pancreatic cancer). In most patients, preoperative bridging anticoagulation is not recommended due to the risk of perioperative bleeding.

answers.content: Switch warfarin to dabigatran and discontinue 48-72 hours prior to surgery
answers.explanation_why: Starting the direct thrombin inhibitor dabigatran immediately after discontinuing warfarin would not allow adequate time for warfarin to be eliminated from the body, since the half-life of warfarin is approximately 36–42 hours. The patient would be at a high risk of bleeding with two anticoagulants at the same time. Moreover, dabigatran is contraindicated in patients with a mechanical valve because it has been shown to increase the risk of thromboembolic events in this patient population. Finally, dabigatran has a half-life of 15 hours, making it less optimal than drugs with shorter half-lives because it is not reliably eliminated from the body immediately before surgery.

answers.content: Stop warfarin and start unfractionated heparin now, discontinue 4-6 hours prior to surgery
answers.explanation_why: Unfractionated heparin (UFH) can be used as bridging anticoagulation and should be discontinued 4–6 hours before surgery to minimize the risk of perioperative bleeding. However, starting UFH immediately after discontinuing warfarin does not allow adequate time for warfarin to be eliminated from the body, because its half-life is approximately 36–42 hours. The patient would be at a high risk of bleeding with two anticoagulants at the same time. UFH is usually started 2 days after discontinuing warfarin, allowing adequate time for warfarin to reach subtherapeutic levels.

Generally, warfarin may be continued for procedures with a low risk of perioperative bleeding (e.g., cataract surgery, pacemaker placement, dermatological surgery). This patient will undergo surgery that poses a moderate bleeding risk, and continuing warfarin during the perioperative period poses an unacceptably high risk of bleeding.

answers.content: Stop warfarin now and continue post-surgery
answers.explanation_why: Stopping warfarin decreases the risk of perioperative bleeding. However, this patient has a high thromboembolic risk, and stopping warfarin without bridging therapy with another anticoagulant increases the risk of DVT and/or pulmonary embolism.

question_text: A 27-year-old soldier is brought to the emergency department of a military hospital 20 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle accident during a training exercise. He was an unrestrained passenger. On arrival, he has shortness of breath and chest pain. He appears anxious. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. He is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Examination shows bruising on the chest, extremities, and abdomen. The lungs are clear to auscultation. He has normal heart sounds and flat neck veins. The abdomen is flat, soft, and mildly tender. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. High-flow oxygen and intravenous fluid therapy are initiated. A focused ultrasonographic assessment (FAST scan) shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 27-year-old soldier is brought to the emergency department of a military hospital 20 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle accident during a training exercise. He was an unrestrained passenger. On arrival, he has shortness of breath and chest pain. He appears anxious. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. He is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Examination shows bruising on the chest, extremities, and abdomen. The lungs are clear to auscultation. He has normal heart sounds and flat neck veins. The abdomen is flat, soft, and mildly tender. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. High-flow oxygen and intravenous fluid therapy are initiated. A focused ultrasonographic assessment (FAST scan) shows no abnormalities. An x-ray of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The patient sustained a deceleration injury and has mediastinal widening on chest x-ray, suggesting blunt thoracic aortic injury.
learning_objective: Recognize blunt thoracic aortic injury, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic test in a hemodynamically stable patient.

answers.explanation_why: Pericardiocentesis is indicated for the treatment of cardiac tamponade, which can occur following trauma (due to a hemopericardium) and cause chest pain, dyspnea, and a widened mediastinum. However, patients with cardiac tamponade typically have muffled heart sounds, hemodynamic instability, and distended (rather than flat) neck veins. The normal FAST scan and the absence of an enlarged cardiac silhouette on chest x-ray make a hemopericardium unlikely.

Blunt force aortic injuries range from small intimal tears and intramural hematomas to aortic rupture. Contrast-enhanced CT angiography (CECT angiography) is indicated for the diagnosis of aortic injury in hemodynamically stable patients and should be performed if the patient has symptoms suggestive of aortic injury (e.g., chest pain), a history of high-energy trauma, or features that suggest aortic injury on the FAST scan (e.g., hemothorax) or chest x-ray (e.g., mediastinal widening, aortic knob loss). CECT angiography has high sensitivity and specificity, can screen for additional vascular injuries (e.g., abdominal aortic injury), and provides anatomical information for planning surgical management. Patients who are hemodynamically unstable should be urgently evaluated with transesophageal echocardiography in the operating room.

Although aortography, which is performed using vascular catheterization, was previously used to evaluate for aortic pathology, less invasive modalities that are more readily available are now preferred.

A transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) to identify thoracic aortic injury is indicated in patients who are hemodynamically unstable and cannot be transported safely for other imaging modalities. A hemodynamically stable patient requires a different imaging modality that provides more detailed anatomical information.
A chest tube can be used to treat patients with a pneumothorax or hemothorax. However, this patient's chest x-ray and FAST scan do not indicate the presence of either of these conditions.

Intubation with positive pressure ventilation may be indicated if the patient has evidence of a flail chest or is developing acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). This patient's chest x-ray finding suggests a different diagnosis.

images.title: Widened mediastinum secondary to traumatic thoracic aortic injury
images.description: X-ray chest (AP view) of a patient with a recent history of a motor vehicle crashA lobulated convexity projects along the left superior mediastinum (green overlay and arrows) in the region of the aortic knob.The differential for the mediastinal widening includes a range of mediastinal soft tissue masses; however, traumatic mediastinal injury (particularly involving the thoracic aorta) is the primary concern in view of the trauma setting. CT angiography is the appropriate next imaging study in a hemodynamically stable patient.Green dashed line: normal margin of the aorta

question_text:
Twelve hours after undergoing a femoral artery embolectomy, an 84-year-old man is found unconscious on the floor by his hospital bed. He had received a patient-controlled analgesia pump after surgery. He underwent 2 coronary bypass surgeries 2 and 6 years ago. He has coronary artery disease, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, gastroesophageal reflux disease, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His current medications include metoprolol, atorvastatin, lisinopril, sublingual nitrate, and insulin. He appears pale. His temperature is 36.1°C (97°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 88/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 85%. The patient does not respond to commands and withdraws his extremities to pain. Examination shows cold, clammy skin and jugular venous distention. There is ecchymosis on the right temple and maxilla. There is a surgical incision over the right thigh that shows no erythema or discharge. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated. A central venous catheter is placed and hemodynamic monitoring shows:

Systemic vascular resistance (SVR)
1600 dynes.sec/cm^5 (N = 900–1400)

Right atrial pressure

13 mm Hg (N = 3–8)

Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP)

4 mm Hg (N = 5–16)

Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: Twelve hours after undergoing a femoral artery embolectomy, an 84-year-old man is found unconscious on the floor by his hospital bed. He had received a patient-controlled analgesia pump after surgery. He underwent 2 coronary bypass surgeries 2 and 6 years ago. He has coronary artery disease, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, gastroesophageal reflux disease, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. His current medications include metoprolol, atorvastatin, lisinopril, sublingual nitrate, and insulin. He appears pale. His temperature is 36.1°C (97°F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 88/60 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 85%. The patient does not respond to commands and withdraws his extremities to pain. Examination shows cold, clammy skin and jugular venous distention. There is ecchymosis on the right temple and maxilla. There is a surgical incision over the right thigh that shows no erythema or discharge. He is intubated and mechanically ventilated. A central venous catheter is placed and hemodynamic monitoring shows: Systemic vascular resistance (SVR) 1600 dynes.sec/cm5 (N = 900–1400) Right atrial pressure 13 mm Hg (N = 3–8) Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) 4 mm Hg (N = 5–16) Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: This patient presents with features of shock: tachycardia, hypotension, and clinical signs of end-organ hypoperfusion (altered consciousness, cold and clammy skin). This patient's hemodynamic parameters help to identify the most likely type of shock.
learning_objective: Recognize features of shock, and recall the diagnostic finding of obstructive shock due to pulmonary embolism.

answers.content: Decreased hematocrit on complete blood count
answers.explanation_why:
Decreased hematocrit on complete blood count can be seen in hemorrhagic shock. This patient recently underwent surgery and sustained a fall, both of which could have led to bleeding. Additionally, patients with hemorrhagic shock typically present with increased SVR and decreased PCWP. However, increased right atrial pressure and jugular venous distension are not expected in hemorrhagic shock.

Note that in acute hemorrhage, hematocrit and hemoglobin may initially be normal as loss of plasma and blood cells occur in proportion; hematocrit and hemoglobin decrease following fluid shifting.

answers.content: Filling defect of a pulmonary artery on CT pulmonary angiography
answers.explanation_why: A filling defect of a pulmonary artery on CT pulmonary angiography indicates pulmonary embolism (PE). Massive PE can cause major obstruction of the pulmonary vasculature, resulting in increased right heart pressures and features of right heart failure, like jugular venous distension. Obstruction of the pulmonary vessels leads to a decreased right heart output, resulting in normal or mildly decreased PCWP and decreased left ventricular end-diastolic volume, which leads to decreased cardiac output and, consequently, obstructive shock. SVR increases to compensate for the decrease in cardiac output.

answers.content: ST-segment elevations in leads V1 through V6
answers.explanation_why: Cardiogenic shock due to ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) is an important differential diagnosis in this patient with a history of coronary artery disease, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and diabetes mellitus. Cardiogenic shock typically manifests with increased SVR and increased right atrial pressure and jugular venous distension can be seen if there is right ventricular failure. However, given the ECG leads affected (V_1 through V_6), features of left ventricular failure (e.g., pulmonary edema, increased PCWP) would be expected.

answers.content: Elevated serum procalcitonin and interleukin-6 levels
answers.explanation_why: Elevated serum procalcitonin and interleukin-6 levels would indicate septic shock, which is an unlikely diagnosis in a patient without findings suggestive of an infectious process (e.g., fever). Additionally, patients with septic shock typically have decreased SVR. Finally, increased right atrial pressure and jugular venous distension are not expected.

answers.content: Improved mental status after naloxone administration
answers.explanation_why: Improved mental status after naloxone administration suggests opioid overdose, which should be considered since the patient was receiving an opiate through a patient-controlled analgesia device. Although opioid toxicity manifests with features that are also present here (e.g., altered mental status, hypotension), bradypnea or hypopnea would be far more likely than tachypnea. Furthermore, the hemodynamic findings seen here are not consistent with opioid overdose and suggest a different etiology.
