question_text: A 19-year-old woman comes to the physician because of severe headaches for the past 3 months. The headaches are pulsating in nature and she describes the pain as 8 out of 10 in intensity. She has visited the emergency department for headaches twice in the past month; during both visits, her blood pressure was elevated. She has polycystic ovarian disease. Her medications include metformin and an oral contraceptive pill.  She is 162 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 86 kg (190 lb); BMI is 33 kg/m^2. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 99/min, and blood pressure is 168/98 mm Hg. Examination shows hirsutism. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. An abdominal bruit is heard on the left side. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, urea nitrogen, and creatinine are within the reference range. Plasma free metanephrines are within the reference range. An abdominal ultrasound shows an increased peak systolic velocity in the distal portion of the left renal artery. A CT angiography of the abdomen shows alternating stenosis and dilation in an 8-mm distal segment of the left renal artery with approximately 75% reduction in the diameter of the vessel; the left kidney is significantly smaller than the right kidney. A CT scan of the brain shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 19-year-old woman comes to the physician because of severe headaches for the past 3 months. The headaches are pulsating in nature and she describes the pain as 8 out of 10 in intensity. She has visited the emergency department for headaches twice in the past month; during both visits, her blood pressure was elevated. She has polycystic ovarian disease. Her medications include metformin and an oral contraceptive pill. She is 162 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 86 kg (190 lb); BMI is 33 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 99/min, and blood pressure is 168/98 mm Hg. Examination shows hirsutism. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. An abdominal bruit is heard on the left side. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, urea nitrogen, and creatinine are within the reference range. Plasma free metanephrines are within the reference range. An abdominal ultrasound shows an increased peak systolic velocity in the distal portion of the left renal artery. A CT angiography of the abdomen shows alternating stenosis and dilation in an 8-mm distal segment of the left renal artery with approximately 75% reduction in the diameter of the vessel; the left kidney is significantly smaller than the right kidney. A CT scan of the brain shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Hypertension with a renal bruit suggests secondary hypertension due to renal artery stenosis. In a female patient aged < 50 years with distal stenotic lesions that have a string of beads appearance on imaging, the most likely cause of renal artery stenosis is fibromuscular dysplasia.
learning_objective: Recognize fibromuscular dysplasia as a cause of secondary hypertension, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.content: Combination therapy with captopril and valsartan
answers.explanation_why: ACE inhibitors, such as captopril, and angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs), such as valsartan, are used to control hypertension in patients with renal artery stenosis (e.g., due to fibromuscular dysplasia). However, the combination of ACE inhibitors and ARBs is generally not recommended.

answers.content: Percutaneous transluminal angioplasty without stent placement
answers.explanation_why: Percutaneous transluminal angioplasty without stent placement is the first-line revascularization procedure for patients with renal artery stenosis secondary to fibromuscular dysplasia (FMD). Although revascularization procedures improve blood pressure control, studies have shown that hypertension persists in the majority of patients with extensive FMD. Medical antihypertensive therapy would, therefore, also be required in addition to a revascularization procedure.

answers.content: Percutaneous transluminal angioplasty with stent placement
answers.explanation_why: In patients with renal artery stenosis due to renal fibromuscular dysplasia (FMD), stent placement can be indicated if complications such as arterial dissection or renal artery perforation occur during angioplasty. In such cases, a stent would help to reinforce the wall of the renal artery. However, stent placement is generally not indicated in patients with renal artery stenosis secondary to FMD. Moreover, medical antihypertensive therapy would also be required in addition to revascularization.

answers.content: Ramipril and percutaneous transluminal angioplasty without stent placement
answers.explanation_why:
All patients with symptomatic or asymptomatic renal artery stenosis (RAS), including those with underlying fibromuscular dysplasia, should be initiated on medical therapy with an ACE inhibitor (e.g., ramipril) or an angiotensin receptor blocker to control hypertension. In patients with hemodynamically significant RAS complicated by heart failure, hypertensive emergencies, resistance to medical treatment, or an unexplained unilateral small kidney (as seen here), revascularization is indicated in addition to medical therapy. The short duration of hypertension in this patient is a further indication that interventional revascularization is likely to normalize blood pressures. In patients with fibromuscular dysplasia who have severe unilateral disease, as in this case, PTA without stent placement is the first-line revascularization procedure. In the absence of complications (e.g., arterial dissection, renal artery perforation), stent placement is usually avoided.

In patients with bilateral stenosis or stenosis of a single functioning kidney, revascularization is indicated if there is progressive renal insufficiency or hemodynamically significant RAS. Serum creatinine and potassium levels should be closely monitored after initiating ACE inhibitors or ARBs in patients with RAS, especially those with bilateral stenosis, because of the risk of acute kidney injury resulting from inhibition of angiotensin II-mediated vasoconstriction of the efferent arteriole.

images.title: String of beads sign in fibromuscular dysplasia
images.description: Angiography abdomen (right renal artery)The caliber of the renal artery alternates between stenoses and aneurysms, creating a string of beads appearance that is characteristic of medial fibromuscular dysplasia.

answers.content: Enalapril and aortorenal bypass with a vein graft
answers.explanation_why: An ACE inhibitor such as enalapril is indicated to control hypertension in patients with renal artery stenosis due to fibromuscular dysplasia. However, aortorenal bypass surgery is usually reserved for severe cases or those in which first-line therapy is unsuccessful. There are less invasive methods with a comparable outcome that should be attempted first.

answers.content: Aortorenal bypass with a vein graft
answers.explanation_why: Aortorenal bypass grafting is usually reserved for severe cases of renal artery stenosis or those in which first-line therapy is unsuccessful. There are less invasive methods with a comparable outcome that should be attempted first. In addition, bypass grafting alone would not be sufficient because medical antihypertensive therapy would still be indicated.

question_text: A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician because of severe headaches and lightheadedness for 2 months. She has also been hearing a 'swoosh' sound in her left ear for the past month. She has allergic rhinitis and acne. Her sister is being treated for thyroid cancer. Current medications include levocetirizine, topical clindamycin, and azelastine-fluticasone nasal spray. She appears anxious. She is 155 cm (5 ft 1 in) tall and weighs 77 kg (170 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m^2. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 168/96 mm Hg. Examination shows cystic acne over the face and back. The pupils are equal and reactive. There is a bruit on the left side of the neck. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is an abdominal bruit on the left side. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?

She has also been hearing a 'swoosh' sound in her left ear for the past month. She has allergic rhinitis and acne. Her sister is being treated for thyroid cancer. Current medications include levocetirizine, topical clindamycin, and azelastine-fluticasone nasal spray. She appears anxious. She is 155 cm (5 ft 1 in) tall and weighs 77 kg (170 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 96/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 168/96 mm Hg. Examination shows cystic acne over the face and back. The pupils are equal and reactive. There is a bruit on the left side of the neck. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is an abdominal bruit on the left side. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: The presence of headaches, lightheadedness, and tinnitus in a young woman with elevated blood pressure and concurrent cervical and abdominal bruits is suggestive of fibromuscular dysplasia.
learning_objective: Recognize fibromuscular dysplasia, and recall the expected laboratory finding.

answers.explanation_why: Increased 24-hour urine cortisol is found in Cushing syndrome which can manifest with secondary hypertension, acne, and obesity. However, the presence of abdominal and cervical bruits suggests another diagnosis.

Elevated plasma metanephrine levels are seen in pheochromocytoma. Patients with a pheochromocytoma may present with headaches and hypertension. However, patients with pheochromocytoma usually present with episodic blood pressure crises with diaphoresis, palpitations, or pallor. Additionally, the presence of abdominal and cervical bruits is suggestive of another diagnosis.

An abnormal breathing pattern at night is present in obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). Although the patient has an elevated BMI and OSA may cause secondary hypertension, there is no evidence to suggest symptoms of OSA, which might include snoring or excessive daytime tiredness. Additionally, the presence of pulsatile tinnitus and abdominal and cervical bruits suggests another diagnosis.
Adrenal adenomas can be seen in primary hyperaldosteronism, which can result in hypertension. However, the presence of abdominal and cervical bruits suggests another diagnosis.

A parathyroid adenoma can cause primary hyperparathyroidism, which may manifest with hypertension (due to hypercalcemia). However, the absence of other features of hypercalcemia (e.g., muscle weakness, lethargy) and the presence of abdominal and cervical bruits suggest a different cause of hypertension in this patient.

An elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate may be seen in vasculitic conditions such as Takayasu arteritis, which may manifest in young females with hypertension, headache, and abdominal and carotid bruits. However, the absence of fever, arthralgias, weight loss, and weak peripheral pulses suggests a different diagnosis.

The proliferation of connective tissue and muscle fibers associated with fibromuscular dysplasia can cause renal artery stenosis, leading to decreased renal perfusion. A decrease in renal perfusion results in a compensatory activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, increasing the secretion of renin with subsequent reabsorption of sodium and water, leading to secondary hypertension. This patient likely also has hypokalemia. The abdominal and cervical bruits are caused by turbulent blood flow in the stenosed arteries.

images.title: Mechanism of action: renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS) inhibitors
images.description: Renin is produced in response to changes in the glomerular filtration rate and solute content of the blood within the renal corpuscle. Renin catalyzes the conversion of angiotensinogen (produced by the liver) to angiotensin I, which is then converted to angiotensin II by angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE; produced by the lungs). Angiotensin II acts to increase blood pressure by causing vasoconstriction, sodium retention, and ADH production.The specific targets of the different RAAS inhibitors are highlighted in red.

question_text: A 76-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of an episode of seeing jagged edges followed by loss of central vision in his right eye. The episode occurred 6 hours ago and lasted approximately 5 minutes. The patient has no pain. He has a 3-month history of intermittent blurriness out of his right eye and reports a 10-minute episode of slurred speech and left-sided facial droop that occurred 2 months ago. He has hypercholesterolemia, stable angina pectoris, hypertension, and a 5-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. Medications include glyburide, atorvastatin, labetalol, isosorbide, lisinopril, and aspirin. He feels well. He is oriented to person, place, and time. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 154/78 mm Hg. The extremities are well perfused with strong peripheral pulses. Ophthalmologic examination shows visual acuity of 20/30 in the left eye and 20/40 in the right eye. Visual fields are normal. Fundoscopic examination shows two grayish-white spots along the supratemporal and inferotemporal arcade. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Cardiopulmonary examination shows systolic rumbling at the right carotid artery. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An ECG shows normal sinus rhythm with no evidence of ischemia. In addition to obtaining a CT scan of the head, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 76-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of an episode of seeing jagged edges followed by loss of central vision in his right eye. The episode occurred 6 hours ago and lasted approximately 5 minutes. The patient has no pain. He has a 3-month history of intermittent blurriness out of his right eye and reports a 10-minute episode of slurred speech and left-sided facial droop that occurred 2 months ago. He has hypercholesterolemia, stable angina pectoris, hypertension, and a 5-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. Medications include glyburide, atorvastatin, labetalol, isosorbide, lisinopril, and aspirin. He feels well. He is oriented to person, place, and time. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 76/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 154/78 mm Hg. The extremities are well perfused with strong peripheral pulses. Ophthalmologic examination shows visual acuity of 20/30 in the left eye and 20/40 in the right eye. Visual fields are normal. Fundoscopic examination shows two grayish-white spots along the supratemporal and inferotemporal arcade. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Cardiopulmonary examination shows systolic rumbling at the right carotid artery. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An ECG shows normal sinus rhythm with no evidence of ischemia. In addition to obtaining a CT scan of the head, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Sudden, painless, transient monocular loss of vision with cloudy discoloration along the retinal arterial supply on fundoscopy is highly suggestive of retinal artery occlusion. The most common cause in older adults is atherosclerotic emboli, which is consistent with this patient's age, extensive atherosclerotic risk factors (hypercholesterolemia, stable angina pectoris, hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus), history of possible transient ischemic attack, and finding of an ipsilateral carotid bruit on examination.
learning_objective: Recognize retinal artery occlusion secondary to atherosclerotic emboli, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic test.

answers.explanation_why: Echocardiography is used to evaluate for cardiac causes of retinal vessel occlusion and TIA, such as emboli due to atrial fibrillation. Cardiogenic emboli are the most common cause of retinal artery occlusion in younger patients (< 40 years of age) and should be suspected based on a patient history that includes, e.g., atrial fibrillation (AF), endocarditis, or valvular disease. However, while this patient does have a history and exam findings that both suggest retinal vessel occlusion and a TIA, he has no AF and there are signs of carotid artery stenosis. Echocardiography would be an appropriate step in management only after atherosclerotic causes of this patient's symptoms have been ruled out.

Fluorescein angiography allows for visualization of flow through the retinal vessels and may be used to diagnose a variety of retinal disorders, such as macular degeneration, diabetic retinopathy, and retinal vascular occlusions. While fluorescein angiography might show slow or absent filling of retinal arteries in retinal artery occlusion, it is usually indicated when the diagnosis is not otherwise clear, e.g., when ischemic retinal whitening is not clearly present on fundoscopy. In this case, such findings are apparent, as is the diagnosis of retinal artery occlusion. Fluorescein angiography would not contribute significantly to this patient's care.

Reassurance and follow-up might be appropriate in a patient with transient vision loss secondary to a benign etiology. For example, migraine is the most common cause of transient binocular vision loss in young adults. This patient's vision loss was transient and he has a history of intermittent blurriness that could be consistent with migrainous aura, but the lack of other migraine symptoms, along with the monocular presentation, make the diagnosis of migrainous aura unlikely.

Temporal artery biopsy could conclusively evaluate for the presence of giant cell arteritis (GCA), which can result in permanent vision loss if untreated. Suspicion of GCA should be especially high in patients above the age of 50 with fundoscopy findings of pallid optic disc swelling without apparent emboli. While our patient's monocular vision loss and history of intermittent monocular blurriness could be consistent with GCA, he lacks additional symptoms such as temporal headache or jaw claudication, and his fundus examination reveals clearly demarcated areas of vascular involvement, which is not consistent with GCA. A temporal artery biopsy is therefore not indicated.

images.title: Polymyalgia rheumatica and giant cell arteritis fact sheet

answers.explanation_why:
Carotid duplex ultrasonography is the best next step in the management of a patient with transient retinal artery occlusion secondary to atherosclerotic emboli. This procedure allows for the assessment of the carotid arteries for atherosclerotic plaques and vessel stenosis, and thus the patient's candidacy for treatment options (e.g., antiplatelet therapy, carotid endarterectomy).

Retinal vessel occlusion is primarily a clinical diagnosis, so confirmatory testing is generally not indicated, except in unusual cases. This patient presented with classic history and exam findings, making testing unnecessary in his case. Instead, the diagnostic focus is on the cause of occlusion, which might be cardiovascular or inflammatory disease.

question_text:
A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of severe back pain for the last 2 hours. He describes a stabbing pain between the scapulae that is 9 out of 10 in intensity. He has vomited once during this period. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus complicated by diabetic nephropathy. Current medications include lisinopril and metformin. He is diaphoretic. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 210/130 mm Hg. He is not oriented to person, place, or time. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The radial pulse is decreased on the left side. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
13.5 g/dL

Leukocyte count
10,000/mm^3

Platelet count
230,000/mm^3

Serum

 Na^+

139 mEq/L

 K^+

4.1 mEq/L

 Cl^-

103 mEq/L

 Creatinine

2.6 mg/dL

 Glucose
230 mg/dL

 Alkaline phosphatase
55 U/L

Urine toxicology screening is positive for opiates and cocaine. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia with no evidence of ischemia. An x-ray of the chest shows a widened mediastinum. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of severe back pain for the last 2 hours. He describes a stabbing pain between the scapulae that is 9 out of 10 in intensity. He has vomited once during this period. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus complicated by diabetic nephropathy. Current medications include lisinopril and metformin. He is diaphoretic. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 210/130 mm Hg. He is not oriented to person, place, or time. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The radial pulse is decreased on the left side. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 13.5 g/dL Leukocyte count 10,000/mm3 Platelet count 230,000/mm3 Serum Na+ 139 mEq/L K+ 4.1 mEq/L Cl- 103 mEq/L Creatinine 2.6 mg/dL Glucose 230 mg/dL Alkaline phosphatase 55 U/L Urine toxicology screening is positive for opiates and cocaine. An ECG shows sinus tachycardia with no evidence of ischemia. An x-ray of the chest shows a widened mediastinum. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Severe stabbing interscapular pain combined with asymmetrical pulse readings between the upper extremities and a widened mediastinum on chest x-ray suggests aortic dissection.
learning_objective: Recognize aortic dissection, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why: Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) is a fast, noninvasive diagnostic method that may be used to evaluate the proximal ascending aorta for dissection. TTE does not, however, allow for visualization of the remainder of the aorta, i.e., mid and distal ascending aorta, transverse arch, and descending aorta. Therefore, TTE may not detect dissection in this patient who presents with interscapular pain, which suggests involvement of the proximal descending aorta. Moreover, the sensitivity and specificity of TTE are lower than that of the recommended imaging modality for aortic dissection.

Magnetic resonance angiography can be performed in stable patients with suspected aortic dissection if CT angiography is unavailable or contraindicated. Gadolinium-enhanced MR angiography has high sensitivity and specificity for aortic dissection. However, gadolinium-enhanced studies should be avoided in patients with renal insufficiency because of the risk of nephrogenic systemic fibrosis. Additionally, patients must be taken out of the acute care setting for this time-consuming imaging technique, which is not readily available in the emergency setting.

Contrast-enhanced CT angiography (CTA) is the best initial test for diagnosing aortic dissection in hemodynamically stable patients. It has high sensitivity and specificity for aortic dissection, is widely available, and provides important anatomical information for surgical management. This patient has renal insufficiency and is therefore at increased risk of contrast-induced nephropathy. Although renal insufficiency is not an absolute contraindication for CTA, it should be taken into consideration when choosing the diagnostic method; in this patient, a different diagnostic examination is preferred if available.

images.title: Aortic dissection (Stanford A)
images.description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT angiography (chest; ECG-gated; venous and arterial phases; axial plane) of a patient with a history of recent weakness, vertigo, and facial swellingThe ascending aorta is dilated and a Stanford type A (DeBakey type II) aortic dissection is seen. The aortic arch and descending aorta are not affected. The right and left coronary, the innominate, the left common carotid, and the subclavian arteries originate from the true lumen (green overlay; false lumen is red overlay). Facial swelling is the result of venous congestion from compression of the superior vena cava (blue overlay) by the dilated ascending aorta. Bilateral small pleural effusions are seen.Additional findings include sternotomy wires, a prosthetic aortic valve, atherosclerotic calcifications, pancreatic calcifications, and a small hiatal hernia.LCA: left coronary artery; RCA: right coronary artery; yellow overlay: azygos vein

answers.explanation_why: Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is a fast, portable test with high sensitivity and specificity for aortic dissection. TEE is the preferred initial study in hemodynamically unstable patients (it can be rapidly performed at the bedside or in the operating room) and patients with renal insufficiency (because of the increased risk of developing contrast-induced nephropathy with CT angiography) or contrast allergy. This imaging modality helps visualize intimal dissection flaps, true and false lumens, thromboses in false lumen, aortic regurgitation, and pericardial effusion, and it aids in determining whether surgical intervention is warranted. TEE cannot be used to assess dissections below the diaphragm; in such cases, CT angiography is preferred.

images.title: Transesophageal echocardiography of aortic dissection
images.description: Echocardiography (transesophageal; transverse view)The descending thoracic aorta shows a crescentic false lumen and rounded true lumen.

answers.explanation_why: Aortography was previously used to evaluate for aortic dissection. This procedure involves considerable radiation exposure and has therefore been replaced by less invasive, more sensitive and specific, and more widely available diagnostic modalities.

question_text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of increasing shortness of breath for 1 month. Initially, he was able to climb the 3 flights of stairs to his apartment, but he now needs several breaks to catch his breath. He has no chest pain. He has rheumatic heart disease and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He emigrated from India about 25 years ago. His current medications include carvedilol, torsemide, and insulin. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 72/min and regular, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Examination shows bilateral crackles at the lung bases. There is an opening snap followed by a low-pitched diastolic murmur at the fifth left intercostal space at the midclavicular line. Echocardiography shows no valvular calcifications, atrial clots, or atrioventricular regurgitation. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
content_preview: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of increasing shortness of breath for 1 month. Initially, he was able to climb the 3 flights of stairs to his apartment, but he now needs several breaks to catch his breath. He has no chest pain. He has rheumatic heart disease and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He emigrated from India about 25 years ago. His current medications include carvedilol, torsemide, and insulin. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 72/min and regular, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Examination shows bilateral crackles at the lung bases. There is an opening snap followed by a low-pitched diastolic murmur at the fifth left intercostal space at the midclavicular line. Echocardiography shows no valvular calcifications, atrial clots, or atrioventricular regurgitation. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
hint: A low-pitched diastolic murmur with an opening snap in a patient with a history of rheumatic heart disease is characteristic of mitral valve stenosis. These findings in combination with exertional dyspnea and bibasilar crackles without chest pain indicate cardiogenic pulmonary edema and heart failure due to valvular disease.
learning_objective: Recognize mitral valve stenosis, and choose the most appropriate treatment.

answers.explanation_why: Aortic valve repair is indicated for symptomatic or severe aortic valve disease. The aortic valve is the second most common valve affected by rheumatic heart disease. Both aortic regurgitation (AR) and aortic stenosis (AS) can cause left heart failure, resulting in symptoms like those seen here. However, unlike this patient's murmur, AR causes a blowing early diastolic murmur heard best at the left midsternal border and AS causes a harsh systolic ejection murmur heard best in the second right intercostal space.

images.title: Cardiomegaly and prominent thoracic aorta in aortic regurgitation
images.description: Chest x-ray (PA view) of a patient with a history of aortic regurgitationThe cardiac silhouette is enlarged. The left ventricle, ascending aorta, and aortic arch are prominent as a result of dilatation.

answers.explanation_why: Mitral valve replacement is indicated for patients with mitral valve stenosis who are not candidates for the first-line treatment. Although mitral replacement is a potential treatment for this patient's mitral valve stenosis, replacement would require open surgery that is associated with considerable morbidity and mortality. Other less invasive treatment options would be preferred, as they offer similar symptomatic improvement with lower risk.

Percutaneous mitral balloon commissurotomy (PMBC) is the treatment of choice for many cases of symptomatic mitral stenosis because it improves valve function and symptoms, is less invasive, and the morbidity and mortality rates are lower than with other surgical treatment options. This patient has a favorable valve morphology (no calcifications) and no evidence of a left atrial thrombus or mitral regurgitation, which makes him a good candidate for PMBC. If the patient's echocardiography were less benign, open valvular replacement would be indicated.

images.title: Heart murmur in mitral stenosis
images.description: Delayed decrescendo diastolic murmur. A presystolic crescendo murmur and/or mitral valve opening snap (OS) may also be present.

answers.explanation_why: Transcatheter aortic valve replacement (TAVR) is the treatment of choice for most cases of symptomatic or severe aortic stenosis (AS) in patients who are not suited to surgery. The aortic valve is the second most common valve affected by rheumatic heart disease, with AS being less common than aortic regurgitation. AS can cause left heart failure, resulting in symptoms like those seen here. However, AS causes a harsh systolic ejection murmur heard best in the second right intercostal space, which is inconsistent with this patient's presentation.

images.title: Heart murmur in hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy, aortic stenosis, and pulmonary stenosis
images.description: A crescendo-decrescendo late systolic murmur is depicted. In the case of aortic stenosis, the murmur may radiate to the carotid arteries.

answers.explanation_why: Warfarin therapy would be indicated if this patient had evidence of atrial fibrillation (e.g., irregular heart rhythm), evidence of left atrial thrombus (e.g., echocardiographic finding or embolic stroke), or a mechanical heart valve. Although this patient is at risk for all of these conditions given his mitral valve stenosis and may require warfarin in the future, there is no clear indication for warfarin at this time.

ACE inhibitors (e.g., enalapril) are indicated for patients with heart failure because they have been shown to reduce mortality (likely via aldosterone reduction, which decreases myocardial remodeling, among other mechanisms). Although this patient has symptoms of heart failure, ACE inhibitors (and other afterload reduction agents) are contraindicated in mitral valve stenosis, which decreases the preload available for the left ventricle to pump into the systemic circulation, meaning that the ability to maintain perfusion of vital organs is already compromised. If the ability of peripheral arteries to constrict is downregulated (e.g., by an ACE inhibitor), then perfusion may be insufficient and end-organ damage may occur.

question_text: A 62-year-old man comes to the emergency department for severe, acute right leg pain. The patient's symptoms began suddenly 4 hours ago while he was reading the newspaper. He has poorly controlled hypertension and osteoarthritis. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 31 years. Current medications include lisinopril, metoprolol, and ibuprofen. He appears to be in severe pain and is clutching his right leg. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 102/min and irregularly irregular, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 152/94 mm Hg. The right leg is cool to the touch, with decreased femoral, popliteal, posterior tibial, and dorsalis pedis pulses. There is moderate weakness and decreased sensation in the right leg. An ECG shows absent P waves and a variable RR interval. Right leg Doppler study shows inaudible arterial signal and audible venous signal. Angiography shows 90% occlusion of the right common femoral artery. In addition to initiating intravenous heparin therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 62-year-old man comes to the emergency department for severe, acute right leg pain. The patient's symptoms began suddenly 4 hours ago while he was reading the newspaper. He has poorly controlled hypertension and osteoarthritis. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 31 years. Current medications include lisinopril, metoprolol, and ibuprofen. He appears to be in severe pain and is clutching his right leg. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 102/min and irregularly irregular, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 152/94 mm Hg. The right leg is cool to the touch, with decreased femoral, popliteal, posterior tibial, and dorsalis pedis pulses. There is moderate weakness and decreased sensation in the right leg. An ECG shows absent P waves and a variable RR interval. Right leg Doppler study shows inaudible arterial signal and audible venous signal. Angiography shows 90% occlusion of the right common femoral artery. In addition to initiating intravenous heparin therapy, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The patient likely has atrial fibrillation (irregularly irregular pulse, absent P waves, variable RR interval) that has been complicated by intraatrial clot formation and embolization affecting the right common femoral artery. His symptoms indicate limb-threatening ischemia (Rutherford stage IIb), which requires urgent intervention.
learning_objective: Recognize acute limb ischemia, and choose the most appropriate next step in management.

answers.explanation_why: This patient presents with limb-threatening ischemia (Rutherford stage IIb), indicated by his severe pain, decreased motor function and sensation, and inaudible arterial Doppler signal. In addition to intravenous heparin therapy (to prevent further clot formation and embolization), the patient requires revascularization within 6 hours to restore blood flow and increase the probability of limb salvage. Balloon thrombectomy and bypass surgery are appropriate revascularization procedures for patients with embolic acute limb ischemia and a threatened extremity.

Amputation is indicated in patients who present with acute extremity ischemia and a nonviable limb. Although this patient has advanced ischemia, his limb would be classified as “threatened” rather than “nonviable” given the presence of a venous Doppler signal and some motor and sensory function. In a nonviable limb, arterial Doppler signals, venous Doppler signals, and motor and sensory function are entirely absent.

Cilostazol therapy should be considered in patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD) and persistent life-limiting claudication despite exercise therapy. Although this patient has risk factors for PAD, he presents with limb-threatening ischemia that requires urgent revascularization. Vasodilator therapy with cilostazol is not appropriate.

In patients with acute limb ischemia, angioplasty may be used for the treatment of the underlying atherosclerotic lesions after the occluding thrombus has been lysed or removed. However, given the patient's likely atrial fibrillation and sudden onset of arterial occlusion, the symptoms are more likely to be embolic than thrombotic in origin.

question_text: A 49-year-old man comes to the physician because of increasing difficulty achieving an erection for 6 months. During this period, he has had to reduce his hours as a construction worker because of pain in his lower back and thighs and a progressive lower limb weakness when walking for longer distances. His pain resolves after resting for a few minutes, but it recurs when he returns to work. He also reports that his pain is improved by standing still. His last visit to a physician was 25 years ago. He is sexually active with 4 female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. His father has coronary artery disease and his mother died of a ruptured intracranial aneurysm at the age of 53 years. He has recently taken sildenafil, given to him by a friend, with no improvement in his symptoms. His only other medication is ibuprofen as needed for back pain. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years.  He is 172.5 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 102 kg (225 lb); BMI is 34 kg/m^2. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 169/98 mm Hg. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, urea nitrogen, and creatinine are within the reference ranges. His hemoglobin A1_c is 6.2%. Which of the following is the most likely finding on physical examination?
content_preview: A 49-year-old man comes to the physician because of increasing difficulty achieving an erection for 6 months. During this period, he has had to reduce his hours as a construction worker because of pain in his lower back and thighs and a progressive lower limb weakness when walking for longer distances. His pain resolves after resting for a few minutes, but it recurs when he returns to work. He also reports that his pain is improved by standing still. His last visit to a physician was 25 years ago. He is sexually active with 4 female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. His father has coronary artery disease and his mother died of a ruptured intracranial aneurysm at the age of 53 years. He has recently taken sildenafil, given to him by a friend, with no improvement in his symptoms. His only other medication is ibuprofen as needed for back pain. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. He is 172.5 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and weighs 102 kg (225 lb); BMI is 34 kg/m2. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 76/min, and blood pressure is 169/98 mm Hg. A complete blood count and serum concentrations of electrolytes, urea nitrogen, and creatinine are within the reference ranges. His hemoglobin A1c is 6.2%. Which of the following is the most likely finding on physical examination?
hint: This patient has multiple risk factors for cardiovascular disease (e.g., obesity, smoking, and positive family history). He has erectile dysfunction and symptoms of intermittent claudication (thigh pain and weakness on exertion, temporarily relieved by rest) that suggest a chronic condition characterized by progressive arterial occlusion.
learning_objective: Recognize Leriche syndrome, and recall its associated physical findings.

answers.explanation_why:
Decreased pulses are a common finding in peripheral arterial disease, for which this patient is at high risk. Decreased bilateral femoral pulses indicate occlusion of either the bilateral iliac arteries or the aortic bifurcation. Lesions at either of these locations cause aortoiliac occlusive disease (Leriche syndrome), which manifests with the classic triad of buttock, hip, or thigh claudication; erectile dysfunction; and absent or diminished femoral pulses. Given this patient's high risk for cardiovascular disease and complaints in accordance with two-thirds of the classic triad, Leriche syndrome is the most likely diagnosis.

Atrophy of the affected limbs is also common in Leriche syndrome.

Internuclear ophthalmoplegia is usually caused by multiple sclerosis or stroke. Although this patient has multiple risk factors for cerebrovascular disease (smoking, obesity, possibly hypertension), stroke generally manifests with acute unilateral sensory and/or motor symptoms, while this patient has chronic, bilateral symptoms. Multiple sclerosis generally has symptoms disseminated in space (different locations in the central nervous system) and time (relapsing/remitting). Additionally, pseudoclaudication and erectile dysfunction are atypical symptoms of multiple sclerosis. Given this patient's risk factors and symptoms, another diagnosis is far more likely.

answers.content: Papular rash over the palms and soles
answers.explanation_why: A papular rash of the palms and soles can be seen in secondary syphilis. Although this patient is at risk for syphilis (unprotected sex, multiple partners), which can have a broad range of presenting symptoms, syphilis is unlikely to present solely with erectile dysfunction and exertional thigh cramping.

images.title: Maculopapular rash in secondary syphilis
images.description: Partially confluent and partially scaling red papules and macules of ∼2–5 mm diameter are visible on the palms and wrists.This appearance is typical of secondary syphilis.

answers.explanation_why: Jugular venous distention is a sign of some cardiac conditions (e.g., heart failure). Although this patient has risk factors for cardiac disease (smoking, obesity), his erectile dysfunction and intermittent claudication suggest a different diagnosis.

Decreased anal tone can be a sign of spinal cord compression (due to lumbosacral neurological lesions or spinal stenosis) or autonomic neuropathy, which can additionally manifest with erectile dysfunction and leg pain, both of which are seen in this patient. However, in patients with lumbar spinal stenosis who have neurogenic pain or pseudoclaudication, pain is generally exacerbated with standing, unlike what is seen here, and relieved with sitting. Type 2 diabetes mellitus can cause vascular claudication due to accelerated atherosclerosis as well as erectile dysfunction and decreased anal sphincter tone due to autonomic neuropathy. Although this patient has risk factors for diabetes mellitus (e.g., obesity), his HbA1_c is < 6.5%.

A painless foot ulcer is usually a complication of diabetes mellitus. Although diabetes can cause erectile dysfunction (autonomic neuropathy), it is unlikely to cause exertional leg pain. Additionally, this patient's hemoglobin A1c was 6.2% (≥ 6.5% is diagnostic of diabetes mellitus). A painful foot ulcer is more consistent with this patient's condition.

question_text:
Two hours after undergoing a left femoral artery embolectomy, a 63-year-old woman has severe pain, numbness, and tingling in the left leg. The surgery was without complication and following the procedure, peripheral pulses were weakly palpable. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus, peripheral artery disease, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia. Prior to admission, her medications included insulin, enalapril, carvedilol, aspirin, and rosuvastatin. She appears uncomfortable. Her temperature is 37.1°C (99.3°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 132/90 mm Hg. Examination shows a left groin surgical incision and swelling, stiffness, and exquisite tenderness to palpation of the left lower extremity. Femoral pulses are palpated bilaterally. Pedal pulses are weaker on the left side. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
12.1 g/dL

Leukocyte count
11,300/mm^3

Platelet count
189,000/mm^3

Serum

 Glucose
222 mg/dL

 Creatinine
1.1 mg/dL

Results of urinalysis are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
content_preview: Two hours after undergoing a left femoral artery embolectomy, a 63-year-old woman has severe pain, numbness, and tingling in the left leg. The surgery was without complication and following the procedure, peripheral pulses were weakly palpable. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus, peripheral artery disease, hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia. Prior to admission, her medications included insulin, enalapril, carvedilol, aspirin, and rosuvastatin. She appears uncomfortable. Her temperature is 37.1°C (99.3°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 132/90 mm Hg. Examination shows a left groin surgical incision and swelling, stiffness, and exquisite tenderness to palpation of the left lower extremity. Femoral pulses are palpated bilaterally. Pedal pulses are weaker on the left side. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 12.1 g/dL Leukocyte count 11,300/mm3 Platelet count 189,000/mm3 Serum Glucose 222 mg/dL Creatinine 1.1 mg/dL Results of urinalysis are within the reference ranges. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
hint: This patient's swollen, painful leg with reduced pedal pulses and paresthesia are suggestive of compartment syndrome.
learning_objective: Recognize reperfusion injury as a cause of compartment syndrome.

answers.explanation_why: Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) of the lower extremity may manifest with asymmetric swelling and pain. However, an asymmetrical reduced pedal pulse and stiff extremity should raise concern for compartment syndrome. DVT may also be complicated by compartment syndrome but the rapid onset of this patient's symptoms and known ischemic injury (femoral arterial thrombus and thromboembolectomy) make another cause more likely. Ultrasound is a helpful diagnostic tool to distinguish DVT from compartment syndrome if physical examination findings are equivocal.

Cases of extremity reperfusion injury in which ischemic endothelium leads to increased capillary permeability and tissue swelling may be severe enough to induce compartment syndrome. This patient's ischemic injury likely resulted from the femoral artery clot in addition to cross-clamping during surgery. Reperfusion then caused oxidative stress and inflammation, worsening tissue damage and swelling (i.e., ischemia-reperfusion edema). Increased compartment pressure obstructs venous outflow and can collapse arterioles, further worsening tissue perfusion and ischemia.

Rhabdomyolysis may result from ischemic injury to the extremity (potentially leading to compartment syndrome in severe cases). It first manifests with muscle tenderness, as seen here. But rhabdomyolysis is also commonly associated with myoglobinuria and acute kidney injury, which are not seen in this patient.

Cholesterol embolism may complicate arterial interventions such as embolectomy. From a distal source such as the femoral artery, a cholesterol embolism may manifest with sudden-onset severe pain at the foot and leg and diminished pedal pulse. This patient has risk factors for cholesterol deposits (hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, diabetes mellitus), but whole-extremity involvement, as well as swelling and stiffness of the leg, make embolism less likely. Moreover, a cholesterol embolism typically causes skin changes (livedo reticularis, purpura, necrosis) over the affected area.

Cellulitis may also manifest with unilateral leg pain and swelling, but more commonly also warmth, erythema, and localized tenderness. This patient has a diffusely tender leg and does not have any signs suggesting infection such as fever or tachycardia.

question_text: A 46-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle collision where he was the unrestrained driver. On arrival, he is unconscious. His pulse is 141/min and irregularly irregular, respirations are 24/min, and palpable systolic blood pressure is 60 mm Hg. Examination shows multiple ecchymoses over the chest. There is a 3-cm (1.2-in) laceration over the abdomen and a 4-cm (1.6-in) laceration over the scalp. Jugular venous pressure is increased. Bilateral crackles are heard at the lung bases. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The abdomen is soft. Two large-bore intravenous catheters are inserted and 0.9% saline infusion is begun. Focused assessment with sonography in trauma (FAST) results are negative. An ECG shows absent P waves. After 5 minutes, his pulse is 160/min and palpable systolic blood pressure is 50 mm Hg. Vasopressors are administered. One hour later, the patient dies. Which of the following was the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 46-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after being involved in a motor vehicle collision where he was the unrestrained driver. On arrival, he is unconscious. His pulse is 141/min and irregularly irregular, respirations are 24/min, and palpable systolic blood pressure is 60 mm Hg. Examination shows multiple ecchymoses over the chest. There is a 3-cm (1.2-in) laceration over the abdomen and a 4-cm (1.6-in) laceration over the scalp. Jugular venous pressure is increased. Bilateral crackles are heard at the lung bases. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. The abdomen is soft. Two large-bore intravenous catheters are inserted and 0.9% saline infusion is begun. Focused assessment with sonography in trauma (FAST) results are negative. An ECG shows absent P waves. After 5 minutes, his pulse is 160/min and palpable systolic blood pressure is 50 mm Hg. Vasopressors are administered. One hour later, the patient dies. Which of the following was the most likely diagnosis?
hint: While hypotension following acute trauma should raise concern for blood loss, this patient's negative FAST exam makes intraabdominal or intrathoracic bleeding less likely. Instead, his profound hypotension despite an apparently normal volume status, the bibasilar lung crackles, and elevated jugular venous pressure potentially indicate cardiogenic shock.
learning_objective: Recognize cardiac contusion.

answers.explanation_why: Tracheobronchial injuries can occur as a result of severe blunt chest trauma and also present with hypotension, dyspnea, or tachypnea. However, they are usually associated with bloody oral secretions, subcutaneous emphysema, and/or pneumothorax with a positive Hamman's sign.

In the context of a serious motor vehicle collision, this patient's hypotension and tachycardia refractive to fluid resuscitation, including vasopressors, combined with atrial fibrillation on ECG and a negative FAST, are highly suspicious for cardiac contusion. Cardiac contusions may manifest with clinical features ranging from asymptomatic arrhythmias to rapidly fatal cardiac rupture. Blunt chest trauma and/or sudden deceleration can lead to decreased contractility and arrhythmias due to injury to cardiac myocytes and pacemaker cells. Decreased contractility directly contributes to cardiogenic shock with decreased cardiac output and hypotension, as in this patient.

Splenic rupture most often occurs in the setting of blunt abdominal trauma and can result in hemodynamic instability secondary to massive intraabdominal blood loss. However, an intraabdominal hemorrhage large enough to lead to deterioration would be seen on the FAST exam.

A hemothorax might manifest with dyspnea, chest pain, diminished/absent breath sounds, decreased tactile fremitus, dullness on percussion, and flat neck veins. It may also be associated with a raised jugular venous pressure. In severe cases of hemothorax, blood loss into the thoracic cavity can lead to hemorrhagic shock, with subsequent tachycardia and hypotension. However, a hemothorax is distinctly identifiable on chest x-ray or on ultrasound as part of the FAST exam. No signs of internal bleeding are apparent on this patient's FAST exam and the physical exam findings (bibasilar crackles, soft abdomen) make a significant hemothorax even more unlikely.

An aortic dissection may occur as the result of rapid deceleration (e.g., in a motor vehicle accident) and typically manifests with severe tearing chest pain that may radiate to different parts of the body. Aortic dissection is associated with hypotension either if the dissection involves the ascending aorta resulting in cardiac tamponade and/or aortic regurgitation, or if it results in aortic rupture and hemorrhage into the mediastinum. On the FAST exam, however, aortic rupture would be apparent as free fluid above the diaphragm, with secondary cardiac tamponade as fluid accumulates in the pericardium. Moreover, secondary aortic regurgitation severe enough to affect the patient's vitals would be heard on auscultation.

Pulmonary contusions can occur in the setting of chest trauma and result in chest pain, dyspnea, tachypnea, and hypoxia as “bruising” of the lung impairs gas exchange. Symptoms may then worsen following fluid administration as fluid accumulates in the damaged lung. While this patient does have chest pain and tachypnea and deteriorated after receiving fluids, pulmonary contusion would be less likely to cause the arrhythmia or fluid- and vasopressor-resistant hypotension that proved fatal in this patient.

Cardiac tamponade due to hemopericardium can occur after chest trauma due to cardiac wall rupture or aortic dissection of the ascending aorta, with accumulation of blood around the heart. Cardiac tamponade can manifest with rapidly developing hypotension and tachycardia following chest trauma, and show elevated jugular venous pressure (as part of Beck triad). However, patients with a cardiac tamponade will have a pulsus paradoxus, characteristically muffled heart sounds, and the FAST exam will show fluid around the heart.

question_text: A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician because of swelling in her legs for the past 2 months. She has noticed that her legs gradually swell up throughout the day. She has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include lisinopril and metformin. She works as a waitress at a local diner. Her father died of liver cancer at the age of 61 years. She drinks one to two glasses of wine daily and occasionally more on weekends. She does not smoke cigarettes or use illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows 1+ pitting edema in both lower extremities up to the level of the calves with relative sparing of the feet. There are several dilated, compressible tortuous veins measuring 4–5 mm over both lower extremities, and multiple excoriation marks are noted over both ankles. There is a 2 x 2-cm ulcer with a shallow base and irregular edges over the medial surface of the left ankle. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, gallops, or rubs. The abdomen is soft and nontender; there is no organomegaly. Serum glucose, urea nitrogen, creatinine, D-dimer concentrations, and results of liver function tests are within the reference ranges. The ankle-brachial index is 1.1 bilaterally. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 52-year-old woman comes to the physician because of swelling in her legs for the past 2 months. She has noticed that her legs gradually swell up throughout the day. She has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include lisinopril and metformin. She works as a waitress at a local diner. Her father died of liver cancer at the age of 61 years. She drinks one to two glasses of wine daily and occasionally more on weekends. She does not smoke cigarettes or use illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows 1+ pitting edema in both lower extremities up to the level of the calves with relative sparing of the feet. There are several dilated, compressible tortuous veins measuring 4–5 mm over both lower extremities, and multiple excoriation marks are noted over both ankles. There is a 2 x 2-cm ulcer with a shallow base and irregular edges over the medial surface of the left ankle. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, gallops, or rubs. The abdomen is soft and nontender; there is no organomegaly. Serum glucose, urea nitrogen, creatinine, D-dimer concentrations, and results of liver function tests are within the reference ranges. The ankle-brachial index is 1.1 bilaterally. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Lower extremity edema with relative sparing of the feet and dilated tortuous veins > 3 mm in diameter (varicose veins) in the absence of other systemic findings (e.g., pulmonary crackles, jugular venous distention) strongly suggests chronic venous disease (CVD), for which this patient's age, sex, and job that involves prolonged standing are risk factors. The presence of certain skin changes such as pruritic dermatitis or a venous ulcer indicates advanced CVD.
learning_objective: Recognize chronic venous disease, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic test.

answers.explanation_why: Sclerotherapy, which is a form of vein ablation therapy (VAT), is a treatment option for varicose veins. However, endovenous thermal ablation is preferred over sclerotherapy because of lower complication rates. Furthermore, another step is required before proceeding with VAT.

Antiplatelet (e.g., clopidogrel) or vasodilator (e.g., cilostazol) therapy is not effective in the management of CVD. These drugs are primarily used in the management of peripheral artery disease (PAD), which can cause lower limb ulcers but such ulcers typically have regular margins and a punched-out appearance and occur over pressure points (e.g., tips of toes, lateral malleolus). Furthermore, PAD causes pale, shiny, cold, hairless skin on the lower extremities rather than edema and dermatitis and the normal ankle-brachial index (1.0–1.4) makes PAD extremely unlikely.

images.title: Features of arterial, venous, and neuropathic ulcers

answers.explanation_why:
Current guidelines recommend that all patients suspected to have CVD should undergo duplex ultrasonography before any treatment. The goal is to identify whether the patient has a correctable cause of venous reflux (e.g., reflux in the superficial venous system), and to plan for an interventional procedure (e.g., by identifying the superficial, deep, and perforator vein sites) if the patient qualifies for such a procedure.

An initial trial of compression therapy is appropriate for patients with mild CVD (i.e., varicose veins or edema only) without a correctable cause, and pregnant patients with CVD. A patient with advanced CVD, as seen here, or a correctable cause of venous reflux should undergo endovenous thermal ablation as long as there are no contraindications to the procedure (e.g., deep vein thrombosis, peripheral artery disease). All patients with CVD should be counseled on lifestyle changes to improve venous return (e.g., daily exercise, frequent elevation of the legs, avoidance of long periods of standing and sitting).

Compression therapy (e.g., with compression stockings) provides symptomatic relief in patients with CVD. An initial trial of compression therapy is appropriate for patients with mild CVD (i.e., varicose veins or edema only) without a correctable cause, and pregnant patients with CVD. This patient has advanced CVD, for which a different treatment is indicated. Regardless of the severity, current guidelines recommend that any form of treatment should be preceded by another step.

For patients with CVD, studies such as venography or venous plethysmography are not routinely recommended. These studies are only considered if the initial imaging modality is inconclusive or in specific circumstances (e.g., surgical planning for CVD due to intraabdominal venous obstruction).

question_text:
Four days after undergoing a craniotomy and evacuation of a subdural hematoma, a 56-year-old man has severe pain and swelling of his right leg. He has chills and nausea. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and chronic kidney disease and was started on hemodialysis 2 years ago. Prior to admission, his medications were insulin, enalapril, atorvastatin, and sevelamer. His temperature is 38.3°C (101.0°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Examination shows a swollen, warm, and erythematous right calf. Dorsiflexion of the right foot causes severe pain in the right calf. The peripheral pulses are palpated bilaterally. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
10.1 g/dL

Leukocyte count
11,800/mm^3

Platelet count
230,000/mm^3

Serum

Glucose
87 mg/dL

Creatinine
1.9 mg/dL

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
content_preview: Four days after undergoing a craniotomy and evacuation of a subdural hematoma, a 56-year-old man has severe pain and swelling of his right leg. He has chills and nausea. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and chronic kidney disease and was started on hemodialysis 2 years ago. Prior to admission, his medications were insulin, enalapril, atorvastatin, and sevelamer. His temperature is 38.3°C (101.0°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Examination shows a swollen, warm, and erythematous right calf. Dorsiflexion of the right foot causes severe pain in the right calf. The peripheral pulses are palpated bilaterally. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 10.1 g/dL Leukocyte count 11,800/mm3 Platelet count 230,000/mm3 Serum Glucose 87 mg/dL Creatinine 1.9 mg/dL Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
hint: Pain and swelling of the right calf, fever, and a positive Homan sign (dorsiflexion of the foot causing pain in the calf) indicate deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which puts this patient at high risk of developing a pulmonary embolism.
learning_objective: Recognize deep vein thrombosis in a postoperative patient, and choose the most appropriate next step in treatment.

answers.explanation_why: Iliac artery stenting is not indicated for DVT but may be considered for patients with symptomatic peripheral artery disease (PAD). Although PAD can sometimes manifest as acute limb ischemia (ALI) from plaque thrombosis, it is unlikely to cause significant swelling, redness, or a positive Homan sign. Instead, ALI patients present with a cool limb, decreased peripheral pulses, and, in some cases, sensory symptoms. PAD usually has a chronic, progressive course and manifests with exertional leg cramping, which is not present in this patient.

Unfractionated heparin therapy is a form of parenteral anticoagulation that can be used to treat acute DVT, especially in patients with poor kidney function. However, anticoagulation is contraindicated in this patient because of his high risk of bleeding (recent surgery and intracranial hemorrhage).

An inferior vena cava filter is indicated in this patient to prevent pulmonary embolism. IVC filters are indicated in patients with (or at high risk of) thromboembolism who have absolute contraindications to anticoagulation (e.g., recent surgery, intracranial hemorrhage, active bleeding), or complications from anticoagulation, as well as those who have not responded to anticoagulation. This patient underwent a craniotomy and evacuation of a subdural hematoma four days ago. Because of the risk of secondary hemorrhage, anticoagulation is contraindicated.

Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) is a parenteral anticoagulant commonly used to treat and prevent DVT. Because it is renally excreted, LMWH is contraindicated in patients with poor kidney function (e.g., patients with chronic kidney disease). Additionally, anticoagulation is contraindicated in this patient because of his high risk of bleeding (recent surgery and intracranial hemorrhage).

Thrombolytic agents, such as urokinase, are reserved for use in patients with phlegmasia cerulea dolens, massive iliofemoral DVT, hemodynamic instability, or those who have not responded to anticoagulation. This patient's recent surgery and intracranial hemorrhage are an absolute contraindication to thrombolytic therapy.

Surgical thrombectomy is reserved for patients with phlegmasia cerulea dolens, massive iliofemoral DVT, or those who have not responded to anticoagulation. Because thrombectomy requires heparinization, it is contraindicated in this patient (recent surgery and intracranial hemorrhage).

Warfarin is commonly prescribed for oral anticoagulation in patients with DVT but not initially as a monotherapy. The problem is that warfarin first decreases anticoagulant proteins C and S because of their shorter half-life (6–10 hours), before reducing the coagulant factors II, VII, IX, and X (half-life of 2–4 days). As a result, warfarin monotherapy induces a transient hypercoagulable state for the first couple of days. Without bridging therapy, this state could worsen the patient's DVT and/or cause warfarin-induced skin necrosis. Regardless of this effect, however, anticoagulation is contraindicated in this patient because of his high risk of bleeding (recent surgery and intracranial hemorrhage).

question_text: Paramedics are called to a 35-year-old man who has accidentally cut off his left fingertip while chopping vegetables. He has no significant past medical history. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 96/min, and blood pressure is 112/72 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 99%. His left index finger is amputated distal to the distal interphalangeal joint at the level of the nail bed, and exposed bone is visible. There is profuse bleeding from the wound site. His ability to flex, extend, abduct, and adduct the joints is preserved and sensation is intact. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step for preserving the detached fingertip prior to transporting this patient to the emergency department?
content_preview: Paramedics are called to a 35-year-old man who has accidentally cut off his left fingertip while chopping vegetables. He has no significant past medical history. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 96/min, and blood pressure is 112/72 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 99%. His left index finger is amputated distal to the distal interphalangeal joint at the level of the nail bed, and exposed bone is visible. There is profuse bleeding from the wound site. His ability to flex, extend, abduct, and adduct the joints is preserved and sensation is intact. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step for preserving the detached fingertip prior to transporting this patient to the emergency department?
hint: In complete fingertip amputations, a specific first-aid technique is recommended to preserve the amputated tissue without causing cellular damage.
learning_objective: Choose the correct method to preserve a detached fingertip prior to transport.

answers.content: Wrap the fingertip in gauze wet with iodine in a sealed plastic bag placed on ice
answers.explanation_why: Although wrapping the fingertip in damp gauze, sealing it in a plastic bag, then placing it on ice is an appropriate approach for preserving an amputated fingertip, antiseptics such as iodine damage the finger tissue and decrease tissue viability, reducing the chances of successful reattachment (replantation).

answers.content: Wrap the fingertip in dry gauze in a sealed plastic bag placed on ice
answers.explanation_why: The fingertip should be wrapped in gauze, sealed in a plastic bag, and then placed on ice. However, dry gauze is not recommended because it compromises tissue integrity and decreases the chances of successful reattachment (replantation).

answers.content: Preserve the fingertip in cooled saline water
answers.explanation_why: Although the fingertip should be kept cool during transport, direct immersion in saline water is not recommended as it may cause maceration of tissue and decrease the likelihood of successful reattachment (replantation).

answers.content: Preserve the fingertip in warm saline water
answers.explanation_why: Warm saline water is not recommended as it may cause maceration (due to direct immersion in fluid) of open tissue and encourage microbial growth in the wound (by warming), both of which would decrease the likelihood of reattachment (replantation).

answers.content: Wrap the fingertip in gauze damp with saline in a sealed plastic bag placed in ice water
answers.explanation_why:
The amputated fingertip should be gently rinsed with water, wrapped in damp gauze, sealed in a watertight bag, and then placed in a bag with ice water. An amputated limb should never be placed directly on ice because of the potential for cold damage (i.e., frostbite). The aim is to preserve the finger as best as possible in order to maximize the chances of successful reattachment (replantation). The patient and their amputated fingertip should then be transported immediately to the emergency department.

Once in the emergency department, the patient's hand would be anesthetized and debrided. The decision to attempt reattachment is typically left to specialist consultation and is decided on a case-by-case basis, although it is not commonly attempted in adults.

answers.content: Place the fingertip on ice in a sealed plastic bag
answers.explanation_why: Directly placing the fingertip on ice is not recommended because of the risk of cold damage (i.e., frostbite).

answers.content: Wrap the fingertip in gauze wet with hydrogen peroxide in a sealed plastic bag placed on ice
answers.explanation_why: Although wrapping the fingertip in damp gauze, sealing it in a plastic bag, then placing it on ice is an appropriate approach for preserving an amputated fingertip, antiseptics such as hydrogen peroxide damage the finger tissue and decrease tissue viability, reducing the chances of successful reattachment (replantation).

answers.content: Wrap the fingertip in gauze wet with alcohol in a sealed plastic bag placed on ice
answers.explanation_why: Although wrapping the fingertip in damp gauze, sealing it in a plastic bag, then placing it on ice is an appropriate approach for preserving an amputated fingertip, antiseptics such as alcohol damage the finger tissue and decrease tissue viability, reducing the chances of successful reattachment (replantation).

question_text: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He has had mild pain in his left groin for 2 weeks. He was admitted to the hospital 1 month ago for myocardial infarction. Cardiac catheterization and angiography showed occlusion of the left anterior descending artery and he underwent placement of 2 stents. He has hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. There is no family history of serious illness. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 30 years. Current medications include aspirin, clopidogrel, rosuvastatin, and enalapril. His temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 130/84 mm Hg. Examination shows a 3-cm (1.2-in), tender, pulsatile mass in the left thigh, below the inguinal ligament. There is mild erythema of the overlying skin. A loud bruit is heard on auscultation of the mass. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. There is no edema in the lower limbs. Femoral and pedal pulses are palpable bilaterally. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He has had mild pain in his left groin for 2 weeks. He was admitted to the hospital 1 month ago for myocardial infarction. Cardiac catheterization and angiography showed occlusion of the left anterior descending artery and he underwent placement of 2 stents. He has hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. There is no family history of serious illness. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 30 years. Current medications include aspirin, clopidogrel, rosuvastatin, and enalapril. His temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 130/84 mm Hg. Examination shows a 3-cm (1.2-in), tender, pulsatile mass in the left thigh, below the inguinal ligament. There is mild erythema of the overlying skin. A loud bruit is heard on auscultation of the mass. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. There is no edema in the lower limbs. Femoral and pedal pulses are palpable bilaterally. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Most cases of percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty are performed via a femoral artery catheterization. The presence of a tender, pulsatile mass with a bruit suggests a complication resulting from injury to the vascular wall during femoral artery catheterization.
learning_objective: Recognize femoral artery pseudoaneurysm.

answers.explanation_why: Femoral artery dissection may occur as a rare complication (< 0.5% of cases) of femoral artery catheterization and can manifest with pain in the groin and a bruit on auscultation. However, most cases usually occur during or immediately after the procedure, and the pain is usually more acute and severe, while this patient presents with mild groin pain for the past 2 weeks. Also, the presence of a pulsatile swelling makes a different diagnosis more likely.
A saphenous varix may manifest with a groin swelling and bruit (venous hum) on auscultation. However, a saphenous varix is not pulsatile; for this reason, a different diagnosis should be considered.

A femoral artery pseudoaneurysm occurs in ∼ 1% of patients following iatrogenic femoral artery puncture (e.g., percutaneous cardiac catheterization via the femoral artery). Femoral artery pseudoaneurysms manifest with pain in the groin, a pulsatile mass, and a systolic bruit over the swelling. Duplex ultrasonography is required to distinguish a femoral artery pseudoaneurysm from other conditions that may manifest similarly (e.g., femoral artery hematoma, femoral arteriovenous fistula, femoral artery aneurysm, saphenous varix). On ultrasound, a femoral artery pseudoaneurysm is usually visible as a nonhomogenous hypoechoic mass that is connected to a femoral vessel via a patent track. Bidirectional flow through the neck of the aneurysm may also be seen.

A femoral hematoma may develop as a complication of femoral artery catheterization. The patient may present with pain in the femoral region and discoloration of the overlying skin. However, this complication usually occurs within 12 hours of the procedure. A different complication is more likely in this patient, who presents with symptoms a few weeks after the procedure.

Accidental puncture of the femoral vein during femoral artery catheterization may rarely (< 1% of cases) result in the formation of an arteriovenous (AV) fistula. Most fistulas are asymptomatic and tend to close spontaneously within a few months. An AV fistula that fails to close would present with a bruit on auscultation. If the fistula is large enough, a pulsatile mass and groin pain may also be present. However, if an AV fistula fails to close, the patient develops limb edema, venous dilatation in the lower limb, symptoms of limb ischemia (e.g., intermittent claudication), and/or clinical features of heart failure a few months after the procedure.

Thrombotic occlusion of the femoral artery may occur as a complication of femoral artery catheterization. However, this complication usually occurs within a few days of the procedure. Moreover, the patient does not have signs of acute limb ischemia (e.g., poor peripheral pulses, limb claudication) associated with femoral artery thrombosis. Finally, femoral artery thrombosis would not manifest as a pulsatile mass.

Femoral artery catheterization during interventional percutaneous cardiac catheterization may rarely (< 1% of cases) result in a femoral abscess due to infection of the puncture site. A femoral abscess would manifest as a tender mass with erythema of the overlying skin, which is seen in this patient. However, femoral abscesses are nonpulsatile and usually develop within a few days of femoral catheterization. Additionally, the lack of systemic signs (e.g., fever) and the onset of symptoms in this patient 2 weeks after the procedure suggests a different diagnosis.
