question_text: A 68-year-old man is admitted to the intensive care unit after open abdominal aortic aneurysm repair. The patient has received 4 units of packed red blood cells during the surgery. During the first 24 hours following the procedure, he has only passed 200 mL of urine. He has congestive heart failure and hypertension. Current medications include atenolol, enalapril, and spironolactone. He appears ill. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/78 mm Hg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes and flat neck veins. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a serum creatinine level of 2.0 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) of 48 mg/dL. His serum creatinine and BUN on admission were 1.2 mg/dL and 18 mg/dL, respectively. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 68-year-old man is admitted to the intensive care unit after open abdominal aortic aneurysm repair. The patient has received 4 units of packed red blood cells during the surgery. During the first 24 hours following the procedure, he has only passed 200 mL of urine. He has congestive heart failure and hypertension. Current medications include atenolol, enalapril, and spironolactone. He appears ill. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 110/78 mm Hg. Examination shows dry mucous membranes and flat neck veins. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show a serum creatinine level of 2.0 mg/dL and a blood urea nitrogen (BUN) of 48 mg/dL. His serum creatinine and BUN on admission were 1.2 mg/dL and 18 mg/dL, respectively. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: This patient's oliguria in combination with increased BUN and creatinine levels suggests acute kidney injury (AKI). The onset of AKI one day after surgery in a patient with signs of hypovolemia (e.g., tachycardia, dry mucous membranes, flat neck veins) and a BUN:creatinine ratio > 20:1 is consistent with prerenal AKI.
learning_objective: Recognize prerenal acute kidney injury, and recall its diagnostic findings.

answers.explanation_why: Intrinsic causes of AKI typically manifest with a decreased urine osmolality (< 350 mOsmol/kg H_2O), as the kidney loses the ability to concentrate the urine. Acute tubular necrosis (e.g., due to hypoxia) is the most common cause of AKI in the postoperative period. However, the BUN:creatinine ratio is decreased (≤ 15:1) in patients with intrinsic AKI because the renal damage causes decreased urea reabsorption. This patient's increased BUN:creatinine ratio (> 20:1) is more consistent with prerenal AKI, in which urea reabsorption is increased.
answers.explanation_but: This patient, who underwent major surgery with loss of large amounts of blood, is at risk for hypoxic damage to the kidney. Prerenal AKI can lead to intrinsic AKI if causes of renal hypoxia (e.g., hypovolemia and/or hypotension) are not treated.

answers.explanation_why: WBC casts are a typical finding in patients with pyelonephritis and tubulointerstitial diseases, such as acute interstitial nephritis and renal papillary necrosis. Pyelonephritis most commonly manifests with high fevers, chills, flank pain, costovertebral angle tenderness, and symptoms of cystitis (e.g., dysuria, frequency, or urgency), which are absent in this patient. Although tubulointerstitial diseases commonly manifest with elevated levels of BUN and creatinine and may result in acute kidney injury, additional symptoms (e.g., flank pain) are usually present. Also, the BUN:creatinine ratio would not be increased.

Damage to any part of the urinary tract may result in hematuria. Hematuria in combination with oliguria and azotemia is a typical finding in nephritic syndrome. However, patients with nephritic syndrome usually have features of hypervolemia (e.g., mild to moderate edema, hypertension) rather than hypovolemia.

Patients with prerenal AKI typically present with a decreased urine sodium concentration (< 20 mmol/L). Prerenal AKI due to hypovolemia causes renal hypoperfusion rather than direct damage to the nephrons. The kidneys physiologically respond to hypoperfusion by reabsorbing large amounts of sodium, which is then followed by water. As a result, the excreted urine contains low amounts of sodium and is concentrated.

In intrinsic AKI (caused by direct kidney damage), the function of the tubular system is impaired, leading to reduced reabsorption of sodium and a urine sodium concentration > 40 mmol/L.

Proteinuria results from direct kidney injury secondary to damage to the glomeruli (e.g., glomerulonephritis, diabetic nephropathy), damage to the tubules (e.g., Fanconi syndrome), or overproduction of low molecular weight proteins (e.g., multiple myeloma). Patients with intrinsic AKI may also present with oliguria and azotemia, as seen here. However, signs of hypervolemia (e.g., edema), rather than hypovolemia (dry mucous membranes and flat neck veins in this patient), would be expected in intrinsic AKI, as the kidneys are unable to effectively remove excess fluid from the body.

question_text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of difficulty walking and cold feet for the past 2 months. His parents report that he tires quickly from walking. The patient was born at 37 weeks' gestation and has met all developmental milestones. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. He is at the 50^th percentile for height and 40^th percentile for weight. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 119/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg in the right arm. A grade 2/6 systolic murmur is heard in the left paravertebral region. At this time, further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of difficulty walking and cold feet for the past 2 months. His parents report that he tires quickly from walking. The patient was born at 37 weeks' gestation and has met all developmental milestones. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. He is at the 50th percentile for height and 40th percentile for weight. His temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), pulse is 119/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg in the right arm. A grade 2/6 systolic murmur is heard in the left paravertebral region. At this time, further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: Cold feet and potential lower-extremity claudication with physical exertion combined with high blood pressure in the upper extremities and a left paravertebral systolic murmur should raise concern for coarctation of the aorta (CoA).

answers.explanation_why: Rib notching can be seen on x-ray in patients with CoA, if compensatory collateral blood flow involves the intercostal vessels. The vessels may dilate to bypass the left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. While this patient may eventually develop visible rib notching, it is generally a sign of chronic disease and usually is not apparent in children before 5 years of age.

images.title: Coarctation of the aorta
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view)Focal indentation of the distal aortic arch is seen at the location of aortic coarctation (illustration). An additional finding is inferior rib notching (Roesler sign; examples indicated by arrowheads), which is produced by dilated intercostal arteries.The figure-3 sign of coarctation (indicated by red line) is seen in this patient. It is produced by prestenotic dilatation of the aortic arch and left subclavian artery in combination with post-stenotic dilatation of the descending aorta. The presence of bilateral rib notching indicates that the coarctation is distal to the origin of both subclavian arteries.

answers.explanation_why:
CoA is most commonly located at the aortic isthmus, resulting in increased blood flow to the upper body and decreased blood flow to the lower body. Patients with noncritical CoA (i.e., mild-to-moderate CoA) typically present later in life (e.g., during childhood) with features of upper body hyperperfusion (e.g., high blood pressure in the upper extremities) and features of lower body hypoperfusion (e.g., cold feet, claudication upon exertion, brachial-femoral delay). In noncritical CoA, the left ventricular outflow obstruction leads to myocardial hypertrophy and increased collateral blood flow (e.g., to the intercostal arteries); rib notching occurs as a consequence of the collateral circulation between the internal thoracic and intercostal arteries and is usually a late finding (typically after 5 years of age).

Doppler echocardiography is the confirmatory test of choice and should be performed in all patients with suspected CoA. It can identify the location and extent of the stenosis and show concurrent anomalies, such as a bicuspid aortic valve (present in ∼ 60% of patients).

images.title: Coarctation of the aorta (hypoplastic type)
images.description: (1) Hypoplasia of aorta can lead to hypertension (↑ BP) in the head and upper limbs as well as poststenotic hypoperfusion. In patent ductus arteriosus, this can be compensated by a right-to-left-shunt of blood from the pulmonary arteries into the aorta, resulting in the flow of mixed blood with decreased oxygen saturation (↓ SaO_2) to the general circulation.(2) After closure of the ductus arteriosus, the right-to-left shunt is absent (~ SaO_2) and there is hypoperfusion (↓ BP) of the abdominal organs and lower extremities with oxygenated blood.

answers.explanation_why: Interarm differences in blood pressure can be a finding of CoA in the rare case that the narrowing is proximal to the left subclavian artery. In such patients, blood pressure in the right arm would be higher than in the left arm. In most infants and children with aortic coarctation, we would instead expect differences in blood pressure between the upper and the lower extremities.

images.title: Coarctation of the aorta
images.description: (1) Stenosis distal to the left subclavian artery results in hypertension (↑ BP) in the upper extremities and the head, and hypotension (↓ BP) in the lower extremities and abdomen.(2) If coarctation involves the origin of the left subclavian artery, BP in the right arm and head will be higher than in the left arm, lower extremities, and abdomen.

answers.explanation_why: A right ventricular outflow tract obstruction (RVOTO) is typically seen in patients with tetralogy of Fallot. While patients with tetralogy of Fallot can also have a systolic ejection murmur, it is usually best heard at the left sternal border, rather than the left paravertebral region, as is the case in this patient. Furthermore, such patients usually present with (mild) cyanosis and intermittent hypoxic episodes that improve with squatting, none of which is present in this patient. CoA is characterized by a fixed supravalvular left ventricular outflow tract obstruction.

answers.content: Low tissue oxygenation in the legs
answers.explanation_why: Low tissue oxygenation in the legs is typically seen in patients with ductal-dependent CoA (i.e., critical CoA and concomitant patent ductus arteriosus). These patients typically have differential cyanosis, as deoxygenated blood flows across the patent ductus arteriosus into the postductal systemic circulation. This patient most likely has noncritical, non-ductal-dependent CoA as there is no history of differential cyanosis. In patients with noncritical CoA, the blood flow to the lower extremities, although reduced, is typically enough to maintain normal arterial oxygen saturation and, therefore, tissue oxygenation. Additionally, the oxygen extraction fraction may increase to compensate for the hypoperfusion, contributing to normal tissue oxygenation.

question_text: A 5-week-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of shortness of breath and noisy breathing for the past 2 weeks. She reports that the episodes are worse when he is agitated and better when he sleeps in supine position. During this period he has had frequent regurgitation of his feeds. He was born at 37 weeks' gestation. The neonatal period was complicated by transient tachypnea. His immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 160/min, respirations are 52/min, and blood pressure is 94/56 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Physical examination shows subcostal retractions. Stridor and diffuse wheezing are heard in the thorax. Anteroposterior and lateral x-rays of the chest show anterior tracheal bowing and narrowing. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 5-week-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of shortness of breath and noisy breathing for the past 2 weeks. She reports that the episodes are worse when he is agitated and better when he sleeps in supine position. During this period he has had frequent regurgitation of his feeds. He was born at 37 weeks' gestation. The neonatal period was complicated by transient tachypnea. His immunizations are up-to-date. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 160/min, respirations are 52/min, and blood pressure is 94/56 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. Physical examination shows subcostal retractions. Stridor and diffuse wheezing are heard in the thorax. Anteroposterior and lateral x-rays of the chest show anterior tracheal bowing and narrowing. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's underlying condition is a rare but important cause of respiratory symptoms in infants. The presence of stridor (suggesting upper airway obstruction) and regurgitation of feeds (due to esophageal compression) are important clues.
learning_objective: Recognize a vascular ring causing respiratory symptoms in an infant, and choose the most appropriate next step in management.

answers.explanation_why: Racemic epinephrine is used to treat upper airway obstruction caused by severe croup, which is a common cause of respiratory symptoms in young children (although uncommon in children < 3 months of age). Croup manifests with hoarseness and a barking cough; fever and rhinorrhea may also be seen. This patient has stridor but no fever or rhinorrhea. Moreover, in croup, x-ray shows a steeple sign, not tracheal bowing.

images.title: Steeple sign
images.description: X-ray neck of a young child (AP view)The upper tracheal air column, which normally appears with a square-shouldered configuration, has assumed a conical shape (green overlay) reminiscent of a church steeple (steeple sign; cf. illustration).The steeple sign indicates subglottic airway narrowing and is most commonly seen in croup. However, it may also appear in other conditions (e.g., bacterial tracheitis, tumors). An accompanying lateral radiograph might additionally show inspiratory overdistention of the hypopharynx.

answers.explanation_why: Tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) causes respiratory distress, drooling, choking, and an inability to feed in newborns; it is unlikely to present in a 5-week-old infant. In addition, the majority of patients with TEF have a history of polyhydramnios due to the inability of the fetus to swallow amniotic fluid. Furthermore, TEF does not explain this patient's stridor or x-ray findings.

images.title: Gross classification of esophageal atresia
images.description: Gross type A: esophageal atresia without tracheoesophageal fistulaGross type B: esophageal atresia with an upper tracheoesophageal fistulaGross type C: esophageal atresia with a lower tracheoesophageal fistulaGross type D: esophageal atresia with upper and lower tracheoesophageal fistulaGross type E: tracheoesophageal fistula without atresia

answers.explanation_why: Nebulized albuterol is used to treat acute asthma, which typically manifests with sudden shortness of breath, wheezing, and a dry cough that usually worsens at night. This patient presents with shortness of breath and wheezing, but his symptoms improve at night. In addition, chest x-ray findings in acute asthma exacerbation are expected to show hyperinflation of the lungs, not tracheal changes.

answers.content: Surgical division of a vascular ring
answers.explanation_why: A vascular ring is a rare cause of respiratory symptoms in infants that is treated with surgical division. Vascular rings typically manifest with shortness of breath, wheezing, stridor due to tracheal compression, as well as difficulty swallowing, regurgitation of food, and/or unintended weight loss resulting from esophageal compression. The severity of symptoms depends on the degree of tracheal and esophageal compression by the vascular ring. X-ray typically shows tracheal bowing and narrowing, indicating tracheal compression.

images.title: Double aortic arch
images.description: Ventral view of mediastinal structuresThere is constriction of the trachea and esophagus as a result of the additional aortic arch (vascular ring anomaly).

answers.explanation_why: Ceftriaxone is indicated for bacterial airway infection (e.g., epiglottitis), which can manifest with respiratory distress and inspiratory stridor. However, it usually also manifests in older children with sore throat, dysphagia, drooling, and acute onset of high fever, which are absent in this patient. Additionally, x-ray of the epiglottitis often shows a characteristic thumbprint sign (enlarged epiglottis), not the tracheal changes seen here.

images.title: Thumb and vallecula signs (epiglottitis)
images.description: X-ray soft tissue neck (lateral view)The epiglottis is swollen and rounded in appearance (thumb sign; highlighted by green overlay and black arrow) as a result of inflammation and edema. The normal air space between the tongue base and epiglottis has been almost entirely obliterated and is seen only as a shallow V-shaped space (vallecula sign; highlighted by red line).The thumb and vallecula signs are useful in the radiographic evaluation of epiglottitis.

answers.explanation_why: Supraglottoplasty is performed in severe cases of laryngomalacia. This condition typically manifests with low-pitched inspiratory stridor that worsens in the supine position and during sleeping or feeding. Other symptoms of laryngomalacia include reflux, swallowing dysfunction, and, in severe cases, failure to thrive. This patient presents with stridor that improves in the supine position and during sleeping. In addition, chest x-ray findings suggest involvement of the trachea rather than the larynx.

question_text: A 35-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 24-hour history of severe, left-sided headache and neck pain. She says that the symptoms started after completing a half-marathon. Shortly after the headache started, she also had weakness of the right upper extremity and sudden loss of vision in her left eye, both of which subsided after a few minutes. Medical history is unremarkable and the patient takes no medications. On arrival, she is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 77/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. Examination shows drooping of the left eyelid and a constricted left pupil. Visual acuity in both eyes is 20/20. There is no swelling of the optic discs. Muscle strength and deep tendon reflexes are normal bilaterally. A CT scan of the head without contrast shows no abnormalities. Duplex ultrasonography of the neck shows an absent flow in the left internal carotid artery. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 35-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 24-hour history of severe, left-sided headache and neck pain. She says that the symptoms started after completing a half-marathon. Shortly after the headache started, she also had weakness of the right upper extremity and sudden loss of vision in her left eye, both of which subsided after a few minutes. Medical history is unremarkable and the patient takes no medications. On arrival, she is alert and oriented to person, place, and time. Temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 77/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. Examination shows drooping of the left eyelid and a constricted left pupil. Visual acuity in both eyes is 20/20. There is no swelling of the optic discs. Muscle strength and deep tendon reflexes are normal bilaterally. A CT scan of the head without contrast shows no abnormalities. Duplex ultrasonography of the neck shows an absent flow in the left internal carotid artery. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Severe ipsilateral head and neck pain and partial Horner syndrome (ptosis and miosis) in combination with duplex ultrasonography findings of absent flow in the left internal carotid artery indicate a carotid artery dissection. This patient also likely experienced the complication of a transient ischemic attack (TIA), characterized by extremity weakness and amaurosis fugax.
learning_objective: Recognize carotid artery dissection, and choose the most appropriate antithrombotic therapy.

answers.explanation_why: Oxygen is the first-line treatment for cluster headaches. Although cluster headaches can present with ptosis and headache, they classically occur as recurrent attacks (up to 8 times per day) of pain in either an orbital or temporal distribution. Additionally, pain in cluster headaches typically does not involve the neck, nor do they cause cerebrovascular accidents such as TIAs.

Sumatriptan is commonly used to treat migraines. A migraine aura may present with neurologic symptoms (e.g., extremity weakness and visual loss) that classically precede a migraine headache. However, this patient experienced headache and neck pain before the onset of neurologic symptoms. Similarly, migraine auras tend to develop gradually and symptoms typically migrate from one side of the body to the other. Lastly, they do not cause cerebrovascular accidents such as TIAs.

Intravenous mannitol is used for the management of intracranial hypertension, which may occur after ischemic stroke or subarachnoid hemorrhage, both of which are complications of carotid artery dissection. Although this patient had a carotid artery dissection with ischemic neurologic symptoms (upper extremity weakness, vision loss) she does not have any signs of intracranial hypertension (e.g., papilledema, Cushing reflex).

Treatment with antithrombotic agents (either antiplatelet drugs or anticoagulants such as heparin) is indicated for carotid artery dissection after ruling out intracranial hemorrhage. Spontaneous carotid artery dissections generally have a good prognosis, but patients should be treated with an anticoagulant agent for 3–6 months and/or an antiplatelet agent for one year to reduce the risk of associated cerebrovascular accidents (such as TIA).

Thrombolytic therapy (e.g., alteplase) is often used to treat acute ischemic stroke, which can be a complication of carotid dissection. Although this patient had unilateral extremity weakness and amaurosis fugax, these symptoms resolved within a few minutes, suggesting a transient ischemic attack. This patient presents with ptosis and miosis without anhidrosis, indicating partial Horner syndrome, likely due to internal carotid artery dissection. Brain ischemia causes full rather than partial Horner syndrome. Furthermore, there is no evidence of ischemia on CT scan 24 hours after symptom onset.

question_text: A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of right-sided weakness and subjective decreased sensation that started 30 minutes ago. The patient reports that his symptoms started to ease 5 minutes after onset and have now completely resolved. He has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. His current medications include lisinopril, metformin, and sitagliptin. He is 183 cm (6 ft 0 in) tall and weighs 105 kg (220 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m^2. He appears well. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 150/88 mm Hg. Neurological examination shows no abnormalities. Cardiac examination shows regular rate and rhythm and a left-sided carotid bruit. Complete blood count, serum glucose, and electrolytes are within the reference ranges. An ECG shows sinus rhythm and left axis deviation. A CT scan of the head without contrast shows no abnormalities. Carotid doppler ultrasound shows 45% stenosis in the left carotid artery and 15% stenosis in the right. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of right-sided weakness and subjective decreased sensation that started 30 minutes ago. The patient reports that his symptoms started to ease 5 minutes after onset and have now completely resolved. He has hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. His current medications include lisinopril, metformin, and sitagliptin. He is 183 cm (6 ft 0 in) tall and weighs 105 kg (220 lb); BMI is 32 kg/m2. He appears well. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 150/88 mm Hg. Neurological examination shows no abnormalities. Cardiac examination shows regular rate and rhythm and a left-sided carotid bruit. Complete blood count, serum glucose, and electrolytes are within the reference ranges. An ECG shows sinus rhythm and left axis deviation. A CT scan of the head without contrast shows no abnormalities. Carotid doppler ultrasound shows 45% stenosis in the left carotid artery and 15% stenosis in the right. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's sudden-onset focal neurological deficits that resolved without treatment in combination with no evidence of ischemia on neuroimaging suggest a transient ischemic attack (TIA), for which this patient has numerous risk factors (diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, tobacco use, carotid artery stenosis). Two important factors for determining the management of carotid artery stenosis are the degree of stenosis (here < 50%) and if a patient is symptomatic (e.g., experiencing a TIA).
learning_objective: Recognize a transient ischemic attack (TIA), and choose the most appropriate secondary prevention strategy.

answers.explanation_why:
Antiplatelet therapy with aspirin or clopidogrel is recommended for all patients with a TIA as secondary stroke prevention. A noncontrast CT should be performed beforehand to rule out intracranial hemorrhage. Additional strategies for preventing recurrent TIA or stroke in this patient with carotid artery stenosis include statin therapy and treatment of modifiable risk factors for atherosclerosis (e.g., diabetes mellitus, hypertension) via lifestyle modifications (e.g., physical activity, dietary interventions, weight loss, smoking cessation) and medications.

Carotid revascularization (e.g., carotid endarterectomy, carotid artery stenting) is contraindicated if carotid artery stenosis is < 50% because the risks from the procedure outweigh any benefits.

images.title: Right internal carotid artery stenosis
images.description: MRI angiography (carotid arteries)There is high-grade stenosis of the origin of the right internal carotid artery (red overlay). Visible major neck vessels (green overlay) include the common carotid arteries (1), internal carotid arteries (2), external carotid arteries (3), right superior thyroid artery (4), and left vertebral artery (5).

answers.explanation_why: Carotid endarterectomy (CEA) is recommended in TIA for symptomatic patients who present with carotid stenosis ≥ 70%. Carotid endarterectomy is warranted in asymptomatic patients if the stenosis is ≥ 80%. CEA should also be considered in select patients with moderate stenosis (50–69%) depending on the patient's age, sex, and comorbidities, but the procedure is generally not indicated if the degree of stenosis is < 50%.

Intravenous alteplase therapy is recommended for the treatment of ischemic stroke. Although this patient has symptoms consistent with stroke (e.g., weakness and decreased sensation), the symptoms only lasted for 5 minutes; such a short duration is inconsistent with ischemic stroke.

Reassurance and follow-up in 2 weeks are not recommended because the patient has a high risk of stroke and requires treatment. Risk factors for cerebral ischemia in this patient include age > 60 years, blood pressure ≥ 140/90 mm Hg, unilateral weakness, diabetes mellitus, and symptoms lasting > 10 minutes.

A transthoracic echocardiogram should be part of the workup for a patient with TIA or stroke if there is suspicion of a cardioembolic etiology. This patient has no history of atrial fibrillation that would predispose him to a cardioembolic stroke and his ECG shows normal sinus rhythm, making a cardioembolic etiology of his symptoms unlikely.

Carotid artery stenting can be considered in patients with advanced carotid artery stenosis if a surgical approach is not feasible, e.g., because of poor surgical access to the stenosis or the presence of comorbidities that increase perioperative mortality. The procedure is generally not indicated if the degree of stenosis is < 50%.

question_text: A 53-year-old woman comes to the physician because of intermittent heaviness and paresthesia of the right arm for the past 2 months. She has also had multiple episodes of lightheadedness while painting a mural for the past 2 weeks. During these episodes, she was nauseated and had blurred vision. Her symptoms resolved after she drank some juice. She has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypercholesterolemia. Current medications include metformin, glipizide, enalapril, and atorvastatin. She appears anxious. Examination shows decreased radial and brachial pulses on the right upper extremity. The skin over the right upper extremity is cooler than the left. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 53-year-old woman comes to the physician because of intermittent heaviness and paresthesia of the right arm for the past 2 months. She has also had multiple episodes of lightheadedness while painting a mural for the past 2 weeks. During these episodes, she was nauseated and had blurred vision. Her symptoms resolved after she drank some juice. She has hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and hypercholesterolemia. Current medications include metformin, glipizide, enalapril, and atorvastatin. She appears anxious. Examination shows decreased radial and brachial pulses on the right upper extremity. The skin over the right upper extremity is cooler than the left. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient likely has a lower blood pressure reading in her right arm compared to the left one.
learning_objective: Recognize subclavian steal syndrome.

answers.explanation_why: Sulfonylureas, such as glipizide, frequently cause hypoglycemia and any combination of antidiabetic drugs is associated with an increased risk of hypoglycemic episodes. Hypoglycemia can manifest with lightheadedness, weakness, blurred vision, and nausea, with improvement of symptoms after oral intake of glucose (e.g., drinking juice). However, the association between arm activity (e.g., painting a mural) and her symptoms makes a drug side effect less likely. Additionally, medication side effect would not explain decreased pulses in this patient's right arm.

answers.content: Reversed blood flow in the right vertebral artery
answers.explanation_why:
Reversed blood flow in the right vertebral artery into the distal subclavian artery rather than towards the brainstem occurs in subclavian steal syndrome. Given this patient's vascular risk factors (i.e., hypercholesterolemia, diabetes mellitus, hypertension), she most likely has an atherosclerotic occlusive plaque in the right subclavian artery. Reduced blood flow explains the heaviness, paresthesia, decreased pulses, and cooler skin of her right arm (i.e., upper extremity ischemia). Furthermore, exertion of the arm leads to retrograde blood flow through the vertebral artery so that the distal subclavian “steals” blood from the brain and causes her presyncopal symptoms (lightheadedness, nausea, and blurred vision) that resolve with rest.

Treatment for subclavian steal syndrome involves control of atherosclerotic disease and antiplatelet therapy. Depending on the severity and location of the occlusion, percutaneous or open revascularization may be performed.

images.title: Pathophysiology of subclavian steal syndrome
images.description: Under normal conditions, the subclavian artery distributes blood equally to the arteries in the brain and arms (A). If there is stenosis of the subclavian artery proximal to the origin of the vertebral artery, this leads to hypoperfusion of the upper extremities on the affected side (B). This is compensated by a contralateral circulation, in which there is increased blood flow from the unaffected side to the affected side via the vertebral arteries. As a result, there is hypoperfusion of the vertebrobasilar territory and corresponding central nervous system symptoms.

answers.explanation_why: Diabetic neuropathy is caused in part by an accumulation of advanced glycosylation end products, which leads to microvascular disease and subsequent nerve fiber damage. Diabetic neuropathy is a chronic, progressive disease that classically begins symmetrically in the distal lower extremities and ascends proximally. This patient's symptoms only occur in the upper extremity, are associated with exercise, and are episodic in nature.

answers.content: Compression of neurovascular structures in the neck
answers.explanation_why: Thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) is caused by compression of the nerves and vessels above the first rib. Neurogenic symptoms of TOS may include weakness and paresthesias of the upper extremity associated with upper extremity movement (especially overhead), similar to the symptoms described by this patient. Compression of the subclavian artery may occur in < 1% of cases (leading to lower blood pressure and decreased pulses in the affected arm), but it does not cause the central neurologic symptoms shown by this patient (i.e., lightheadedness, nausea, blurred vision).

answers.content: Infarction of the middle cerebral artery
answers.explanation_why: A left middle cerebral artery stroke may manifest with several symptoms including hemiplegia of the upper extremity. However, symptoms would not be transient or episodic over a period of months. This patient has no focal neurological deficits on examination, which makes ischemic stroke unlikely. Also, asymmetric radial pulses would not be seen in a cerebral artery infarct.

question_text: A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of headache, blurred vision, and numbness of the right leg for the past 2 hours. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include enalapril and metformin. He is oriented only to person. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 99/min, and blood pressure is 158/94 mm Hg. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Muscle strength is normal in all extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Sensation to fine touch and position is decreased over the right lower extremity. The confrontation test shows loss of the nasal field in the left eye and the temporal field in the right eye with macular sparing. He is unable to read phrases shown to him but can write them when they are dictated to him. He has short-term memory deficits. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 62-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of headache, blurred vision, and numbness of the right leg for the past 2 hours. He has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Current medications include enalapril and metformin. He is oriented only to person. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 99/min, and blood pressure is 158/94 mm Hg. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Muscle strength is normal in all extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Sensation to fine touch and position is decreased over the right lower extremity. The confrontation test shows loss of the nasal field in the left eye and the temporal field in the right eye with macular sparing. He is unable to read phrases shown to him but can write them when they are dictated to him. He has short-term memory deficits. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient has sudden-onset neurologic symptoms, most likely caused by a stroke. He presents with vision loss in the right halves of the visual field (nasal field on the left and temporal field on the right), which is consistent with right-sided homonymous hemianopia. This finding suggests the involvement of the visual pathways behind the optical chiasma.
learning_objective: Recognize left posterior cerebral artery infarct.

answers.content: Infarct of the right middle cerebral artery
answers.explanation_why: The middle cerebral artery (MCA) supplies the lateral cortex, including the lateral portion of the frontal and parietal lobes, which provides motor and sensory innervation to the face and upper extremities. Stroke of the right MCA manifests with contralateral (i.e., left) homonymous hemianopia without macular sparing due to damage to the optic radiations. In addition, patients usually experience contralateral sensory loss and paralysis of the upper extremity, lower extremity, and lower half of the face with gaze deviation towards the side of the stroke. If the stroke occurs in the nondominant (typically the right) hemisphere, patients may also present with hemineglect. This patient has right-sided homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing, sensory impairment without motor impairment, no gaze deviation, and alexia without agraphia rather than hemineglect, making this diagnosis unlikely.

answers.content: Infarct of the left posterior inferior cerebellar artery
answers.explanation_why: Patients with ischemic stroke of the left posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) present with Wallenberg syndrome, or lateral medullary syndrome. Occlusion of the left PICA leads to ischemia and necrosis of the left lateral medulla. Patients experience ipsilateral Horner's syndrome, palatal weakness and dysphagia, vertigo, hemiataxia, and contralateral truncal sensory disturbances. This patient has decreased sensation of his right leg rather than right trunk, and the description of his verbal difficulties is more consistent with alexia than dysphagia. He exhibits none of the classic signs and symptoms for a PICA infarct.

answers.content: Infarct of the right posterior cerebral artery
answers.explanation_why: The right posterior cerebral artery (PCA) supplies the visual cortex of the occipital lobe. Patients with right-sided PCA stroke present with homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing on the left, not right. Patients with right-sided PCA strokes also often present with prosopagnosia due to damage to the fusiform face area, a symptom not experienced by this patient.

images.title: Posterior cerebral artery infarct
images.description:
A posterior cerebral artery infarct (left-sided here) typically leads to the following:
– Contralateral sensory loss (due to lateral thalamic involvement)
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing (because the macula receives collateral vascular supply from the middle cerebral artery)

answers.content: Infarct of the right anterior cerebral artery
answers.explanation_why: The anterior cerebral artery (ACA) supplies the anteromedial cortex, including the medial portion of the frontal and parietal lobes, which provides motor and sensory innervation to the lower extremities. Patients with stroke of the right ACA present with sensory and motor loss in the contralateral (i.e., left) lower limb; however, this patient has sensory findings in the right lower extremity. In addition, ACA stroke results in limb apraxia, urinary incontinence, dysarthria, and aphasia, none of which are seen in this patient. Furthermore, ACA stroke does not typically result in homonymous hemianopia.

Patients with HSV encephalitis present with a prodrome of headache, fever, nausea, and vomiting, followed by an acute onset of altered mental status, seizures, and psychiatric symptoms or behavioral changes (e.g., hypersexuality, hypomania, agitation). Patients also present with focal neurologic deficits (e.g., dysphasia, ataxia, hemiparesis, cranial nerve signs). Although this patient does have altered mental status, visual field deficits, and memory loss, he does not present with other symptoms of HSV encephalitis.

answers.content: Infarct of the left middle cerebral artery
answers.explanation_why: The middle cerebral artery (MCA) supplies the lateral cortex, including the lateral portion of the frontal and parietal lobes, which provides motor and sensory innervation to the face and upper extremities. Stroke of the left MCA manifests with contralateral (i.e., right) homonymous hemianopia, typically without macular sparing due to damage to the optic radiations. In addition, patients usually experience contralateral sensory loss and paralysis of the upper extremity, lower extremity, and lower half of the face with gaze deviation towards the side of the stroke. If the stroke occurs in the dominant (typically the left) hemisphere, patients may also present with aphasia. This patient has right-sided homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing, sensory impairment without motor impairment, no gaze deviation, and alexia without agraphia rather than aphasia, making this diagnosis unlikely.

images.title: Middle cerebral artery infarct
images.description:
A middle cerebral artery infarct (left-sided in this case) leads to various combinations of the following:– Contralateral hemisensory loss
– Contralateral hemiparesis, including central facial nerve palsy (with preserved or only mildly impaired forehead movement due to bilateral innervation)
– Ipsilateral gaze deviation
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopia
– Aphasia (if the dominant hemisphere is involved)

answers.content: Infarct of the left anterior inferior cerebellar artery
answers.explanation_why: Patients with ischemic stroke of the left anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA) present with lateral pontine syndrome due to ischemia of the left inferolateral pons, including cranial nerve nuclei. Symptoms include ipsilateral Horner's syndrome, facial paralysis and droop, decreased taste from the anterior 2/3 of the tongue, vertigo, audiovestibular dysfunction, and ataxia. This patient exhibits none of these symptoms.

answers.content: Infarct of the left anterior cerebral artery
answers.explanation_why: The anterior cerebral artery (ACA) supplies the anteromedial cortex, including the medial portion of the frontal and parietal lobes, which provides motor and sensory innervation to the lower extremities. Patients with stroke of the left ACA present with sensory and motor loss in the contralateral (i.e., right) lower limb, and while this patient does have sensory findings in the right lower extremity, muscle strength is still intact. In addition, ACA stroke results in limb apraxia, urinary incontinence, dysarthria, and aphasia, none of which are seen in this patient. Furthermore, ACA stroke does not typically result in homonymous hemianopia.

answers.content: Infarct of the right posterior inferior cerebellar artery
answers.explanation_why: Patients with ischemic stroke of the right posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) present with Wallenberg syndrome, or lateral medullary syndrome. Occlusion of the right PICA leads to ischemia and necrosis of the right lateral medulla. Patients experience ipsilateral Horner's syndrome, palatal weakness and dysphagia, vertigo, hemiataxia, and contralateral truncal sensory disturbances. This patient has decreased sensation of his right leg rather than left trunk, and the description of his verbal difficulties is more consistent with alexia rather than dysphagia. He exhibits none of the classic signs and symptoms for a PICA infarct.

answers.content: Infarct of the left posterior cerebral artery
answers.explanation_why: The posterior cerebral artery (PCA) supplies the posteroinferior cortex, including the visual cortex in the occipital lobe. Stroke in this area most commonly manifests with contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing, as seen in this patient, because the macula receives collateral vascular supply from the middle cerebral artery. Because the PCA also supplies the lateral parts of the thalamus, patients may also report contralateral hemisensory abnormalities such as numbness or paresthesia in the limbs, trunk, and/or chest. Further manifestations include memory deficits, vertigo, and nausea. If the PCA of the dominant (usually the left) hemisphere is affected, patients may also present with alexia without agraphia, anomic aphasia, and/or visual agnosia due to ischemic damage to the splenium of the corpus callosum, which carries visual information from the visual cortex to the Broca area and Wernicke area. If the PCA of the nondominant (usually the right) hemisphere is affected, patients may present with prosopagnosia.

images.title: Posterior cerebral artery infarct
images.description:
A posterior cerebral artery infarct (left-sided here) typically leads to the following:
– Contralateral sensory loss (due to lateral thalamic involvement)
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing (because the macula receives collateral vascular supply from the middle cerebral artery)

answers.content: Infarct of the right anterior inferior cerebellar artery
answers.explanation_why: Patients with ischemic stroke of the right anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA) present with lateral pontine syndrome due to ischemia of the right inferolateral pons, including cranial nerve nuclei. Symptoms include ipsilateral Horner's syndrome, facial paralysis and droop, decreased taste from the anterior 2/3 of the tongue, vertigo, audiovestibular dysfunction, and ataxia. This patient exhibits none of these symptoms.

Patients with ophthalmic or retinal migraine present with headache and monocular visual impairments, such as scotomas, bright flashing lights, or complete monocular blindness. A migraine can cause paresthesias, but is usually preceded by a prodrome of yawning, difficulty writing or reading, mood changes, and, in some cases, an aura. This patient has a headache, but no history of a prodrome prior to this event. In addition, he has bilateral visual impairment rather than unilateral.

question_text: A 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of weakness of his left leg for the past hour. He was unable to get out of bed that morning. His pants are soaked with urine. He has hypertension and coronary artery disease. Current medications include enalapril, carvedilol, aspirin, and simvastatin. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. Examination shows equal pupils that are reactive to light. Muscle strength is 2/5 in the left lower extremity. Plantar reflex shows an extensor response on the left. Sensation is decreased in the left lower extremity. On mental status examination, he is oriented to person, place, and time and has a flat affect. When asked to count backwards from 20, he stops after counting to 17. When asked to name 10 words beginning with the letter “d,” he stops after naming two words. Fundoscopy shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of weakness of his left leg for the past hour. He was unable to get out of bed that morning. His pants are soaked with urine. He has hypertension and coronary artery disease. Current medications include enalapril, carvedilol, aspirin, and simvastatin. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. Examination shows equal pupils that are reactive to light. Muscle strength is 2/5 in the left lower extremity. Plantar reflex shows an extensor response on the left. Sensation is decreased in the left lower extremity. On mental status examination, he is oriented to person, place, and time and has a flat affect. When asked to count backwards from 20, he stops after counting to 17. When asked to name 10 words beginning with the letter “d,” he stops after naming two words. Fundoscopy shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient has sudden-onset neurologic symptoms. An inability to complete goal-directed tests such as counting backward from 20 or naming words starting with the letter “d” together with a flat affect indicates abulia, which is usually the result of damage to the frontal lobe.
learning_objective: Recognize right anterior cerebral artery occlusion.

answers.explanation_why: Normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) may manifest with urinary incontinence and behavioral changes including a flattened affect and abulia. However, this condition is a gradually progressive disease, unlike the acute presentation in this patient. Although patients with NPH may have a feeling of weakness and numbness, true sensory deficits or lower limb weakness severe enough to impair movement are not typically seen. Instead, gait abnormalities (typically a shuffling, wide-based gait) are usually the earliest sign.

images.title: Normal pressure hydrocephalus
images.description: Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

answers.explanation_why: Occlusion of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery would result in lateral medullary syndrome, which is characterized by hoarseness, dysphagia, ipsilateral ataxia, ipsilateral preganglionic Horner's syndrome, as well as loss of pain and temperature sensations over the face ipsilaterally and in the contralateral side of the body. Urinary incontinence, motor deficits, and clinical features of frontal lobe damage are not usually seen.

A large infarct in the territory of the left middle cerebral artery (MCA) may result in abulia as well as sensory and motor deficits. However, neurologic deficits would occur in the right limb rather than the left one and are usually more prominent in the upper limb and trunk when compared to the lower limb. Patients with a left MCA stroke would also have dysphasia.

images.title: Middle cerebral artery infarct
images.description:
A middle cerebral artery infarct (left-sided in this case) leads to various combinations of the following:– Contralateral hemisensory loss
– Contralateral hemiparesis, including central facial nerve palsy (with preserved or only mildly impaired forehead movement due to bilateral innervation)
– Ipsilateral gaze deviation
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopia
– Aphasia (if the dominant hemisphere is involved)

answers.explanation_why: Occlusion of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery results in infarction of the lateral caudal pons and/or ischemia in the territory of the labyrinthine artery. Patients present with ipsilateral sensorineural hearing loss, ipsilateral ataxia, ipsilateral preganglionic Horner's syndrome, as well as loss of pain and temperature sensations over the face ipsilaterally and in the contralateral side of the body. Urinary incontinence, motor deficits, and clinical features of frontal lobe damage (e.g., abulia, flat affect) are not usually seen.

A large infarct in the territory of the right middle cerebral artery (MCA) can cause abulia and sensory and motor neurologic deficits on the left side of the body. However, neurologic deficits are usually more prominent in the upper limb and trunk than in the lower limb. Also, a patient with a massive right MCA stroke would present with left hemineglect (if the right hemisphere is nondominant) or aphasia (if the right hemisphere is dominant).

The anterior cerebral artery (ACA) supplies the anteromedial cortex, including the medial part of the frontal lobe and parietal lobe. These areas provide motor and sensory innervation of the lower extremities as well as control of micturition. Occlusion of the postcommunal segment (distal to the circle of Willis) of the right ACA typically results in upper motor neuron weakness manifesting with a contralateral positive Babinski sign, sensory deficits of the contralateral lower limb, and urinary incontinence. Signs of frontal lobe damage (e.g., abulia), as well as aphasia and limb apraxia, may also be present.

A right posterior cerebral artery (PCA) occlusion typically results in left homonymous hemianopia, not urinary incontinence and frontal lobe signs such as abulia. Larger PCA infarcts may occasionally cause hemisensory loss and/or hemiparesis. However, other features such as prosopagnosia (in individuals where the right hemisphere is the nondominant one) would also be expected.

images.title: Posterior cerebral artery infarct
images.description:
A posterior cerebral artery infarct (left-sided here) typically leads to the following:
– Contralateral sensory loss (due to lateral thalamic involvement)
– Contralateral homonymous hemianopsia with macular sparing (because the macula receives collateral vascular supply from the middle cerebral artery)

answers.explanation_why: Occlusion of the left anterior cerebral artery (ACA) manifests with urinary incontinence and abulia with sensory loss and upper motor neuron weakness in the lower limb (which causes a positive Babinski sign). However, the neurologic deficits in a left ACA stroke would appear in the right lower limb, not the left one.

Encephalitis that predominantly affects the medial temporal lobe is characteristic of herpes simplex encephalitis, which may manifest with focal neurologic deficits. However, in almost all patients, the onset of neurologic deficits would be preceded by fever, headache, and/or vomiting. Other clinical features such as memory loss, emotional lability, and/or dysphasia would also be present.

Hypertensive encephalopathy is a hypertensive emergency that occurs in patients with a mean arterial pressure >180 mm Hg and can cause neurologic deficits and nonlocalizing signs of cerebral edema, such as severe headache, nausea, and/or vomiting. Furthermore, hypertensive encephalopathy typically has an insidious onset, in contrast to the acute onset in this patient. Other features such as findings of grade IV hypertensive retinopathy on fundoscopy (flame-shaped hemorrhage, papilledema, and/or cotton wool spots) would also be present.

A left posterior cerebral artery (PCA) occlusion typically results in right homonymous hemianopia, not urinary incontinence and frontal lobe signs such as abulia. Larger PCA infarcts may occasionally cause hemisensory loss and/or hemiparesis. However, in a patient with a large left PCA infarct, the contralateral (right not left) limb would be affected, and other clinical features such as alexia without agraphia would be present.

question_text: Four hours after undergoing an open emergency surgery under general anesthesia for a bleeding abdominal aortic aneurysm, a 55-year-old man is unable to move both his legs. During the surgery, he had prolonged hypotension, which was corrected with IV fluids and vasopressors. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Prior to admission, his medications were hydrochlorothiazide and atorvastatin. The patient is conscious and oriented to place and person. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.0°F), pulse is 74/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. Examination shows muscle strength is 1/5 in the lower extremities. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: Four hours after undergoing an open emergency surgery under general anesthesia for a bleeding abdominal aortic aneurysm, a 55-year-old man is unable to move both his legs. During the surgery, he had prolonged hypotension, which was corrected with IV fluids and vasopressors. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 35 years. Prior to admission, his medications were hydrochlorothiazide and atorvastatin. The patient is conscious and oriented to place and person. His temperature is 37.7°C (99.0°F), pulse is 74/min, and blood pressure is 100/70 mm Hg. Examination shows muscle strength is 1/5 in the lower extremities. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: Sudden onset of paraparesis and autonomic dysfunction immediately after an aortic surgery, especially in the setting of intraoperative hypotension, is highly suggestive of anterior spinal artery (ASA) syndrome, as the artery that contributes to spinal cord perfusion (artery of Adamkiewicz) can be injured during aortic surgery.
learning_objective: Recognize anterior spinal artery syndrome, and recall the preserved sensory function.

answers.content: Normal temperature sensation in the extremities
answers.explanation_why: Pain and temperature sensations are carried by the spinothalamic tracts, which are located anterolaterally within the spinal cord. In ASA syndrome, the anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord is damaged, causing pain and temperature sensation to be lost.

Babinski sign, which is a feature of an upper motor neuron lesion, would eventually be present in ASA syndrome because of damage to the corticospinal tract. But Babinski reflex is usually not present initially because of spinal shock, and first appears typically 24 hours later.

The presence of a normal bulbocavernosus reflex indicates the resolution of spinal shock. Sudden-onset paraplegia and autonomic dysfunction immediately after aortic surgery are highly suggestive of spinal shock during the acute phase of ASA syndrome. The bulbocavernosus reflex is normally absent during this phase.

answers.content: Bilaterally increased knee and ankle jerk
answers.explanation_why: Bilaterally increased knee and ankle jerk reflexes are features of an upper motor neuron lesion. Since corticospinal tracts are damaged in ASA syndrome, patients eventually develop hyperreflexia in all limbs below the level of the lesion after about a week. During the acute phase of ASA syndrome, though, deep tendon reflexes are usually lost as a result of spinal shock.

In ASA syndrome, the anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord is damaged. The dorsal column, which receives its blood supply from the posterior spinal arteries, usually remains intact. Therefore, proprioception, pressure, and vibration senses are preserved in patients with ASA syndrome.

images.title: Anterior spinal artery syndrome at T8 level
images.description: Note that this illustration depicts late manifestations of anterior spinal artery syndrome. Acute findings, including flaccid paralysis at and below the level of lesion, are typically due to spinal shock.

question_text: A 2400-g (5.29-lb) male newborn is delivered at term to a 38-year-old woman. The initial examination shows that the child is at the 5th percentile for head circumference and 10th percentile for weight and length. He has a sloping forehead, a flat nasal bridge, increased interocular distance, low-set ears, and a protruding tongue. An examination of the peripheries reveals a single palmar crease and an increased gap between the first and second toes. Ocular examination reveals small white and brown spots in the periphery of both irises. The abdomen is distended. An x-ray of the abdomen shows two large air-filled spaces in the upper quadrant. This child's condition is most likely associated with which of the following cardiac anomalies?
content_preview: A 2400-g (5.29-lb) male newborn is delivered at term to a 38-year-old woman. The initial examination shows that the child is at the 5th percentile for head circumference and 10th percentile for weight and length. He has a sloping forehead, a flat nasal bridge, increased interocular distance, low-set ears, and a protruding tongue. An examination of the peripheries reveals a single palmar crease and an increased gap between the first and second toes. Ocular examination reveals small white and brown spots in the periphery of both irises. The abdomen is distended. An x-ray of the abdomen shows two large air-filled spaces in the upper quadrant. This child's condition is most likely associated with which of the following cardiac anomalies?
hint: The characteristic morphological features, Brushfield spots in the eye, and the “double bubble” sign on abdominal x-ray (indicating duodenal atresia) are all suggestive of trisomy 21 (Down syndrome).
learning_objective: Recognize Down syndrome, and recall its associated cardiac anomalies.

answers.explanation_why: Atrial septal defects (ASD) are among the most common congenital heart defects and are commonly associated with fetal alcohol syndrome, trisomy 21, and Holt-Oram syndrome. Although ASD occurs in approx. 15% of patients with Down syndrome, it is not the most common congenital cardiac anomaly seen in this condition.

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in atrial septal defect
images.description: An atrial septal defect causes blood to flow from the left to the right atrium (left-to-right shunt; white arrow), resulting in volume overload of the right atrium and ventricle (1). As a result, there is dilation and compensatory hypertrophy (double-headed white arrows) of the right atrium and ventricle (2). In the late stages, Eisenmenger syndrome with shunt reversal (right-to-left shunt; white arrow) and cyanosis can occur (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

answers.explanation_why:
Atrioventricular septal defects (AVSD; also referred to as endocardial cushion defects) are the most common congenital heart defects in patients with Down syndrome, occurring in about 40% of newborns with trisomy 21. AVSDs are usually diagnosed in the prenatal period, and discovery of an AVSD should warrant prompt genetic testing, as there is a strong association with trisomy 21. Down syndrome is diagnosed in approx. 40–50% of children with AVSD.

Diuretics, inotropic agents, and ACE inhibitors are usually given to improve cardiac function. Definitive treatment consists of complete surgical repair.

Ventricular septal defects (VSD) account for approx. 50% of all congenital heart defects, making them the most common cause of congenital heart disease overall. They are commonly associated with fetal alcohol syndrome, intrauterine infections, and many genetic syndromes (including trisomy 13, trisomy 18, and trisomy 21). Although VSD occurs in approximately 30% of patients with Down syndrome, it is not the most common congenital cardiac anomaly seen in this condition.

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in ventricular septal defect
images.description: A defect in the ventricular septum leads to a left-to-right shunt, the volume of which is dependent on the size of the defect. Blood flows from the left ventricle to the right ventricle (white arrow) along the pressure gradient (1). This leads to increased RV and LV preload (due to increased end-diastolic volume), ventricular hypertrophy and dilation (double-headed white arrows), and pulmonary hypertension resulting from excessive pulmonary blood flow (2). In end-stage disease, the pressure gradient is reversed because of Eisenmenger syndrome (shunt reversal), leading to the flow of mixed blood to the systemic circulation (white arrow) and subsequent cyanosis (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

answers.explanation_why: A patent ductus arteriosus is most commonly associated with prematurity, fetal alcohol syndrome, birth at high altitude, or congenital rubella infection. Although it occurs in approx. 5% of patients with Down syndrome, it is not the most common congenital cardiac anomaly seen in this condition.

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in patent ductus arteriosus
images.description: In patent ductus arteriosus, there is a left-to-right shunt, with blood flowing from the aorta to the pulmonary arteries during both systole and diastole (1). This shunt leads to volume overload (recirculation) of the blood within the pulmonary vessels, the left atrium, and left ventricle (2). Eventually, because of the increased blood flow to the pulmonary circulation, pulmonary hypertension may develop as well as Eisenmenger syndrome, which involves a shunt reversal. The left-to-right-shunt without cyanosis becomes a right-to-left shunt with cyanosis (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Pink: structures that contain mixed blood

answers.explanation_why: Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is the most common cause of cyanotic heart disease in children. Most cases arise sporadically, but approx. 15% of patients with TOF have an underlying genetic syndrome (such as Down syndrome or DiGeorge syndrome). Although it occurs in approx. 5% of patients with Down syndrome, it is not the most common congenital cardiac anomaly seen in this condition.

images.title: Tetralogy of Fallot
images.description:
Tetralogy of Fallot is the simultaneous occurrence of:
(a) Pulmonary stenosis
(b) Right ventricular hypertrophy
(c) Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
(d) An overriding aorta (above the VSD)The hemodynamic effects depend on the extent of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. With mild obstruction (1), a left-to-right shunt is more pronounced and there is mild cyanosis. With severe obstruction (2), a right-to-left shunt is more pronounced, which results in severe cyanosis. Pulmonary circulation may be supplied via a patent ductus arteriosus.

answers.explanation_why: Congenital pulmonary valve stenosis usually arises sporadically, but it can be seen in association with other congenital heart defects such as tetralogy of Fallot. It is not commonly associated with Down syndrome.

Transposition of the great arteries accounts for 20% of all cases of cyanotic congenital heart disease. It is associated with maternal diabetes, advanced maternal age, and congenital rubella infection. Unlike many other congenital heart defects, it is rarely associated with any genetic conditions such as Down syndrome.

images.title: Transposition of the great vessels (TGV)
images.description: TGV is a cyanotic congenital heart disease in which the pulmonary artery arises from the left ventricle and the aorta from the right ventricle, resulting in the formation of parallel circulatory systems. The left ventricle pumps oxygenated blood into the pulmonary circulation (red) and the right ventricle pumps deoxygenated blood into the aorta (blue), resulting in cyanosis.TGV is fatal unless a shunt between the two circulations is present (i.e., a patent ductus arteriosus or a patent foramen ovale) or a surgical intervention is performed in the neonatal period.

question_text: A 19-month-old girl is brought for a well-child examination. She was born at term and has been healthy. On physical examination, the child is alert and active. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 102/54 mm Hg. She is at the 75^th percentile for height and 80^th percentile for weight. Cardiac examination shows a normal S_1 and a split S_2 during inspiration. A grade 2/6 soft mid-systolic murmur is heard maximally at the lower left sternal border. A contrast echocardiogram is performed and reveals a mild transient right-to-left interatrial shunt that becomes apparent when the child coughs. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 19-month-old girl is brought for a well-child examination. She was born at term and has been healthy. On physical examination, the child is alert and active. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 102/54 mm Hg. She is at the 75th percentile for height and 80th percentile for weight. Cardiac examination shows a normal S1 and a split S2 during inspiration. A grade 2/6 soft mid-systolic murmur is heard maximally at the lower left sternal border. A contrast echocardiogram is performed and reveals a mild transient right-to-left interatrial shunt that becomes apparent when the child coughs. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: A right-to-left interatrial shunt (made apparent by a saline bubble study on echocardiography) that opens during coughing is diagnostic of patent foramen ovale (PFO). During coughing, right-to-left shunting of blood can occur through this defect because of the transiently increased pressure in the pulmonary circulation (and consequently increased right atrial pressure).
learning_objective: Recognize patent foramen ovale (PFO) in an asymptomatic patient, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: Percutaneous closure of a PFO is only necessary when ischemic infarction has occurred due to a presumed paradoxical embolism in a patient with confirmed PFO. Typically, endovascular closure is performed in patients with recurrent ischemic events despite medical therapy and patients in whom long-term anticoagulation is contraindicated. Since this patient does not present with clinical manifestations of paradoxical embolism, percutaneous closure is not indicated.

This patient's mild, asymptomatic PFO requires no further diagnostic procedure, follow-up, or treatment. A persistent foramen ovale occurs in approx. 25–30% of the general population and, since most patients are asymptomatic, is typically an incidental finding. A diagnostic workup (i.e., contrast echocardiography) and treatment (e.g., anticoagulation, closure of the defect) only become necessary if paradoxical embolism occurs. While this patient has a soft-mid systolic murmur that may be just an innocent heart murmur, she is well without signs of paradoxical embolism (e.g., stroke symptoms).

A split S_2 during inspiration is physiological. If the S_2 splitting is fixed (persistently audible on auscultation during inspiration and expiration), there might be an underlying right ventricular overload (e.g., large atrial septal defects). PFOs are usually hemodynamically irrelevant and so do not cause fixed S_2 splitting.

Warfarin therapy is indicated in patients with a PFO and paradoxical embolism. After an embolic event, treatment is either initiated with antiplatelet therapy alone (e.g., aspirin) or, in high-risk individuals, in combination with warfarin (e.g., patients with a PFO with major shunt, recurrent cryptogenic TIA or stroke, DVT, and pulmonary embolism). Since this patient does not present with clinical manifestations of paradoxical embolism, anticoagulation is not indicated.

Aspirin therapy is indicated in patients with a PFO and paradoxical embolism (e.g., stroke). After an embolic event, treatment is either initiated with antiplatelet therapy alone (i.e., aspirin) or combined with warfarin in high-risk individuals (e.g., patients with a PFO with major shunt, recurrent cryptogenic TIA or stroke, DVT, or pulmonary embolism). Since this patient does not present with clinical manifestations of paradoxical embolism, antiplatelet therapy is not indicated.

Surgical closure permanently seals the PFO and is indicated in large PFOs > 2.5 cm or if percutaneous closure was previously unsuccessful. Since this patient is asymptomatic and only has a mild, transient defect, surgery is not indicated. In addition, the risks associated with surgery are greater than that of complications of PFO (e.g., paradoxical embolism) occurring.

Follow-up with serial echocardiography may be indicated for some patients with atrial septal defects to monitor defect size and evaluate shunting. However, for patients with PFO, given the high likelihood of spontaneous closure during childhood and adolescence and the low likelihood of complications, monitoring with serial echocardiography does not have any benefit according to the currently available evidence.

question_text: A previously healthy 10-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for the evaluation of one episode of vomiting and severe headache since this morning. His mother says he also had difficulty getting dressed on his own. He has not had any trauma. The patient appears nervous. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 185/125 mm Hg. He is confused and oriented only to person. Ophthalmic examination shows bilateral optic disc swelling. There is an abdominal bruit that is best heard at the right costovertebral angle. A complete blood count is within normal limits. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 185/125 mm Hg. He is confused and oriented only to person. Ophthalmic examination shows bilateral optic disc swelling. There is an abdominal bruit that is best heard at the right costovertebral angle. A complete blood count is within normal limits. Which of the following is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
hint: In a young patient with a hypertensive emergency (blood pressure 185/125 mm Hg, papilledema, severe headache, confusion, and vomiting) and an abdominal bruit on examination that is best heard at the right costovertebral angle, fibromuscular dysplasia (FMD) should be suspected.
learning_objective: Recognize fibromuscular dysplasia in a hypertensive emergency, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why: Echocardiography with doppler is used to confirm coarctation of the aorta. Although, coarctation of the aorta can also lead to hypertension in children, other symptoms such as hypotension and claudication of the lower extremities or a continuous murmur below the left clavicula and between the shoulder blades are typically present. An abdominal bruit as in this boy, however, would not be expected.

An oral sodium loading test is used to confirm primary hyperaldosteronism. Although primary hyperaldosteronism is a common cause of secondary hypertension in young patients, symptoms of hypokalemia such as fatigue or muscle weakness are also typically present. Additionally, primary hyperaldosteronism would not explain this patient's abdominal bruit.

CT angiography is a noninvasive imaging method that has high accuracy in confirming the diagnosis of fibromuscular dysplasia. Imaging would typically show a single or multiple stenoses of the renal arteries. Other imaging methods that can be used to diagnose FMD are duplex ultrasonography and magnetic resonance angiography. The choice of method depends mostly on expertise and availability at individual institutions. After this patient's blood pressure has been adequately controlled and the diagnosis has been confirmed, the renal artery stenosis should be treated with percutaneous transluminal angioplasty.

Serum IGF-I levels are used in the evaluation of acromegaly. Although acromegaly can also cause secondary hypertension, it usually occurs in adults and is associated with other symptoms such as a large skull, coarsened features, and widened hands, fingers, and feet. Additionally, it would not explain this patient's abdominal bruit on examination.

Serum PTH levels are used in the diagnostic evaluation of hyperparathyroidism. Primary hyperparathyroidism can also lead to hypertension due to progressive calcification of the arteries and heart muscle. However, it is typically associated with other findings such as nephrolithiasis, constipation, gastric ulcers, psychological symptoms (e.g., depression, fatigue), and/or bone, muscle, and joint pain. Additionally, primary hyperparathyroidism would not cause this patient's abdominal bruit.

A high-dose dexamethasone suppression test is used to confirm Cushing syndrome. While Cushing syndrome is also a common cause of secondary hypertension, it is usually accompanied by other symptoms such as obesity, hirsutism, and easily bruisable skin with stretch marks. Additionally, it would not explain this patient's abdominal bruit on examination.

Serum 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels are used to screen for congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). Although CAH can also cause secondary hypertension, it is often associated with precocious puberty and electrolyte abnormalities and would not explain this patient's abdominal bruit. Additionally, all newborns in the US are screened for CAH, so that a delayed diagnosis at age 10 would be unlikely.

Testing for urine catecholamines is used to confirm the diagnosis of neuroblastoma. Although neuroblastoma can also manifest with hypertension, nausea, and headaches, it typically also causes constitutional symptoms, such as failure to thrive, weight loss, and fever. In the majority of cases the tumor is located in the abdomen, palpable as an irregular abdominal mass and accompanied by abdominal pain and distention. An abdominal bruit on examination would not be expected. In addition, the tumor is more common in young children (1–2 years of age) and would be exceedingly rare in 10-year-old.
