question_text: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department 3 hours after the sudden onset of colicky abdominal pain and vomiting. She also has nonpruritic redness and swelling of the face and lips. Her symptoms began following a tooth extraction earlier this morning. She had a similar episode of facial swelling after a bicycle accident 1 year ago, which resolved within 48 hours without treatment. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows nontender facial edema, erythema of the oral mucosa, and an enlarged tongue. The abdomen is soft and there is tenderness to palpation over the lower quadrants. An abdominal ultrasound shows segmental thickening of the intestinal wall. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department 3 hours after the sudden onset of colicky abdominal pain and vomiting. She also has nonpruritic redness and swelling of the face and lips. Her symptoms began following a tooth extraction earlier this morning. She had a similar episode of facial swelling after a bicycle accident 1 year ago, which resolved within 48 hours without treatment. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows nontender facial edema, erythema of the oral mucosa, and an enlarged tongue. The abdomen is soft and there is tenderness to palpation over the lower quadrants. An abdominal ultrasound shows segmental thickening of the intestinal wall. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
hint: This patient presents with acute-onset abdominal pain and widespread mucocutaneous edema following a dental procedure. This is suggestive of hereditary angioedema (HAE).
learning_objective: Recognize hereditary angioedema, and recall its underlying cause.

answers.explanation_why: A rare but potentially fatal complication of angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors is bradykinin-mediated angioedema. Gastrointestinal complaints and facial swelling without hives and pruritus are typical symptoms of this type of angioedema. However, ACE inhibitor-induced angioedema is more commonly observed in older patients taking the medication. This child has no history of exposure to ACE inhibitors.

C1 inhibitor deficiency is the underlying cause of HAE. A deficiency or dysfunction of C1 inhibitor results in elevated levels of bradykinin, which is a strong vasodilator. HAE is characterized by recurrent episodes of swelling without hives or pruritus that primarily affects the skin and mucosa of the gastrointestinal and upper respiratory tracts. The most common triggers are stress and trauma, especially from dental procedures. The episodes are usually self-limited and resolve within 2–4 days. HAE is an autosomal dominant disorder, however, about 25% of cases are due to spontaneous mutations.

images.title: Bradykinin-mediated angioedema
images.description: Bradykinin-mediated angioedema is triggered by increased levels of the proinflammatory vasodilator bradykinin, which can build up via several different mechanisms.Top left: The rare hereditary angioedema (HAE) type III (normal levels and function of C1-INH) can be caused by several different gene mutations; illustrated here is a mutation resulting in increased Factor XII activity, which leads to increased bradykinin generation.Center left: In HAE type I (low levels of normal C1-INH), HAE type II (normal or high levels of dysfunctional C1-INHI), and acquired angioedema (acquired low levels of C1-INH), the normal inhibitory function of C1-INH on the kallikrein-kinin system is reduced, resulting in increased bradykinin generation.Bottom left: In ACE inhibitor-induced angioedema, reduced bradykinin breakdown due to inhibition of ACE results in the build-up of bradykinin.C1-INH: C1 inhibitor; ACE: angiotensin-converting enzyme; HMWK: high-molecular-weight kininogen; HAE: hereditary angioedema

answers.explanation_why: Type 2 hypersensitivity reactions (HSRs) result in autoantibody-mediated tissue damage, which is the underlying mechanism of various autoimmune conditions. Acute type 2 HSRs may occur following exposure to drugs or transfusion of blood products. Examples of type 2 HSRs with a gradual onset include pernicious anemia, rheumatic fever, and myasthenia gravis. Angioedema is not associated with type 2 HSRs.

Pseudoallergic reactions can occur secondary to exposure to NSAIDs, which inhibit prostaglandin and result in overproduction of proinflammatory leukotriene. This provokes angioedema with hives and pruritus, which is not consistent with this patient's symptoms. Also, gastrointestinal tract involvement would not be expected. Reactions due to NSAID exposure, for which there is no evidence in this patient, most commonly occur in individuals with preexisting conditions such as asthma, rhinosinusitis, and chronic urticaria.

A T-cell mediated immune reaction is seen in type 4 hypersensitivity reactions. This is classically a delayed response that takes several days to develop, unlike this patient's acute presentation. Examples of T-cell mediated immune reactions include drug reactions, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, graft-versus-host reaction, and multiple sclerosis.

Immediate allergic reactions (type 1 hypersensitivity reaction) result in mast cell activation, which can cause mast cell-mediated angioedema. Typical triggers include drugs (most commonly NSAIDs) and other allergens, such as food, antibiotics, or latex. While the patient may have been exposed to such triggers in the context of the dental procedure, mast cell-mediated angioedema typically presents much faster (within 30 minutes to 2 hours after exposure to the allergen) with faciolabial swelling as well as hives and prominent pruritus.

question_text: Three days after delivery of a male newborn, a 36-year-old gravida 1, para 1 woman has fever and pain in her left leg. Pregnancy was complicated by premature rupture of membranes; the child was delivered at 35 weeks' gestation by lower segment transverse cesarean section because of a nonreassuring fetal heart rate. The patient has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 5 years and continued to smoke during her pregnancy. Her temperature is 38.9°C (102.0°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. Examination shows an edematous, erythematous, and warm left leg. Passive dorsiflexion of the left foot elicits pain in the calf. The peripheral pulses are palpated bilaterally. The uterus is nontender and palpated at the umbilicus. Ultrasonography of the left leg shows an incompressible left popliteal vein. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
content_preview: Three days after delivery of a male newborn, a 36-year-old gravida 1, para 1 woman has fever and pain in her left leg. Pregnancy was complicated by premature rupture of membranes; the child was delivered at 35 weeks' gestation by lower segment transverse cesarean section because of a nonreassuring fetal heart rate. The patient has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 5 years and continued to smoke during her pregnancy. Her temperature is 38.9°C (102.0°F), pulse is 110/min, and blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. Examination shows an edematous, erythematous, and warm left leg. Passive dorsiflexion of the left foot elicits pain in the calf. The peripheral pulses are palpated bilaterally. The uterus is nontender and palpated at the umbilicus. Ultrasonography of the left leg shows an incompressible left popliteal vein. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
hint: This patient's D-dimer values would be elevated but are no longer needed as part of the workup because her ultrasonography confirms the diagnosis. Other ultrasonography findings include a visible hyperechoic mass and reduced/absent flow in Doppler imaging.
learning_objective: Recognize postpartum deep venous thrombosis, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why: This patient presents with fever, leg pain, warmth, edema, and erythema, as well as a positive Homans sign, 3 days after delivery, which suggests a diagnosis of postpartum deep venous thrombosis (DVT). Compression ultrasonography confirms the diagnosis. Pregnancy is a hypercoagulable state; the risk of venous thromboembolisms reaches its peak in the first 6 weeks postpartum, when hypercoagulability is accompanied by endothelial injury (e.g., due to surgical delivery) and possibly venous stasis (e.g., due to immobilization after delivery). Smoking also increases the risk of DVT, as does delivery via cesarean section, maternal age > 35 years, and preterm delivery. LMWH, administered subcutaneously, is the initial treatment of choice because of its immediate antithrombotic effect and safety during breastfeeding. If no significant bleeding has occurred, it can safely be started 12 hours after cesarean section.

Surgical fasciotomy is the treatment of choice to relieve the pressure, and thus, restore perfusion in patients with compartment syndrome. Acute compartment syndrome is a possible cause of postpartum limb pain, as it can be triggered by intrapartum hypotension (e.g., due to blood loss) or after the application of vasoconstrictive therapeutic agents (e.g., oxytocin to induce labor). In the early stages, it can manifest with swelling, paresthesia, and pain that is exacerbated by passive stretching or extension of the muscles; distal pulses are often initially palpable and do not rule out the diagnosis. However, physical examination typically shows very tight, “wood-like” muscles. This patient's examination findings suggest deep venous thrombosis rather than compartment syndrome.

Embolectomy is not indicated in the treatment of deep venous thrombosis (DVT) but may be considered for patients with acute limb ischemia (ALI). Although ALI can manifest with acute pain, it is unlikely to cause significant swelling, redness, and a positive Homan sign. Instead, patients with ALI typically have a source of arterial embolus (e.g., atrial fibrillation, myocardial infarction) and present with a cool limb, decreased peripheral pulses, and possibly sensory symptoms.

Urokinase is a thrombolytic agent that is indicated in the treatment of pulmonary embolism, phlegmasia cerulea dolens, massive ileofemoral deep vein thrombosis (DVT), hemodynamic instability, and in patients who have failed anticoagulation. Although this patient has a DVT, it is located in the popliteal vein rather than the proximal ileofemoral vein, which indicates that another step is more appropriate. Additionally, this patient's recent surgery (cesarean section) is an absolute contraindication to thrombolytic therapy.

Dicloxacillin is indicated in mild cases of cellulitis, which can manifest with leg pain, erythematous skin, pasty swelling, and fever. A positive Homan sign, however, is not typical of this condition. Furthermore, the lack of a possible portal of entry (e.g., minor skin injury) makes this diagnosis less likely. Though cellulitis of the breast is a possible complication of breastfeeding that most commonly occurs within the first 4 weeks after delivery, cellulitis of a limb is not a typical complication of the postpartum period.

Warfarin (a vitamin K antagonist) is commonly prescribed for oral anticoagulation in patients with deep venous thrombosis (DVT); however, it is not indicated as initial monotherapy in patients with acute DVT. Warfarin monotherapy induces a transient hypercoagulable state in the first few days of therapy as it decreases anticoagulant proteins C and S because of their shorter half-life (6–10h) before reducing the coagulant factors II, VII, IX, and X (half-life of 2–4 days). To not worsen the patient's DVT and/or cause warfarin-induced skin necrosis, the initial therapy must contain another drug that has an immediate antithrombotic effect, before introducing an oral anticoagulation (bridging therapy).

Graduated compression stockings are indicated in the management of lymphedema since the compression of these tight-fitting stockings improve lymphatic drainage and decrease edema. This patient's physical examination findings (e.g., fever, leg swelling, erythema, warmth) shortly after surgical delivery suggest postpartum deep vein thrombosis (DVT) rather than lymphedema. In this case, graduated compression stockings can be used to decrease pain and edema of acute DVT, but they would not prevent clot lysis or propagation.

question_text: A 38-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 32 weeks' gestation comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of dyspnea and left-sided chest pain that is worse when she breathes deeply. One week ago, she returned from a trip to Chile, where she had a 3-day episode of flu-like symptoms that resolved without treatment. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child were uncomplicated. She has no history of serious illness. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 118/min, respirations are 28/min and slightly labored, and blood pressure is 110/76 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. Examination shows jugular venous distention and bilateral pitting edema below the knees that is worse on the left side. Breath sounds are decreased over the left lung base. The uterus is consistent in size with a 32-week gestation. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 38-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 32 weeks' gestation comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of dyspnea and left-sided chest pain that is worse when she breathes deeply. One week ago, she returned from a trip to Chile, where she had a 3-day episode of flu-like symptoms that resolved without treatment. Pregnancy and delivery of her first child were uncomplicated. She has no history of serious illness. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), pulse is 118/min, respirations are 28/min and slightly labored, and blood pressure is 110/76 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. Examination shows jugular venous distention and bilateral pitting edema below the knees that is worse on the left side. Breath sounds are decreased over the left lung base. The uterus is consistent in size with a 32-week gestation. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: Left-sided pleuritic pain with decreased breath sounds over the left lower lung field indicate left-sided pleuritis and pleural effusion. Pleuritis with acute onset of dyspnea, tachypnea, tachycardia, hypoxemia, and features of right ventricular overload (jugular venous distention, bilateral pedal edema) suggests pulmonary embolism (PE).
learning_objective: Recognize pulmonary embolism, and recall its diagnostic findings.

answers.content: Decreased left ventricular ejection fraction on echocardiography
answers.explanation_why:
A decrease in the left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) can be seen with impaired left ventricular (LV) contractility or an increase in afterload. Pulmonary embolism may result in a decrease in cardiac output but the LVEF is usually normal because LV systolic function and LV contractility remain unaffected. Instead, a dilated right ventricle with a decreased right ventricular ejection fraction would be more typical for patients with severe PE.

The physiological increase in cardiac output during pregnancy and/or maternal comorbidities such as anemia and hyperthyroidism can place the myocardium under hypoxic stress. This stress can worsen an underlying heart disease (e.g., arrhythmias, coronary artery disease, rheumatic aortic stenosis) and cause heart failure with decreased LVEF. Other causes of a decreased LVEF that are unique to pregnancy include severe gestational hypertension and peripartum cardiomyopathy.

answers.content: Decreased fibrinogen levels on serum studies
answers.explanation_why: Decreased fibrinogen levels would be seen in disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). DIC, which may occur during pregnancy as a result of amniotic fluid embolism or severe preeclampsia (HELLP syndrome) can result in dyspnea, chest pain, tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypoxemia. Amniotic fluid embolism to the lungs can manifest with pleuritis and preeclampsia with pedal edema. However, patients with DIC would usually present with features of shock (e.g., cold clammy extremities, hypotension, altered mental status) and/or bleeding manifestations. Moreover, there is no history of gestational hypertension or a risk factor for amniotic fluid embolism in this patient (e.g., uterine rupture, a recent amniocentesis).

answers.content: Depression of the PR segment on ECG
answers.explanation_why: Depression of the PR segment on ECG is seen in acute viral pericarditis and atrial myocardial infarction. Acute pericarditis can manifest with tachycardia, dyspnea, and chest pain that worsens with inspiration. However, other features such as fever and a pericardial friction rub would be present. An acute myocardial infarction (MI) can result in chest pain but the chest pain would usually be continuous without exacerbation during inspiration. Also, patients with an atrial MI usually have bradycardia due to heart blocks, or supraventricular tachyarrhythmias such as atrial fibrillation.

answers.content: Decreased myocardial perfusion on cardiac PET scan
answers.explanation_why: Decreased myocardial perfusion is seen in patients with myocardial infarction (MI). An acute MI can manifest with chest pain, dyspnea, tachycardia, tachypnea, and hypoxemia. Also, congestive heart failure (CHF) as a result of MI would result in pedal edema, jugular venous distention, and possibly pleural effusion. The chest pain in acute MI is, however, described as continuous with radiation to the jaw or left arm. An increase in pain with inspiration along with evidence of pleural effusion (decreased breath sounds) indicates a pleuritic cause for chest pain. Moreover, in patients with CHF, peripheral edema would be symmetrical, pleural effusions would occur bilaterally (or more commonly in the right side if unilateral), and basal crepitations would be expected.

answers.content: Consolidation of the left lung base on chest x-ray
answers.explanation_why:
Consolidation of the left lung base is seen in patients with left lower lobe pneumonia, which can manifest with dyspnea, tachycardia, and tachypnea. Although this patient's decreased breath sounds and pleuritic chest pain could be due to concomitant parapneumonic effusion, pneumonia would not result in asymmetrical peripheral edema and jugular venous distention. Also, patients with pneumonia typically present with a cough and systemic symptoms such as fever and malaise.

A wedge-shaped opacification of the lung field (Hampton hump), which can be mistaken for lung consolidation, may occur in patients with PE as a result of pulmonary infarction.

A noncompressible venous segment on ultrasonography is a sign of venous thrombosis. Pulmonary embolism is most commonly caused by a blood thrombus that arises from the deep venous system of the legs or pelvis (deep venous thrombosis) and embolizes to the lungs. DVT of the left femoral vein also explains this patient's asymmetrical peripheral edema. Both pregnancy and immobilization (e.g., due to long-distance travel) are risk factors for venous thromboembolism.

images.title: Pulmonary embolism: thrombus formation and embolization
images.description: Pulmonary emboli typically arise from thrombosed deep veins of the calf and travel toward the lungs through the inferior vena cava, right atrium, right ventricle, and pulmonary arteries. An embolus can lodge anywhere along its course toward the lungs or within the pulmonary arterioles, depending on its size. Common sites of embolism include the bifurcation of the pulmonary arteries (saddle thrombus), within the right and/or left pulmonary artery, and within the lobar, segmental, or subsegmental branch of the pulmonary arteries. The degree of hemodynamic compromise is proportional to the size of the vessel occluded by the pulmonary embolism.

answers.content: Protein dipstick test of 2+ on urinalysis
answers.explanation_why: Proteinuria during pregnancy would be seen in preeclampsia. Severe preeclampsia can manifest with dyspnea (due to pulmonary edema) and peripheral edema. However, peripheral edema in preeclampsia would typically be symmetrical, and bilateral pulmonary crepitations would be expected instead of a unilateral decrease in breath sounds. The absence of gestational hypertension also suggests a diagnosis other than preeclampsia.

question_text:
A 72-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressively worsening shortness of breath. The symptoms most commonly occur when lying flat at night. He also reports shortness of breath when walking up the two flights of stairs to his apartment. He reports no chest pain. Medical history is remarkable for myocardial infarction 2 years ago. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. He does not exercise. His medications include aspirin, lisinopril, bisoprolol, and atorvastatin. Pulse is 85/min and blood pressure is 124/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Examination shows an extra heart sound during early diastole on auscultation. Faint crackles are heard at both lung bases. There is 1+ ankle edema bilaterally. Cardiac ultrasonography shows a left ventricular ejection fraction of 0.35. Which of the following hemodynamic changes are most likely present in this patient?

Cardiac output (CO)
Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP)
Left ventricular end-diastolic volume (LVEDV)
Total peripheral resistance (TPR)

A
Decreased
decreased
decreased
decreased

B
Decreased
unchanged
decreased
increased

C
Decreased
decreased
decreased
increased

D
Decreased
increased
increased
increased

E
Increased
decreased
decreased
decreased
content_preview: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician because of progressively worsening shortness of breath. The symptoms most commonly occur when lying flat at night. He also reports shortness of breath when walking up the two flights of stairs to his apartment. He reports no chest pain. Medical history is remarkable for myocardial infarction 2 years ago. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. He does not exercise. His medications include aspirin, lisinopril, bisoprolol, and atorvastatin. Pulse is 85/min and blood pressure is 124/70 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Examination shows an extra heart sound during early diastole on auscultation. Faint crackles are heard at both lung bases. There is 1+ ankle edema bilaterally. Cardiac ultrasonography shows a left ventricular ejection fraction of 0.35. Which of the following hemodynamic changes are most likely present in this patient? Cardiac output (CO) Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (PCWP) Left ventricular end-diastolic volume (LVEDV) Total peripheral resistance (TPR) A Decreased decreased decreased decreased B Decreased unchanged decreased increased C Decreased decreased decreased increased D Decreased increased increased increased E Increased decreased decreased decreased
hint: Features of pulmonary congestion (exertional dyspnea, orthopnea, bibasilar crackles) and an S_3 gallop along with a history of myocardial infarction suggest congestive heart failure (CHF) most likely due to ischemic heart disease. A decreased left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) indicates systolic dysfunction.
learning_objective: Recognize congestive heart failure, and recall its hemodynamic findings.

answers.explanation_why: In systolic dysfunction, poor contractility leads to decreased stroke volume and cardiac output. In response to decreased cardiac output, there is compensatory activation of the RAAS and sympathetic nervous system, resulting in increased TPR. In addition, incomplete ventricular emptying during systole results in left ventricular volume overload, which results in increased LVEDV. Increased LVEDV and poor forward flow cause increased left ventricular pressure, which is transmitted to the left atrium, resulting in increased PCWP.

These parameters suggest hypovolemic shock. Decreased circulating blood volume leads to decreased venous return, resulting in reduced blood flow to the left ventricle, which causes decreased LVEDV and low PCWP. Decreased CO and effective circulating volume activate the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system and sympathetic nervous system, resulting in increased TPR.

These parameters can be found in the early stages of septic shock. Inflammatory mediators lead to systemic vasodilation and decreased TPR. This results in decreased effective circulating volume, which causes decreased venous return. With decreased venous return, there is decreased LVEDV and decreased PCWP. In the early stages of sepsis, the heart can become hyperdynamic, resulting in increased CO.

These parameters suggest late-stage untreated septic shock. Elevated inflammatory mediators lead to systemic vasodilation and decreased TPR. This results in decreased effective circulating volume, which causes decreased venous return. Decreased venous return leads to decreased LVEDV and decreased PCWP. Eventually, the heart can no longer compensate and CO begins to fall.

These parameters can be found in obstructive causes of shock such as massive pulmonary embolism or pericardial tamponade. Venous return remains the same but cannot be transmitted through the heart chambers effectively. This results in increased central venous pressure but decreased LVEDV and CO. PCWP may be decreased or unchanged depending on the extent of obstruction.

question_text: A 33-year-old man comes to the physician because of gradually worsening bilateral foot pain for the past 2 months. The pain used to only occur after long walks and subside with rest. For the past week, the pain has been continuous and associated with burning sensations. He has also had transient painful nodules along the course of the leg veins for 4 months that resolve spontaneously. The patient is wearing an ankle brace for support because of a sprained left ankle that occurred 3 months ago. His mother was diagnosed with protein C deficiency as a teenager. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 15 years and does not drink alcohol. Vitals signs are within normal limits. Examination shows ulcers on the distal portion of his left great, second, and fifth toes. The feet are cool. Pedal pulses are barely palpable. Ankle-brachial pressure index is 0.3 in the left leg and 0.5 in the right leg. Which of the following interventions is most likely to decrease the risk of amputation in this patient?
content_preview: A 33-year-old man comes to the physician because of gradually worsening bilateral foot pain for the past 2 months. The pain used to only occur after long walks and subside with rest. For the past week, the pain has been continuous and associated with burning sensations. He has also had transient painful nodules along the course of the leg veins for 4 months that resolve spontaneously. The patient is wearing an ankle brace for support because of a sprained left ankle that occurred 3 months ago. His mother was diagnosed with protein C deficiency as a teenager. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 15 years and does not drink alcohol. Vitals signs are within normal limits. Examination shows ulcers on the distal portion of his left great, second, and fifth toes. The feet are cool. Pedal pulses are barely palpable. Ankle-brachial pressure index is 0.3 in the left leg and 0.5 in the right leg. Which of the following interventions is most likely to decrease the risk of amputation in this patient?
hint: Claudication pain, features of chronic limb-threatening ischemia (rest pain for > 2 weeks, decreased peripheral pulses, cold extremities, digital ulcers, very low ankle-brachial pressure index), and history of migratory superficial thrombophlebitis (transient, painful nodules along the course of the veins) in a young, male patient indicate thromboangiitis obliterans (TAO).
learning_objective: Recognize thromboangiitis obliterans, and choose the primary intervention to decrease the risk of amputation.

answers.explanation_why: In patients with peripheral arterial disease, the use of compression stockings is contraindicated if the ankle-brachial index is < 0.6 because it can exacerbate lower limb ischemia. Instead, they are indicated in chronic venous insufficiency (CVI), which can manifest with pain in the lower limb and lower limb ulcers. However, CVI causes a “dragging” pain that is worsened by prolonged standing and relieved by walking or lying down with the lower limbs elevated, and venous ulcers typically occur over the shin and medial malleolus. Moreover, the skin surrounding the ulcers would be hyperpigmented and/or thickened, and a history of lower limb edema and/or varicose veins would be present. Also, CVI typically occurs in elderly patients.

Chronic mechanical, extrinsic blood flow obstruction can cause limb ischemia or even compartment syndrome, which would manifest with progressively worsening pain despite immobilization, sensory deficits, as well as out-of-proportion pain on passive movement in the affected limb. This patient has clinical signs of vasculitis, and painful legs, bilaterally.

Peripheral artery bypass surgery or other revascularization procedures (e.g. angioplasty) usually cannot be performed in TAO because TAO affects distal small and medium-sized arteries, which are not amenable to revascularization procedures.

Smoking is the single most important risk factor for TAO. The exact mechanism by which smoking causes TAO is unknown, but direct endothelial cell toxicity from the components of tobacco is presumed to play a role. Complete cessation of smoking and other tobacco products is, therefore, the most important therapeutic measure to prevent gangrene and amputation.

In patients with chronic limb-threatening ischemia, anticoagulation with unfractionated heparin or low molecular weight heparin (e.g., enoxaparin) is not useful. Anticoagulation should instead be used in a patient with acute limb ischemia (ALI), which can manifest similarly with painful cold limbs bilaterally if a saddle thrombus occurs. A family history of protein C deficiency is also a risk factor for thrombosis. However, with ALI, the onset of symptoms would be acute (as the name suggests!), the pedal pulses would be absent rather than decreased, and paralysis of the lower limbs would be expected. Moreover, patients with protein C deficiency would typically present with venous rather than arterial thrombosis.

Steroid therapy, e.g., with prednisolone, is commonly indicated to treat vasculitides with systemic features such as respiratory symptoms (e.g. Churg-Strauss, granulomatosis with polyangiitis) or renal involvement (e.g. polyarteritis nodosa, microscopic polyangiitis). It is not useful in the treatment of TAO where the disease process is primarily confined to the distal extremities. This patient lacks symptoms of systemic vasculitis and is not a candidate for steroid therapy.
Iloprost therapy can help relieve the limb pain associated with TAO. However, a different measure is more important to prevent amputation of the limb.

Statins are a crucial component in medical therapy for patients with atherosclerotic peripheral artery disease (PAD), which can manifest similarly with limb claudication, decreased pulses, digital ulcers, and a low ABI. However, atherosclerotic PAD typically occurs in elderly patients, and superficial thrombophlebitis is not a feature of atherosclerotic PAD. Progression of TAO cannot be prevented by statins because it is not an atherosclerotic process.

To prevent secondary Raynaud phenomenon, which commonly occurs in patients with TAO, protection of fingers and toes from cold temperatures is recommended. This intervention, however, only helps reduce the symptoms associated with painful vasospasms and does not address the underlying cause.

question_text: A 54-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of dull, persistent pain and swelling of her right leg. The pain is worse at the end of the day and is relieved by walking or elevating her feet. Two years ago, she developed acute deep vein thrombosis in her right calf after a long flight, which was treated with anticoagulants for 6 months. Physical examination shows 2+ pitting edema of her right leg. The skin around the right ankle shows a reddish-brown discoloration and multiple telangiectasias. She has dilated varicose veins in the right leg. Which of the following is most likely to establish the diagnosis?
content_preview: A 54-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of dull, persistent pain and swelling of her right leg. The pain is worse at the end of the day and is relieved by walking or elevating her feet. Two years ago, she developed acute deep vein thrombosis in her right calf after a long flight, which was treated with anticoagulants for 6 months. Physical examination shows 2+ pitting edema of her right leg. The skin around the right ankle shows a reddish-brown discoloration and multiple telangiectasias. She has dilated varicose veins in the right leg. Which of the following is most likely to establish the diagnosis?
hint: This patient's unilateral chronic dull pain, edema, dilated veins in the lower extremity, and history of deep venous thrombosis (DVT) suggest chronic venous insufficiency (CVI).
learning_objective: Recognize chronic venous insufficiency, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why: Computed tomography scan with contrast of the lower extremities is used to evaluate patients for deep infections (e.g., abscesses), malignancy, or injury in the lower extremities. It is not used to evaluate for CVI.

Nerve conduction studies are used to evaluate the function of the peripheral nervous system. They are particularly critical for diagnosing polyneuropathies (e.g., due to chronic diabetes mellitus). Although polyneuropathy can manifest with asymmetric or unilateral pain, which is seen in this patient, the pain usually takes the form of a buzzing or tingling sensation, not a dull ache. Moreover, polyneuropathy would not cause the edema and telangiectasias seen in this patient.

The D-dimer assay is a nonspecific test that is indicated for patients with a low pretest probability of acute DVT to rule out an acute thrombotic event. The test has a high negative predictive value (> 95%); therefore, a negative test result effectively rules out the presence of a DVT or a pulmonary embolism.

The ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI) is used to screen for peripheral arterial disease (PAD) in patients who present with lower limb pain that suggests claudication pain (i.e., pain on walking that is relieved with rest). This patient's pain improves with walking, making PAD an unlikely cause of her symptoms. Her symptoms are consistent with CVI, which cannot be evaluated with ABPI.

Duplex ultrasonography (compression ultrasonography) is the first-line investigation in patients with features suggestive of CVI, as seen here. Evidence of venous reflux on duplex ultrasonography confirms the diagnosis of CVI. Duplex ultrasonography can help determine the course of treatment by identifying which valves are incompetent and assessing the patency of the previously thrombosed deep veins.

question_text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of increasing calf cramping in both legs when walking for the past year. Symptoms are especially severe when walking on an incline. He has been exercising on a treadmill 4 times a week; he walks until the pain starts and then continues after a short break. He has a history of hypertension controlled with enalapril. He smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 35 years but quit 5 months ago. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 132/78 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The calves and feet are pale. Femoral pulses can be palpated bilaterally; pedal pulses are absent. His ankle-brachial index is 0.6. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of increasing calf cramping in both legs when walking for the past year. Symptoms are especially severe when walking on an incline. He has been exercising on a treadmill 4 times a week; he walks until the pain starts and then continues after a short break. He has a history of hypertension controlled with enalapril. He smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 35 years but quit 5 months ago. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 132/78 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The calves and feet are pale. Femoral pulses can be palpated bilaterally; pedal pulses are absent. His ankle-brachial index is 0.6. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient presents with increasing calf cramping on exertion, a history of smoking and hypertension, pale lower extremities, and absent pedal pulses, the combination of which suggests peripheral arterial disease (PAD).
learning_objective: Recognize peripheral arterial disease, and choose the appropriate pharmacotherapy.

answers.explanation_why:
Intensive treatment and optimization of risk factors for atherosclerotic disease improve outcomes in PAD and prevent ischemic events. Statins help to control hyperlipidemia and should be offered to all patients with PAD. Antiplatelet therapy (e.g., with clopidogrel) is indicated in all symptomatic patients. Other cardiovascular risk factors that require long-term treatment are hypertension (controlled with enalapril in this patient) and hyperglycemia.

A thorough workup of this patient is warranted, as PAD often coexists with coronary artery disease, stroke, atrial fibrillation, and renal disease.

During operative vascular reconstruction (e.g., bypass surgery, endarterectomy), an autologous vein (e.g., great saphenous vein) is used to bypass the stenosis and restore blood flow in the ischemic limb. This treatment option is indicated in advanced disease if conservative and pharmacological treatment has failed or if chronic limb-threatening ischemia (e.g., resting pain, ulcer, gangrene) is present.

Percutaneous transluminal angioplasty is indicated in advanced PAD if conservative and pharmacological treatment has failed or if chronic limb-threatening ischemia (e.g., resting pain, ulcer, gangrene) is present.

Vancomycin and piperacillin is the treatment of choice for severe soft tissue infection (e.g., cellulitis). This patient does not have erythematous skin lesions, purulent exudate, or systemic signs of infection such as fevers, chills, or confusion.

Rest and orthotic braces are the treatment of choice for insertional tendinopathy. While tendinopathy is characterized by pain, especially on movement, this condition would not manifest with pallor, pulselessness, and decreased ankle-brachial index.

question_text: A previously healthy 64-year-old man comes to the physician 3 days after noticing a lump in his right groin while he was bathing. He has no history of trauma to the region. He has hypercholesterolemia and hypertension treated with atorvastatin and labetalol. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 35 years. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a 4-cm (1.6-in), nontender, pulsatile mass with a palpable thrill at the right midinguinal point. On auscultation, a harsh bruit is heard over the mass. Femoral and pedal pulses are palpable bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A previously healthy 64-year-old man comes to the physician 3 days after noticing a lump in his right groin while he was bathing. He has no history of trauma to the region. He has hypercholesterolemia and hypertension treated with atorvastatin and labetalol. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 35 years. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a 4-cm (1.6-in), nontender, pulsatile mass with a palpable thrill at the right midinguinal point. On auscultation, a harsh bruit is heard over the mass. Femoral and pedal pulses are palpable bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: Duplex ultrasonography is a rapid, noninvasive, and inexpensive tool to diagnose this condition.
learning_objective: Recognize a femoral artery aneurysm.

answers.explanation_why: An inguinal hernia is one of the most common causes of a painless mass in the inguinal region, especially in elderly men. However, an inguinal hernia is not pulsatile and does not have a palpable thrill or a bruit on auscultation. Rather, an inguinal hernia would show an expansile cough impulse, will be doughy/elastic in consistency, and have bowel sounds on auscultation (if the inguinal content is bowel).

A femoral artery pseudoaneurysm may manifest as a painless, pulsatile swelling at the midinguinal point, with a palpable thrill and audible bruit on examination, as in this patient. However, spontaneous pseudoaneurysms are very rare, occurring in patients with underlying vasculitides (e.g., Behcet disease) or connective tissue disorders (e.g., Ehlers-Danlos syndrome). Femoral artery pseudoaneurysms typically follow an iatrogenic intervention on the femoral artery (e.g., cardiac catheterization, femoral ABG, surgery) or trauma (e.g., gunshot wound) to the inguinal region. This patient does not have a preceding history of femoral artery trauma/intervention and has no features of other underlying disorders, making this diagnosis highly unlikely.

Although a femoral hernia may manifest as a painless swelling in the inguinal region, it is not pulsatile and there would be no palpable thrill or audible bruit on examination. A femoral hernia would instead show an expansile cough impulse, will be doughy/elastic in consistency, and have bowel sounds on auscultation (if the hernia content is bowel).

Painless femoral lymphadenopathy that overlies the femoral artery may be seen as a pulsatile mass in the inguinal region. However, there would be no palpable thrill or audible bruit on examination. In addition, this patient has no features to suggest an underlying genital/anal/lower limb infection or malignancy that would cause femoral lymphadenopathy.

answers.content: Arteriovenous fistula of the femoral vessels
answers.explanation_why: An arteriovenous fistula (AVF) of the femoral vessels can manifest with a painless, pulsatile swelling at the midinguinal point with a palpable thrill and an audible bruit. However, spontaneous AVFs are very rare; they typically follow an iatrogenic intervention on the femoral artery (e.g., cardiac catheterization, femoral ABG, surgery) or trauma (e.g., gunshot wound) to the inguinal region, which this patient has no history of. Other typical features of a femoral AVF, such as edema and varicose veins in the affected limb (due to transfer of arterial pressure to the femoral vein) are also absent in this patient.

A femoral abscess manifests as a tender inguinal mass that may be pulsatile if it's overlying the femoral artery; but without a palpable thrill or an audible bruit. Other typical features of a femoral abscess include fever, localized pain over the swelling, and signs of inflammation (erythema, warmth) of the overlying skin. In addition, a femoral abscess typically follows an injury or iatrogenic intervention at the site (e.g., following cardiac catheterization) or could represent a cystic/necrotic/liquified stage of femoral lymphadenitis secondary to tuberculosis or a malignancy (e.g., genital/anal/lower limb squamous cell carcinoma). This patient has no risk factors or features of a femoral abscess.

A saphenous varix may manifest with a painless inguinal swelling with an audible bruit (venous hum) on auscultation. However, a saphenous varix is not pulsatile, making a different diagnosis more likely.

A palpable pulsatile mass in the thigh with a bruit on auscultation is characteristic of an unruptured femoral artery aneurysm. This condition can be asymptomatic or manifest with thigh or groin pain and is often diagnosed incidentally during the workup of other aneurysms or vascular conditions. Risk factors for femoral artery aneurysms include ASCVD risk factors (e.g., hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, smoking).

question_text:
A 71-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well. He goes for a 30-minute walk three times a week and does not experience any shortness of breath or chest or leg pain on exertion. He has not had any weakness, numbness, or vision disturbance. He has diabetes that is well-controlled with insulin injections. He had smoked one pack of cigarettes every day for 40 years but quit 5 years ago. He appears healthy and well-nourished. His temperature is 36.3°C (97.3°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 136/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows normal heart sounds. There are systolic bruits over the neck bilaterally. Physical and neurologic examinations show no other abnormalities. Fasting serum studies show:

Total cholesterol
285 mg/dL

HDL cholesterol
32 mg/dL

LDL cholesterol
205 mg/dL

Triglycerides
240 mg/dL

Glucose
92 mg/dL

Duplex ultrasonography of the carotid arteries shows an 85% stenosis on the left and a 55% stenosis on the right side. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
content_preview: A 71-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine health maintenance examination. He feels well. He goes for a 30-minute walk three times a week and does not experience any shortness of breath or chest or leg pain on exertion. He has not had any weakness, numbness, or vision disturbance. He has diabetes that is well-controlled with insulin injections. He had smoked one pack of cigarettes every day for 40 years but quit 5 years ago. He appears healthy and well-nourished. His temperature is 36.3°C (97.3°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 136/78 mm Hg. Physical examination shows normal heart sounds. There are systolic bruits over the neck bilaterally. Physical and neurologic examinations show no other abnormalities. Fasting serum studies show: Total cholesterol 285 mg/dL HDL cholesterol 32 mg/dL LDL cholesterol 205 mg/dL Triglycerides 240 mg/dL Glucose 92 mg/dL Duplex ultrasonography of the carotid arteries shows an 85% stenosis on the left and a 55% stenosis on the right side. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
hint: When choosing the next step in management, the degree of the stenosis, the patient's age, and the absence of symptoms should be considered.
learning_objective: Recognize significant asymptomatic carotid artery stenosis, and choose the most appropriate treatment.

answers.explanation_why: Aspirin therapy is used to manage carotid stenosis by reducing the risk of cardiovascular events, such as stroke. While this patient should be placed on aspirin therapy or another antiplatelet agent such as clopidogrel, medical therapy alone would not be recommended in a patient with severe carotid stenosis.

Atorvastatin therapy is used to manage carotid stenosis by reducing the risk of cardiovascular events, such as stroke. While this patient should be placed on a long-term statin, medical therapy alone would not be recommended in a patient with severe carotid stenosis.

Carotid endarterectomy (CEA) should be considered in asymptomatic patients with severe carotid stenosis. The 85% stenosis of the left carotid in this otherwise healthy patient warrants recanalization at this time to prevent future morbidity and mortality. In addition, all patients with carotid artery stenosis should receive medical management comprised of statin therapy, antiplatelet drugs (e.g., aspirin or clopidogrel), and treatment of modifiable risk factors for atherosclerosis (e.g., diabetes mellitus, hypertension) via lifestyle modifications (e.g., physical activity, smoking cessation) and medications.
Carvedilol therapy is indicated to control hypertension in patients who have carotid artery stenosis. This patient is normotensive and does not require hypertension medication at this time.
Reassurance is not appropriate for this patient at this time. Studies have shown that the annual risk of stroke in patients with asymptomatic carotid artery stenosis ≥ 50% is 0.5–1%.

Carotid artery stenting can be considered in patients with carotid stenosis who are not appropriate candidates for carotid endarterectomy, such as patients who have comorbidities that increase perioperative mortality. Compared to the treatment of choice, carotid artery stenting is associated with an increased risk of adverse events in patients > 70 years. This otherwise healthy 71-year-old patient should therefore be considered for a different next step in management.

Bilateral carotid endarterectomy (CEA) is not indicated at this time. CEA is indicated for asymptomatic patients with severe carotid stenosis. The right carotid artery is only 55% occluded and can be managed expectantly.

question_text: A 63-year-old woman comes to the physician with a 3-month history of progressively worsening right calf pain. She reports that the pain occurs after walking for about 10 minutes and resolves when she rests. She has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She takes lisinopril and simvastatin daily. She has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 34 years. Her pulse is 78/min and blood pressure is 142/96 mm Hg. Femoral and popliteal pulses are 2+ bilaterally. Left pedal pulses are 1+; right pedal pulses are absent. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Ankle-brachial index (ABI) is 0.65 in the right leg and 0.9 in the left leg. This patient is at greatest risk for developing which of the following?
content_preview: A 63-year-old woman comes to the physician with a 3-month history of progressively worsening right calf pain. She reports that the pain occurs after walking for about 10 minutes and resolves when she rests. She has hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She takes lisinopril and simvastatin daily. She has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 34 years. Her pulse is 78/min and blood pressure is 142/96 mm Hg. Femoral and popliteal pulses are 2+ bilaterally. Left pedal pulses are 1+; right pedal pulses are absent. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Ankle-brachial index (ABI) is 0.65 in the right leg and 0.9 in the left leg. This patient is at greatest risk for developing which of the following?
hint: This patient presents with intermittent claudication (pain on exertion that is relieved on rest) of her right calf with diminished pedal pulses and decreased ABI (normal range: 1–1.3). These features are characteristic of peripheral arterial disease (PAD). Her risk factors include hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and smoking.
learning_objective: Recognize peripheral arterial disease (PAD), and recall its cardiovascular complications.

answers.content: Abdominal aortic aneurysm requiring open surgical repair
answers.explanation_why: Lower extremity PAD is associated with an increased risk of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA), as both diseases have a similar pathogenesis involving systemic atherosclerosis and shared risk factors (e.g., smoking, hypertension, etc). However, she is at even higher risk for development of a different complication.

Lymphedema refers to abnormal accumulation of fluid in the interstitium from lymphatic system dysfunction (e.g, due to injury, infection, congenital abnormality, following surgery or radiation, etc.). Although this condition may initially manifest similarly, this patient's exertional pain and lack of edema effectively rule out this diagnosis. Additionally, the presence of PAD is not associated with an increased risk of lymphedema.

Limb amputation is used as a last resort in patients with chronic limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI) if other treatment options (e.g., endovascular or surgical revascularization) have proven unsuccessful or if patients have limited life expectancy, deep space infections, or wet gangrene. Although the risk of CLTI requiring amputation is significantly higher in patients with diabetes, only a minority of patients with PAD will require limb amputation and this patient is at greater risk for a different condition.

Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is a manifestation of venous thromboembolism, and should always be considered as a differential diagnosis in patients with asymmetric lower extremity pain. Common risk factors for DVT include immobility, malignancy, obesity, and increased age. While atherosclerosis (including PAD) and DVT share some risk factors (e.g., smoking), there is no clear association between PAD and risk of DVT.

The presence of PAD suggests systemic atherosclerosis and is associated with an increased risk of acute mesenteric ischemia (AMI). However, the majority of cases of AMI arise from intracardiac emboli (i.e., mural thrombi, valvular disorders, arrhythmias), rather than thrombosis from atherosclerotic disease. The risk of another complication is higher.

PAD is a very strong predictor of coexisting coronary artery disease, as both diseases have a similar pathogenesis (atherosclerosis) and shared risk factors (e.g., smoking, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes). Compared to healthy individuals, patients with PAD are at significantly increased risk for myocardial infarction and stroke. Evaluation and management of underlying coronary artery disease is recommended for patients with PAD, and risk factors should be addressed.

First-line therapy of lower extremity PAD is management of cardiovascular risk factors (e.g., smoking, diabetes, hypertension) and exercise (walking) therapy.

question_text: A 72-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of severe, acute, right leg pain for 2 hours. The patient's symptoms started suddenly while he was doing household chores. He has no history of leg pain at rest or with exertion. He has hypertension treated with ramipril. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 105/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 146/92 mm Hg. The right lower extremity is cool and tender to touch. A photograph of the limb is shown. Femoral pulses are palpable bilaterally; popliteal and pedal pulses are decreased on the right side. Sensation to pinprick and light touch and muscle strength are decreased in the right lower extremity. Which of the following is most likely to have shown the underlying cause prior to the onset of this patient's current symptoms?
content_preview: A 72-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of severe, acute, right leg pain for 2 hours. The patient's symptoms started suddenly while he was doing household chores. He has no history of leg pain at rest or with exertion. He has hypertension treated with ramipril. He appears uncomfortable. His temperature is 37.4°C (99.3°F), pulse is 105/min and irregular, and blood pressure is 146/92 mm Hg. The right lower extremity is cool and tender to touch. A photograph of the limb is shown. Femoral pulses are palpable bilaterally; popliteal and pedal pulses are decreased on the right side. Sensation to pinprick and light touch and muscle strength are decreased in the right lower extremity. Which of the following is most likely to have shown the underlying cause prior to the onset of this patient's current symptoms?
hint: Pain, pallor, pulselessness, paralysis, paresthesia, and poikilothermia (6 Ps) are hallmarks of acute limb ischemia (ALI).
learning_objective: Recognize acute limb ischemia, and recall the diagnostic study to identify its common underlying cause.

answers.explanation_why: Gadolinium-enhanced magnetic resonance angiography (MRA) of the legs is a confirmatory test for ALI and is useful for identifying arterial thrombi and dissections as an underlying etiology of ALI. It would not, however, help to confirm the most likely underlying source of this patient's ALI.

Echocardiography can be used to visualize an atrial thrombus, which can develop as a complication of atrial fibrillation (Afib). This patient's irregular pulse is suggestive of Afib. The atrial thrombus (or parts of it) may dislodge and embolize into the systemic circulation, thereby leading to arterial occlusion and subsequent ischemia. The most common location of arterial occlusion due to arterial embolism is the femoropopliteal artery.

ALI is commonly caused by thrombosis secondary to peripheral artery disease (PAD); however, the absence of preexisting claudication in this case makes PAD a less likely diagnosis.

images.title: Thrombus in the left atrial appendage
images.description: Transesophageal echocardiogram in a 78-year-old patient with atrial fibrillation, aphasia, dysarthria, and numbness in the left leg (midesophageal short-axis view of the left atrium)A hyperechoic structure (red overlay) fills most of the LAA (white arrow; green outline).This finding is typical of a large thrombus in the left atrial appendage. Transesophageal echocardiography is highly sensitive for cardiac thrombus.AV: aortic valve; LA: left atrium; LAD: left anterior descending artery

answers.explanation_why: Doppler ultrasonography of the legs is the best initial test for detecting arterial and venous thrombosis and assessing the severity of ALI. It would not, however, help to confirm the most likely underlying cause of this patient's current symptoms.

Digital subtraction angiogram (DSA) is an imaging modality used to diagnose ALI. It should only be performed if treatment can be delayed for further imaging without posing a threat to the extremity. DSA is useful for identifying arterial occlusions or dissections as an underlying etiology of ALI and facilitates immediate therapeutic intervention, e.g., catheter-directed thrombolysis. DSA would not, however, help to confirm the most likely underlying source of this patient's ALI.

Needle manometry of the limb is the diagnostic test of choice for suspected compartment syndrome, which typically occurs secondary to trauma (e.g., expanding hematoma, closed fracture, crush injury) and leads to extrinsic compression of the arteries. Symptoms (the 6 Ps) are difficult to distinguish from those caused by acute intraluminal occlusion of an artery. However, manometry would not help to identify the underlying etiology of ALI.

The ankle-brachial index is primarily used to diagnose peripheral artery disease (PAD), but it is also used to assess ALI. Values < 0.4 indicate severe occlusion and ischemia. This patient has no history of claudication or trophic changes to his lower extremities, making PAD unlikely. Although this test quantifies the severity of arterial occlusion in ALI, it does not help to confirm the underlying etiology.

images.title: Cyanosis of the foot
images.description: Soles of a patient with acute unilateral limb ischemia. Marked purplish discoloration (cyanosis) of the right foot can be seen (likely caused by thromboembolism of the posterior tibial artery).

question_text: A 55-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of sudden pain in his right calf and foot that started 30 minutes ago and is worsening. He also has a tingling sensation and weakness in his right leg. He has had no similar episodes, recent trauma, or claudication. One month ago, he was diagnosed with myocardial infarction and treated with stent implantation in the left anterior descending coronary artery. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and was diagnosed with hypertension 20 years ago. His sister has systemic sclerosis. He works as an office administrator and sits at his desk for most of the day. Current medications include metformin and lisinopril. He has smoked one and a half packs of cigarettes daily for 30 years. Pulse is 110/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. There is slightly reduced muscle strength in the right leg, which is pale and cool to the touch. Pedal pulse is absent on the right. Examination of the left leg shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's clinical findings?
content_preview: A 55-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of sudden pain in his right calf and foot that started 30 minutes ago and is worsening. He also has a tingling sensation and weakness in his right leg. He has had no similar episodes, recent trauma, or claudication. One month ago, he was diagnosed with myocardial infarction and treated with stent implantation in the left anterior descending coronary artery. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and was diagnosed with hypertension 20 years ago. His sister has systemic sclerosis. He works as an office administrator and sits at his desk for most of the day. Current medications include metformin and lisinopril. He has smoked one and a half packs of cigarettes daily for 30 years. Pulse is 110/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. There is slightly reduced muscle strength in the right leg, which is pale and cool to the touch. Pedal pulse is absent on the right. Examination of the left leg shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's clinical findings?
hint: This patient presents with the 6 Ps of acute limb ischemia (ALI): pain, paresthesia, pallor, paralysis, pulselessness, and poikilothermia.
learning_objective: Recognize arterial embolism as a cause of acute limb ischemia.

answers.explanation_why: Acute deep vein thrombosis (DVT) of the lower limb can manifest with sudden unilateral leg pain. Although this patient has several risk factors for DVT (e.g., obesity, a sedentary lifestyle, advanced age, and smoking), this condition typically manifests with swelling (due to edema), erythema, and warmth, not pallor, muscle weakness, numbness, absent pulses, or coldness to touch.

Raynaud phenomenon is caused by abnormal vasospasm in response to stress or cold and may manifest with pale and cold extremities. This condition is associated with connective tissue disorders, such as SLE and systemic sclerosis. This patient's family history of systemic sclerosis is a risk factor for developing the disease. In contrast to this patient's condition, Raynaud phenomenon usually affects the small, distal arteries (e.g., digital arteries) and typically has a symmetrical distribution.

Popliteal artery aneurysm is rare and most commonly manifests with chronic ischemia, but it can also manifest with acute limb ischemia if sudden thrombosis or distal embolization occurs. This patient has risk factors for an aneurysm (e.g., hypertension, smoking), but his history of cardiac disease and the absence of a pulsatile popliteal mass on physical examination make another cause more likely.

answers.content: Atherosclerotic narrowing of a peripheral artery
answers.explanation_why: Atherosclerotic narrowing of a peripheral artery causes peripheral arterial disease (PAD). Atherosclerotic plaque disruption in a diseased arterial segment may cause acute-on-chronic limb ischemia, which manifests with pallor, decreased skin temperature, and an absent pulse. This patient's history of smoking, hypertension, and type 2 diabetes mellitus puts him at increased risk of PAD. However, symptoms of acute-on-chronic limb ischemia are usually less severe and develop within a few hours to a few days because of the collateral blood circulation. Moreover, this patient does not have features of PAD (e.g., claudication, diminished pulses in the opposite extremity), making a different cause more likely.

Vasculitis and subsequent thrombosis of medium-sized arteries are the underlying pathogenesis of thromboangiitis obliterans (TAO), which can present with limb pain, paresthesia, and absent pulses. However, the onset of TAO is insidious, and it typically affects younger smokers (< 45 years of age). This patient presents with acute onset of unilateral leg pain with no preceding symptoms and no evidence of chronic arterial insufficiency, making TAO an unlikely diagnosis.

Sudden onset of ALI in a previously asymptomatic patient (no trauma and no features of peripheral artery disease such as claudication) is most likely caused by arterial embolism. Arterial embolisms most commonly originate from a cardiac thrombus, which typically forms if there is intracardiac blood stasis (e.g., due to atrial fibrillation or complications of myocardial infarction such as noncontractile myocardium or ventricular aneurysm). This patient’s sensory loss and muscle weakness strongly suggest that the right limb is under immediate threat. Management of ALI in a viable or threatened limb begins with an IV heparin bolus followed by continuous infusion and emergent revascularization (via catheter-directed thrombolysis, percutaneous mechanical thromboembolectomy, or open thromboembolectomy) to restore blood flow to the extremity.

ALI most commonly results from the rupture of an atherosclerotic plaque or thrombosis in a previously stenotic but patent artery, such as those in patients with PAD. In PAD, collateral circulation often gradually develops, which protects against sudden, severe ischemia. Therefore, in patients with PAD, the manifestation of ALI is typically less severe than arterial embolism and symptoms usually develop within a few hours to a few days (i.e., acute-on-chronic limb ischemia)

Cholesterol embolism (CE) can occur after coronary stent placement and may manifest with symptoms of ALI. However, CE typically clogs small to medium-sized vessels, resulting in insidious organ damage (especially with renal involvement) and/or skin changes (e.g., livedo reticularis, blue toe syndrome). In addition, CE most commonly manifests shortly after the vascular intervention when cholesterol is released from atherosclerotic plaques, whereas this patient's symptoms began one month after stent placement.

question_text: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-week history of tingling pain in the sole of his right foot when he raises it above chest level during exercises. He reports that he started exercising regularly 2 months ago and that his right calf cramps when he uses the incline feature on the treadmill, forcing him to take frequent breaks. The pain completely disappears after resting for a few minutes. He has an 8-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 34 years. His only medication is metformin. His pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 170/92 mm Hg. Straight leg raise test elicits pallor and tingling pain in the right foot. There is no pain in the back. His muscle strength is normal. Femoral pulses are palpable; right pedal pulses are absent. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-week history of tingling pain in the sole of his right foot when he raises it above chest level during exercises. He reports that he started exercising regularly 2 months ago and that his right calf cramps when he uses the incline feature on the treadmill, forcing him to take frequent breaks. The pain completely disappears after resting for a few minutes. He has an 8-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 34 years. His only medication is metformin. His pulse is 82/min, and blood pressure is 170/92 mm Hg. Straight leg raise test elicits pallor and tingling pain in the right foot. There is no pain in the back. His muscle strength is normal. Femoral pulses are palpable; right pedal pulses are absent. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: This patient presents with features of the most common subtype of peripheral arterial disease (PAD).
learning_objective: Recognize femoropopliteal artery stenosis.

answers.explanation_why: This patient's symptoms of arterial insufficiency (paresthesia, intermittent claudication) in his right calf and foot and palpable femoral pulses but absent right pedal pulses indicate stenosis of the femoropopliteal artery, the most common site of peripheral arterial disease. The foot tingling on leg elevation is due to the decrease in arterial blood flow to the limb when raised above the level of the heart (usually insignificant, but can cause symptoms in patients with preexisting arterial insufficiency). The cramping pain upon exertion (e.g., walking on the treadmill) and relief at rest are characteristic of intermittent claudication (stage II according to Fontaine classification), which is a symptom of arterial insufficiency. Chronic smoking, hypertension, advanced age, and male gender are all significant risk factors for the development of PAD.

images.title: Buerger test (Buerger sign)
images.description: The Buerger test is used to evaluate peripheral arterial disease of the lower limbs.With the patient in the supine position, elevate the lower limbs to ∼45° at the hip and evaluate for foot pallor. If no pallor occurs, ask the patient to plantarflex and dorsiflex or to rotate their feet a few times, looking for exercise-induced pallor.Next, ask the patient to sit up with their legs hanging off the examination table and evaluate the time taken for the color to return to the feet and for the veins to fill again.Foot pallor on elevation, or reactive hyperemia or delayed venous refilling on dependency, indicate arterial insufficiency (positive Buerger sign). A venous filling time of > 20 seconds may indicate advanced ischemia.

answers.explanation_why: Paresthesia of the extremities is a characteristic feature of diabetic neuropathy, a complication seen in patients with chronic diabetics, as seen here. However, diabetic neuropathy typically affects the extremities symmetrically (glove and stocking distribution) and neurological examination would show sensory loss in the affected areas.

answers.content: Vasculitis of the right popliteal artery
answers.explanation_why: Vasculitis and thrombosis of small and medium-sized arteries, e.g., the popliteal artery, are the underlying pathogenesis of thromboangiitis obliterans (TAO), for which chronic smoking is the most important risk factor. TAO manifests with features of arterial insufficiency (paresthesia, claudication, absent peripheral pulses in the affected limb), as seen in this patient. However, TAO typically affects more than one limb, commonly manifests with features of Raynaud phenomenon and migratory thrombophlebitis, and rarely affects patients > 45 years of age.

answers.content: Acute thrombosis of right popliteal vein
answers.explanation_why: Acute deep vein thrombosis (DVT) of the right popliteal vein can manifest with sudden, severe pain in the calf that exacerbates on exertion but would not disappear on rest. In addition, paresthesia that worsens on raising the limb above the level of the heart and absent pedal pulses on examination are not features of venous disease. Instead, acute DVT would show edema, warmth, calf tenderness, and, possibly, distended superficial veins in the affected limb, none of which are present in this patient.

Lumbar spinal stenosis caused by progressive narrowing of the central spinal canal (e.g., due to spondylolisthesis, intervertebral disk herniation) can manifest with pseudoclaudication (neuropathic claudication). Although tingling and cramping are symptoms of pseudoclaudication, and the condition occurs unilaterally in about 30% of cases, it typically involves the entire leg and would not cause absent pedal pulses. Additionally, a straight-leg raising test would elicit pain in the back and/or lower limbs.

images.title: Posture-dependent pain in lumbar spinal stenosis (neuropathic claudication)
images.description: Pain due to lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS) is typically dependent on postural changes. Symptoms typically improve when sitting or leaning forward (shopping-cart sign), as lumbar flexion widens the central spinal canal and relieves nerve root compression. In contrast, symptoms typically worsen with positions involving lumbar extension (e.g., walking, prolonged standing). This phenomenon is referred to as neuropathic claudication and is a hallmark of LSS.

answers.explanation_why: Although aortoiliac occlusive disease can manifest with unilateral paresthesia and claudication of the calf and foot, examination would show absent femoral pulses. Additionally, patients with significant aortoiliac stenosis would typically have claudication symptoms in the thigh and gluteal regions.

question_text:
A 54-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of severe pain in his right leg that began suddenly 3 hours ago. For the past 4 months he has experienced cramping in his right calf when walking, but it has never been this severe. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypercholesterolemia, and hypertension. Current medications include insulin, enalapril, aspirin, and simvastatin. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 33 years. He does not drink alcohol. His pulse is 103/min and blood pressure is 136/84 mm Hg. Femoral pulses are palpable bilaterally. The popliteal and pedal pulses are absent on the right. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
16.1 g/dL

Serum

Urea nitrogen
14 mg/dL

Glucose
166 mg/dL

Creatinine
1.5 mg/dL

A CT angiogram of the right lower extremity is ordered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 54-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of severe pain in his right leg that began suddenly 3 hours ago. For the past 4 months he has experienced cramping in his right calf when walking, but it has never been this severe. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypercholesterolemia, and hypertension. Current medications include insulin, enalapril, aspirin, and simvastatin. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 33 years. He does not drink alcohol. His pulse is 103/min and blood pressure is 136/84 mm Hg. Femoral pulses are palpable bilaterally. The popliteal and pedal pulses are absent on the right. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 16.1 g/dL Serum Urea nitrogen 14 mg/dL Glucose 166 mg/dL Creatinine 1.5 mg/dL A CT angiogram of the right lower extremity is ordered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: Patients with borderline renal function are at high risk of contrast-induced nephropathy and require specific preventive measures.
learning_objective: Choose the most appropriate management to prevent contrast-induced nephropathy in a patient at risk.

answers.explanation_why: Remote ischemic preconditioning (RIPC) consists of deliberately inducing transient ischemia in an organ to prevent subsequent ischemic injury. RIPC is not performed to prevent contrast-induced nephropathy as there is not enough evidence to support its effectiveness and safety.

Administering mannitol and other diuretics prior to performing contrast-enhanced CT angiography is not effective in preventing contrast-induced nephropathy in at-risk patients. Diuretics can result in volume depletion and dehydration, which actually increase the risk of contrast-induced nephropathy!

Ionic contrast medium is a high-osmolar agent that can worsen renal function in patients with borderline creatinine levels, which increases the risk of contrast-induced nephropathy. In patients at risk of developing contrast-induced nephropathy (e.g., history of chronic kidney disease, diabetes mellitus), such as this man, the lowest effective dose of non-ionic contrast medium should be used.
There is no evidence that hemodialysis following intravascular administration of a contrast agent prevents contrast-induced nephropathy in at-risk patients.
Acetylcysteine may help prevent contrast-induced nephropathy. However, studies have shown inconsistent results of its efficacy, making an alternative preventive method a better first step.

Intravenous administration of normal saline prior to and for several hours after performing contrast-enhanced CT angiography is indicated in patients who are at risk of developing contrast-induced nephropathy. Major risk factors include chronic kidney disease, diabetes mellitus (particularly diabetic nephropathy), dehydration, and the use of nephrotoxic drugs (e.g., NSAIDs). This patient's laboratory studies show elevated creatinine and borderline normal BUN level, which suggest impaired kidney function. Therefore, urgent prophylactic hydration is vital in this patient. Laboratory monitoring is necessary following the procedure to detect worsening creatinine levels (typically highest after 3–5 days), which would indicate contrast-induced nephropathy.

NSAIDs should be avoided prior to, and for several hours after, administering intravascular contrast medium because they cause renal vasoconstriction and subsequently increase the risk of contrast-induced nephropathy. Other nephrotoxic drugs (e.g., ACE inhibitors) should also be discontinued.

Although sodium bicarbonate may be administered to prevent contrast-induced nephropathy, it is a more expensive option and carries a risk of compounding error because it must be prepared using bicarbonate and sterile water. Also, studies have not shown any benefit of sodium bicarbonate compared to a cheaper alternative, which is considered the preferred preventive measure.
