question_text: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of a rash on her ankles with intermittent itching. After the rash developed, she started applying a new scented lotion to her legs daily. She works as a cashier at a grocery store. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medications include metformin and enalapril. Examination shows enlarged superficial veins of the right lower extremity and red-brown discoloration with indistinct margins over the medial ankles. There is 1+ edema in the lower extremities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s skin findings?
content_preview: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of a rash on her ankles with intermittent itching. After the rash developed, she started applying a new scented lotion to her legs daily. She works as a cashier at a grocery store. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medications include metformin and enalapril. Examination shows enlarged superficial veins of the right lower extremity and red-brown discoloration with indistinct margins over the medial ankles. There is 1+ edema in the lower extremities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s skin findings?
hint: This woman has a pruritic, red-brown rash over the medial ankles, varicose veins, and bilateral lower extremity edema. Her occupation likely requires her to stand for prolonged periods. These findings suggest stasis dermatitis due to chronic venous disease.
learning_objective: Recognize stasis dermatitis, and recall its pathophysiology.

answers.content: Bacterial spread through the superficial dermis
answers.explanation_why: Bacterial spread through the superficial dermis and lymphatics is the underlying cause of erysipelas, which typically results in lower extremity erythema and edema and is more common in individuals with diabetes mellitus (due to impaired neutrophil function from hyperglycemia and diabetic neuropathy). However, skin lesions of erysipelas are usually well-demarcated, unilateral, nonpruritic, and associated with systemic manifestations (e.g., fever and chills).

images.title: Erysipelas
images.description: Sharply demarcated, swollen, erythematous lesion with raised borders on the lower leg. Additionally, pitting edema is seen in the areas where the sock has applied pressure to the underlying tissue.

answers.content: Contact of antigen with pre-sensitized T lymphocytes
answers.explanation_why: Contact of antigen with pre-sensitized T lymphocytes is the underlying mechanism of allergic contact dermatitis, which usually manifests with a pruritic, erythematous rash with indistinct margins. Products that contain fragrance are common contact allergens. However, this patient's rash preceded her use of a new lotion. Additionally, allergic contact dermatitis typically only causes edema in areas that have thin skin (e.g., the lips and eyelids) and does not result in varicose veins.

images.title: Allergic contact dermatitis
images.description: Upper body of a man presenting with a severely pruritic rash after getting a henna tattoo on the right armAn erythematous papulovesicular rash is visible over the chest and arms. The rash is most severe around the henna tattoo, which appears markedly erythematous.This is the typical appearance of allergic contact dermatitis.

answers.explanation_why: Intracellular accumulation of sorbitol is involved in the pathogenesis of diabetic neuropathy, a condition that causes abnormal sensation in the lower extremities in patients with diabetes. Sorbitol accumulates in cells that lack sorbitol dehydrogenase (e.g., Schwann cells), which leads to osmotic damage. However, diabetic neuropathy does not cause edema, varicose veins, or red-brown discoloration.

Insufficient arterial tissue perfusion can cause ischemic ulcers, which often manifest at sites of focal pressure such as the medial malleoli. These ulcers develop in patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD), which is associated with advanced age, diabetes, and hypertension. However, they are typically painful and well-demarcated. Additionally, this patient does not have other common symptoms of PAD such as claudication, hair loss on the leg, or nail changes.

Tinea pedis, a dermatophyte infection, most commonly develops on the feet and causes a pruritic, scaly rash. Erythema can also occur but is less common. Tinea pedis typically affects the digital interspaces and soles of the feet (not the medial ankles) and is not associated with edema or varicose veins.

images.title: Tinea pedis (athlete's foot)
images.description: Plantar view of the left foot There is skin peeling in the region of the forefoot with a blistered appearance. The erythematous base appears dry and scaly. These findings are characteristic of tinea pedis.

answers.explanation_why: Dermal deposition of hemosiderin is a key feature of stasis dermatitis. Elevated venous pressures from chronic venous disease result in red blood cell breakdown, which leads to hemosiderin production. Hemosiderin penetrates defective capillaries and accumulates in the dermis, which causes a pruritic, red-brown rash, as seen in this patient. The medial ankles are the most frequently involved site.

images.title: Chronic venous insufficiency
images.description: Yellow-brown skin discoloration (hemosiderin deposition) and edema is present. A varicose vein can be seen on the anterior aspect of the right leg below the knee.These changes are consistent with CEAP class 4 venous insufficiency.

question_text:
Six days after undergoing open reduction and internal fixation of a left-sided femur fracture that he sustained in a motor vehicle collision, a hospitalized 67-year-old man has sudden-onset severe pain and paresthesia in his right arm. The operation and the immediate postoperative course were uneventful. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. He is alert and oriented. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.2°F), pulse is 85/min and regular, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 136/92 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Physical examination of the right arm shows decreased brachial and radial pulses, and a capillary refill time of 6 seconds. The skin over the right arm is pale and cold to the touch. Preoperative laboratory studies were within the reference range. Current laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
13.8 g/dL

Leukocyte count
8300/mm^3

Platelet count
60,000/mm^3

Serum

 Creatinine
1.0 mg/dL

 Partial thromboplastin time, activated

55 seconds

 Prothrombin time
14 seconds

 D-Dimer
positive

Arterial Doppler ultrasonography shows occlusion of the right brachial artery. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's current condition?
content_preview: Six days after undergoing open reduction and internal fixation of a left-sided femur fracture that he sustained in a motor vehicle collision, a hospitalized 67-year-old man has sudden-onset severe pain and paresthesia in his right arm. The operation and the immediate postoperative course were uneventful. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. He is alert and oriented. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.2°F), pulse is 85/min and regular, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 136/92 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Physical examination of the right arm shows decreased brachial and radial pulses, and a capillary refill time of 6 seconds. The skin over the right arm is pale and cold to the touch. Preoperative laboratory studies were within the reference range. Current laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 13.8 g/dL Leukocyte count 8300/mm3 Platelet count 60,000/mm3 Serum Creatinine 1.0 mg/dL Partial thromboplastin time, activated 55 seconds Prothrombin time 14 seconds D-Dimer positive Arterial Doppler ultrasonography shows occlusion of the right brachial artery. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's current condition?
hint: After major orthopedic surgery involving the lower limb, an increase in the activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) is an indicator of appropriate postoperative management!
learning_objective: Recognize heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT).

answers.explanation_why: Peripheral arterial disease (PAD) manifests with limb ischemia and this patient has a significant smoking history, is male, and is older than 65 years of age, all of which are important risk factors for PAD. However, PAD most commonly manifests with chronic limb ischemia and is much more common in the lower extremities. Furthermore, PAD does not manifest with thrombocytopenia.

A patent foramen ovale can permit paradoxical embolism to an artery but such an event is exceedingly uncommon. Moreover, this patient's new-onset thrombocytopenia suggests a different underlying cause of his acute arterial occlusion.

Thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP) causes an acute drop in the platelet count. However, TTP typically only causes microthrombi formation; acute occlusion of large blood vessels (e.g., brachial artery) is not characteristic of TTP. Furthermore, other typical features of TTP, such as fever, neurologic changes (e.g., altered mental status, delirium), microangiopathic hemolytic anemia (manifesting as low hemoglobin), and impaired renal function, are absent in this patient.

As evidenced by his increased aPTT and normal PT, this patient was given subcutaneous heparin for deep vein thrombosis prophylaxis. Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT), formerly called type 2 HIT, is a rare, immune-mediated adverse effect of heparin. The risk of developing this condition is higher with unfractionated heparin but can also occur in patients treated with low molecular weight heparin. HIT typically occurs 5–14 days after initiation of heparin and can result in thrombotic events (e.g., arterial occlusion). Although HIT is characterized by thrombocytopenia, bleeding manifestations are rare as the platelet count rarely decreases below 20,000 platelets/mm^3. The diagnosis is confirmed by serum immunoassays to detect anti-heparin/platelet factor 4 antibodies but heparin should be immediately stopped without waiting for diagnostic confirmation and nonheparin anticoagulation should be initiated.

HIT should be differentiated from the more common nonimmune heparin-associated thrombocytopenia (formerly called type 1 HIT), which occurs within 5 days of heparin initiation and is a transient, clinically insignificant, mild to moderate thrombocytopenia that can be managed with serial monitoring of platelet counts and does not require discontinuation of heparin.

Fat embolization is a serious complication of long bone fractures (e.g., humerus or femur) and can result in thrombocytopenia. However, fat embolism most commonly manifests with acute-onset respiratory symptoms (e.g., hypoxemia, dyspnea, tachypnea) due to obstruction of the pulmonary circulation, features of neurological involvement (e.g., confusion, lethargy, seizures), and a petechial rash on the axilla and chest wall due to capillary occlusion. Acute arterial occlusion is uncommon with fat embolization.

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) can occur following severe trauma and manifest with thrombotic features, thrombocytopenia, prolonged aPTT, and a positive D-dimer. However, DIC typically causes microthromboses in multiple organs; thromboses of large veins can also occur but an isolated arterial thrombosis is not typical of DIC. Furthermore, DIC also causes bleeding manifestations (e.g., petechiae, purpura, ecchymoses, bleeding from venipuncture sites) and, since DIC is a consumption coagulopathy, the PT value would also be increased. This patient's increased aPTT and normal PT indicate a different cause.

question_text: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of a 6-month history of progressive fatigue and worsening shortness of breath on exertion. The parents report that the boy “has always tired out a bit more easily than other kids.” The family recently immigrated to the United States from rural Bolivia. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96% on both index fingers. Cardiac examination shows a right parasternal heave on palpation and a pronounced S_2 on auscultation. Pulses in the upper and lower extremities are synchronous bilaterally. There is mild bluish discoloration and bulbous enlargement of the distal toes bilaterally. Echocardiography is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because of a 6-month history of progressive fatigue and worsening shortness of breath on exertion. The parents report that the boy “has always tired out a bit more easily than other kids.” The family recently immigrated to the United States from rural Bolivia. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96% on both index fingers. Cardiac examination shows a right parasternal heave on palpation and a pronounced S2 on auscultation. Pulses in the upper and lower extremities are synchronous bilaterally. There is mild bluish discoloration and bulbous enlargement of the distal toes bilaterally. Echocardiography is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: The patient presents with lower extremity cyanosis and clubbing with preserved upper extremity oxygenation (a finding known as differential cyanosis) and symptoms of heart failure.
learning_objective: Recognize the clinical features of a large patent ductus arteriosus, and recall the expected echocardiographic finding.

answers.content: Single overriding great vessel arising from the heart
answers.explanation_why: A single overriding great vessel is called a persistent truncus arteriosus. This single arterial trunk arising from the heart provides mixed blood to the pulmonary arteries and the systemic circulation. Pulses may be accentuated and bounding; however, oxygen saturation would be decreased in all extremities. Furthermore, if it is not diagnosed prenatally, it will typically present perinatally with symptoms of global cyanosis and heart failure, while this adolescent patient only has differential cyanosis.

answers.content: Anomalous shunting of blood through a defect in atrial septum
answers.explanation_why: Atrial septal defects (ASD) are often asymptomatic. In adults, larger defects may lead to a distinct left-to-right shunt, which can result in right heart failure, supraventricular arrhythmias, and pulmonary hypertension, and ultimately lead to an Eisenmenger reaction and global cyanosis. Differential cyanosis would not be seen.

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in atrial septal defect
images.description: An atrial septal defect causes blood to flow from the left to the right atrium (left-to-right shunt; white arrow), resulting in volume overload of the right atrium and ventricle (1). As a result, there is dilation and compensatory hypertrophy (double-headed white arrows) of the right atrium and ventricle (2). In the late stages, Eisenmenger syndrome with shunt reversal (right-to-left shunt; white arrow) and cyanosis can occur (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

answers.content: Persistent blood flow between the pulmonary artery and descending aorta
answers.explanation_why:
Failure of the ductus arteriosus to completely close postnatally allows blood to flow from the descending aorta back to the pulmonary artery (left-to-right shunt). In a large patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), this leads to volume overload of the right ventricle and the lung circuit. This increased blood flow causes pulmonary hypertension and irreversible remodeling of small pulmonary vessels, which may eventually lead to an Eisenmenger reaction (shunt reversal). This patient's palpable right parasternal heave and pronounced S_2 are evidence of increased right heart strain. In patients with a large PDA, the features of differential cyanosis occur once shunt reversal develops. Because the ductus is located on the descending aorta distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery, reversal of the shunt results in deoxygenated blood reaching only the lower body. Due to the rise in pulmonary pressure, the characteristic continuous machine-like murmur heard in patients with PDA eventually disappears.

Infants with PDA usually receive an infusion of indomethacin to induce closure of the duct, while in older children symptomatic PDAs are typically closed surgically or via percutaneous catheter occlusion. The presence of an Eisenmenger reaction is, however, a contraindication to a PDA closure.

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in patent ductus arteriosus
images.description: In patent ductus arteriosus, there is a left-to-right shunt, with blood flowing from the aorta to the pulmonary arteries during both systole and diastole (1). This shunt leads to volume overload (recirculation) of the blood within the pulmonary vessels, the left atrium, and left ventricle (2). Eventually, because of the increased blood flow to the pulmonary circulation, pulmonary hypertension may develop as well as Eisenmenger syndrome, which involves a shunt reversal. The left-to-right-shunt without cyanosis becomes a right-to-left shunt with cyanosis (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Pink: structures that contain mixed blood

answers.content: Positioning of the ascending aorta directly over a ventricular septal defect
answers.explanation_why: Positioning of the ascending aorta directly over a ventricular septal defect is seen in tetralogy of Fallot. The other features of this cardiac abnormality are pulmonary stenosis and right ventricular hypertrophy. It is typically symptomatic in infancy and presents with tet spells and mild cyanosis in all extremities.

images.title: Tetralogy of Fallot
images.description:
Tetralogy of Fallot is the simultaneous occurrence of:
(a) Pulmonary stenosis
(b) Right ventricular hypertrophy
(c) Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
(d) An overriding aorta (above the VSD)The hemodynamic effects depend on the extent of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. With mild obstruction (1), a left-to-right shunt is more pronounced and there is mild cyanosis. With severe obstruction (2), a right-to-left shunt is more pronounced, which results in severe cyanosis. Pulmonary circulation may be supplied via a patent ductus arteriosus.

answers.content: Abnormal narrowing of the aorta at the aortic isthmus
answers.explanation_why: Abnormal narrowing at the aortic isthmus is consistent with coarctation of the aorta (CoA), which would cause differential cyanosis if the CoA is severe (i.e., a ductal-dependent congenital heart defect) but this differential cyanosis would be evident from the neonatal period. In addition, patients with CoA have a brachio-femoral pulse delay rather than synchronous pulses. The symptoms of a mild CoA can begin later in life but in such a scenario, differential cyanosis would not be expected. Instead, patients present with features of brachiocephalic hypertension (e.g., headaches, epistaxis), lower extremity arterial insufficiency (manifesting with claudication and cool skin with faint or unpalpable pulses, but no cyanosis), and evidence of compensatory collateral arteries (e.g., continuous murmur over the back).

images.title: Coarctation of the aorta (hypoplastic type)
images.description: (1) Hypoplasia of aorta can lead to hypertension (↑ BP) in the head and upper limbs as well as poststenotic hypoperfusion. In patent ductus arteriosus, this can be compensated by a right-to-left-shunt of blood from the pulmonary arteries into the aorta, resulting in the flow of mixed blood with decreased oxygen saturation (↓ SaO_2) to the general circulation.(2) After closure of the ductus arteriosus, the right-to-left shunt is absent (~ SaO_2) and there is hypoperfusion (↓ BP) of the abdominal organs and lower extremities with oxygenated blood.

question_text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of recurrent nosebleeds and fatigue for the past 2 months. He also frequently complains his head hurts. The patient has met all motoric milestones for his age but does not like to run because his legs start to hurt if he does. He is at the 40^th percentile for both height and weight. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure in the right arm is 130/85 mm Hg. A grade 2/6 systolic murmur is heard in the left paravertebral region. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
content_preview: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of recurrent nosebleeds and fatigue for the past 2 months. He also frequently complains his head hurts. The patient has met all motoric milestones for his age but does not like to run because his legs start to hurt if he does. He is at the 40th percentile for both height and weight. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 32/min, and blood pressure in the right arm is 130/85 mm Hg. A grade 2/6 systolic murmur is heard in the left paravertebral region. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
hint: This patient's general fatigue, hypertension, low-grade systolic ejection murmur, lower-extremity claudication, headaches, and recurrent epistaxis together suggest coarctation of the aorta (CoA).
learning_objective: Recognize coarctation of the aorta, and recall its diagnostic findings.

answers.explanation_why: Notching of the ribs, an x-ray finding in patients with coarctation of the aorta, results from compensatory collateral blood flow involving the intercostal vessels. Those vessels may dilate to bypass the left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. Although this patient may eventually develop visible rib notching, it is generally a sign of chronic disease and usually does not become apparent in children before the age of 5 years.

images.title: Coarctation of the aorta
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view)Focal indentation of the distal aortic arch is seen at the location of aortic coarctation (illustration). An additional finding is inferior rib notching (Roesler sign; examples indicated by arrowheads), which is produced by dilated intercostal arteries.The figure-3 sign of coarctation (indicated by red line) is seen in this patient. It is produced by prestenotic dilatation of the aortic arch and left subclavian artery in combination with post-stenotic dilatation of the descending aorta. The presence of bilateral rib notching indicates that the coarctation is distal to the origin of both subclavian arteries.

answers.explanation_why: Interarm differences in tissue oxygenation and blood pressure can be a finding of coarctation of the aorta in the rare case that the narrowing is proximal to the left subclavian artery. In such patients, blood pressure in the right arm would be markedly higher than in the left arm and oxygen saturation would be lower in the left arm. However, coarctation of the aorta most commonly presents with differences in blood pressure between the upper and the lower extremities.

Congenital pulmonary valve stenosis is a characteristic feature of tetralogy of Fallot. A systolic ejection murmur can be present and is usually best heard at the left sternal border, rather than the left paravertebral region. Patients usually present with (mild) cyanosis and intermittent hypoxic episodes that improve with squatting, none of which are seen here. Coarctation of the aorta is characterized by an outflow obstruction of the left ventricle.

Left-axis deviation and increased R wave amplitude in V5–V6 on ECG are signs of left ventricular hypertrophy. While myocardial hypertrophy is one of the compensatory mechanisms to counter the aortic narrowing in patients with coarctation of the aorta, such as this 3-year-old boy, the changes in ECG vary with age and degree of stenosis, and it usually takes several years before the hypertrophy becomes apparent. In older children and adults, ECG may show signs of left ventricular hypertrophy in the left precordial leads (e.g., positive Sokolow-Lyon criteria).

In patients with CoA, delayed or even absent lower extremity pulses are expected distal to the stenotic portion of the aorta. Since the post-stenotic blood supply is limited, the resulting lower-extremity hypoxia becomes evident, especially during exertion, which is a strong sign of intermittent claudication, as in this patient.

Doppler echocardiography is the confirmatory test of choice and can identify the location and extent of the stenosis.

question_text: A 29-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being stabbed in the left thigh. His pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows a 2-cm wound overlying a pulsatile mass on the left anterior thigh, 4 cm below the inguinal crease. A thrill is palpated, and a bruit is heard over this area. Peripheral pulses are normal bilaterally. The patient is at greatest risk for which of the following?
content_preview: A 29-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after being stabbed in the left thigh. His pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Examination shows a 2-cm wound overlying a pulsatile mass on the left anterior thigh, 4 cm below the inguinal crease. A thrill is palpated, and a bruit is heard over this area. Peripheral pulses are normal bilaterally. The patient is at greatest risk for which of the following?
hint: This patient has a traumatic arteriovenous fistula, which typically manifests as a pulsatile mass with a palpable thrill and audible bruit.
learning_objective: Recognize traumatic arteriovenous fistula, and recall its complications.

answers.explanation_why: The aneurysmal dilation of an arteriovenous fistula in the anterior thigh 4 cm below the inguinal crease can result in compression of surrounding structures. However, pudendal nerve compression is unlikely given the location of this patient's injury.

High-output cardiac failure can occur following the formation of a traumatic arteriovenous fistula due to the shunting of blood from the arterial high-pressure system to the venous low-pressure system. As a result of this shunt, systemic vascular resistance decreases, which, in turn, results in an increased heart rate, stroke volume, and cardiac output. However, despite increased cardiac output, low systemic vascular resistance results in arterial underfilling, decreased renal perfusion, and retention of water and salt, which leads to volume overload and heart failure.

Although this patient has an increased risk of thrombus development at the site of an arteriovenous fistula, a pulmonary embolism would be an unlikely complication because a dislodged thrombus would travel distally into the affected vein as a result of the reverse blood flow caused by the pressure differential from the arterial to venous systems.

Risk factors for the development of an iliac artery aneurysm include connective tissue disorders, older age, history of smoking, hypertension, and atherosclerosis. The mechanism of this patient's injury could compromise the vascular integrity at the level of the injury but is unlikely to affect the iliac artery given how distal the wound is.

Osteonecrosis of the femoral head can result from trauma to the medial circumflex femoral artery (e.g., from femoral head fracture or lateral or medial femoral neck fracture, especially with dislocation). However, a stab wound in the anterior thigh is unlikely to affect the medial circumflex femoral artery.

question_text: A 3-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of poor weight gain. She also reports a dusky blue discoloration to his skin during feedings and when crying. On examination, there is a harsh, systolic murmur heard over the left upper sternal border. An x-ray of the chest is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
content_preview: A 3-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of poor weight gain. She also reports a dusky blue discoloration to his skin during feedings and when crying. On examination, there is a harsh, systolic murmur heard over the left upper sternal border. An x-ray of the chest is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely cause of his symptoms?
hint: The boot-shaped heart on this boy's x-ray is caused by right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH). His harsh, systolic murmur heard over the left upper sternal border is caused by pulmonary stenosis. These findings, along with his acute hypoxic spells (which cause cyanosis), indicate a diagnosis of tetralogy of Fallot (TOF).
learning_objective: Recognize right ventricular outflow obstruction.

answers.content: Persistent connection between the aorta and pulmonary artery
answers.explanation_why: A persistent connection between the aorta and pulmonary artery characterizes a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), an acyanotic heart defect that can cause cyanosis if Eisenmenger syndrome develops. However, patients with a PDA and Eisenmenger syndrome typically develop differential cyanosis because right-to-left shunting through the ductus arteriosus delivers unoxygenated blood distal to the left subclavian artery. Additionally, PDA causes a continuous, machine-like murmur heard throughout systole and diastole (unlike this patient's systolic murmur), and chest x-ray shows a prominent mediastinum caused by an enlarged pulmonary artery and aortic knob (not a boot-shaped heart).

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in patent ductus arteriosus
images.description: In patent ductus arteriosus, there is a left-to-right shunt, with blood flowing from the aorta to the pulmonary arteries during both systole and diastole (1). This shunt leads to volume overload (recirculation) of the blood within the pulmonary vessels, the left atrium, and left ventricle (2). Eventually, because of the increased blood flow to the pulmonary circulation, pulmonary hypertension may develop as well as Eisenmenger syndrome, which involves a shunt reversal. The left-to-right-shunt without cyanosis becomes a right-to-left shunt with cyanosis (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Pink: structures that contain mixed blood

answers.explanation_why: Hypoplasia of the left ventricle is caused by hypoplastic left heart syndrome (HLHS), a heart condition that is typically acyanotic in the early postnatal period because a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) ensures systemic perfusion. Cyanosis develops when the PDA closes, usually within a few days of birth (not as late as 3 months as in this case). Neonates with HLHS also have weak peripheral pulses, hypotension, and metabolic acidosis as the hypoplastic left ventricle cannot maintain adequate cardiac output. Additionally, HLHS does not cause a murmur, and findings on chest x-ray are variable (e.g., small, normal, or enlarged heart and increased pulmonary venous markings) but do not include a boot-shaped heart.

answers.content: Narrowing of the distal aortic arch
answers.explanation_why: Narrowing of the distal aortic arch, or coarctation of the aorta, manifests variably depending on the degree of aortic stenosis (AS) and the presence of a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). Patients with significant AS and PDA present with differential cyanosis because right-to-left shunting through the ductus arteriosus delivers unoxygenated blood distal to the left subclavian artery. Once the PDA closes (usually within a few days after birth), heart failure develops and manifests as dyspnea, sweating during feeds, and poor weight gain. Examination shows pallor (rather than cyanosis), features of inadequate left ventricular output (absent or weak femoral pulses, brachio-femoral delay), and signs of right heart failure (e.g., raised jugular venous pressure, edema, and hepatomegaly). Chest x-ray shows cardiomegaly and increased pulmonary venous markings, not a boot-shaped heart.

images.title: Coarctation of the aorta (hypoplastic type)
images.description: (1) Hypoplasia of aorta can lead to hypertension (↑ BP) in the head and upper limbs as well as poststenotic hypoperfusion. In patent ductus arteriosus, this can be compensated by a right-to-left-shunt of blood from the pulmonary arteries into the aorta, resulting in the flow of mixed blood with decreased oxygen saturation (↓ SaO_2) to the general circulation.(2) After closure of the ductus arteriosus, the right-to-left shunt is absent (~ SaO_2) and there is hypoperfusion (↓ BP) of the abdominal organs and lower extremities with oxygenated blood.

answers.explanation_why:
Right ventricular outflow obstruction (RVOO) in this patient is caused by pulmonary stenosis, which is one of the components of TOF, along with RVH, an overriding aorta, and a ventricular septal defect (VSD). Exertion, such as crying or feeding, increases the RVOO. This results in cyanosis (tet spells) due to right-to-left shunting of deoxygenated blood through the VSD instead of the pulmonary valve, which in turn causes the murmur to become softer. The right ventricle hypertrophies because it chronically pumps against high resistance caused by the RVOO.

Older children with TOF tend to squat during a tet spell. Squatting increases systemic vascular resistance, which increases left ventricular pressure and decreases the right-to-left shunting of blood through the VSD. Infants who are having a tet spell should be placed with their knees toward their chest to achieve the same effect.

images.title: Tetralogy of Fallot
images.description:
Tetralogy of Fallot is the simultaneous occurrence of:
(a) Pulmonary stenosis
(b) Right ventricular hypertrophy
(c) Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
(d) An overriding aorta (above the VSD)The hemodynamic effects depend on the extent of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. With mild obstruction (1), a left-to-right shunt is more pronounced and there is mild cyanosis. With severe obstruction (2), a right-to-left shunt is more pronounced, which results in severe cyanosis. Pulmonary circulation may be supplied via a patent ductus arteriosus.

answers.content: Anatomic reversal of aorta and pulmonary artery
answers.explanation_why: Anatomic reversal of the aorta and pulmonary artery is known as transposition of the great vessels (TGV). This condition causes cyanosis because the aorta arises from the right ventricle and thus results in systemic circulation of deoxygenated blood. However, unlike this patient, cyanosis in TGV manifests immediately after birth. Additionally, chest x-ray in TGV shows an egg-on-a-string appearance due to an enlarged heart with a narrowed mediastinum, which resembles an egg lying on its side.

images.title: Intracardiac shunt in the transposition of the great vessels
images.description: In transposition of the great vessels, deoxygenated blood enters the systemic circulation. Survival after birth is only possible via an intracardiac shunt (e.g., across a patent ductus arteriosus and/or a patent foramen ovale). The shunt diverts oxygenated blood from the pulmonary circulation into the systemic circulation (white arrows).

answers.explanation_why: Tricuspid regurgitation (TR) in infants is usually due to a malformed and displaced tricuspid valve in Ebstein anomaly. These infants may develop cyanosis only if there's an associated ASD or PFO that allows for right-to-left shunting of blood. Auscultation would reveal a holosystolic murmur at the left sternal border, like in this patient, with a widely split S2. However, a chest x-ray in Ebstein anomaly will show right atrial enlargement (due to chronic reflux of blood from the right ventricle into the right atrium) - not a boot-shaped heart as seen in this infant.

images.title: Ebstein anomaly
images.description: In the Ebstein anomaly, the tricuspid valve is displaced into the lumen of the right ventricle, resulting in atrialization of the right ventricle. The remaining ventricle is small and hypocontractile. Because tricuspid valve regurgitation is also usually present, there is retrograde flow in the right atrium, which is dilated by the volume overload, in addition to antegrade pulmonary blood flow. Blood flows through the patent foramen ovale or (commonly associated) atrial septal defect from the right atrium to the left atrium (right-to-left shunt) and then via the left ventricle into the circulation, resulting in pronounced cyanosis. The pulmonary circulation system may also be perfused through blood from the aorta (via the ductus arteriosus).

images.title: Boot-shaped heart in tetralogy of Fallot
images.description: X-ray chest (PA view) of a patient with a history of tetralogy of FallotThe cardiac apex is upturned from right ventricular hypertrophy, and the pulmonary artery segment is small and concave in appearance as a result of pulmonary stenosis. These findings produce a characteristic boot-shaped heart (green overlay; cf. illustration), seen in some patients with tetralogy of Fallot. Pulmonary vascular markings are diminished as a result of reduced blood flow to the lungs.White dashed outline: normal size and shape of the heart

question_text: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of right flank pain. He has a history of diabetes mellitus and peripheral artery disease. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 35 years. His blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows abdominal tenderness and right flank tenderness. An ultrasound shows diffuse dilation of the right ureter and renal pelvis; the left ureter and kidney appear normal. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 68-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of right flank pain. He has a history of diabetes mellitus and peripheral artery disease. He has smoked two packs of cigarettes daily for 35 years. His blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows abdominal tenderness and right flank tenderness. An ultrasound shows diffuse dilation of the right ureter and renal pelvis; the left ureter and kidney appear normal. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?
hint: This patient's unilateral hydronephrosis is most likely caused by urinary tract obstruction.
learning_objective: Recognize iliac artery aneurysm as a cause of unilateral hydronephrosis.

answers.explanation_why: Renal artery stenosis can cause reduced blood flow to the kidneys and result in renal ischemia. Lack of blood flow also causes activation of RAAS, which leads to hypertension. However, renal artery stenosis would not cause abdominal or right flank tenderness. Furthermore, it is not a known cause of hydronephrosis.

The urethra runs through the prostate just distal to the bladder. Enlargement of the prostate, as seen in BPH, can cause blockage of the urethra, resulting in bladder outlet obstruction. Patients with BPH typically present with urinary frequency, urgency, and incontinence, not abdominal pain. Moreover, this type of obstruction would result in bilateral, not unilateral, hydronephrosis.

Polycystic kidney disease can manifest with flank pain and hypertension (due to increased production of renin). However, polycystic kidney disease causes bilateral renal enlargement due to development of numerous cysts in the renal cortex and medulla; unilateral hydronephrosis is not consistent with this condition.

This patient's right flank tenderness, abdominal pain, and hypertension are all symptoms of urinary tract obstruction, which can, over time, lead to hydronephrosis. The middle portion of the ureter runs anterior to the common iliac artery as it enters the pelvis on its way from the kidney to the bladder. Although rare, large aneurysms of the common, external, or internal iliac artery may compress the ureter, causing an extrinsic urinary tract obstruction and resulting in unilateral hydronephrosis.

images.title: Urinary tract and vasculature of the testes

answers.explanation_why: The urethra originates from the bladder. A urethral stricture would result in a bladder outlet obstruction. This type of obstruction would result in bilateral, not unilateral, hydronephrosis.

question_text: A 2300-g (5.07-lb) male newborn is delivered at term to a 39-year-old woman. Examination shows a sloping forehead, a flat nasal bridge, increased interocular distance, low-set ears, a protruding tongue, a single palmar crease and an increased gap between the first and second toe. There are small white and brown spots in the periphery of both irises. The abdomen is distended. An x-ray of the abdomen shows two large air-filled spaces in the upper quadrant. This patient's condition is most likely associated with which of the following cardiac anomalies?
content_preview: A 2300-g (5.07-lb) male newborn is delivered at term to a 39-year-old woman. Examination shows a sloping forehead, a flat nasal bridge, increased interocular distance, low-set ears, a protruding tongue, a single palmar crease and an increased gap between the first and second toe. There are small white and brown spots in the periphery of both irises. The abdomen is distended. An x-ray of the abdomen shows two large air-filled spaces in the upper quadrant. This patient's condition is most likely associated with which of the following cardiac anomalies?
hint: The characteristic morphological features, Brushfield spots in the eye, and the “double bubble” sign on abdominal x-ray (indicating duodenal atresia) are all suggestive of trisomy 21 (Down syndrome).
learning_objective: Recognize atrioventricular septal defect associated with Down syndrome.

answers.explanation_why: A patent ductus arteriosus is most commonly associated with prematurity, fetal alcohol syndrome, birth at high altitude, or congenital rubella infection. Although it occurs in approx. 5% of patients with Down syndrome, it is not the most common congenital cardiac anomaly seen in this condition.

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in patent ductus arteriosus
images.description: In patent ductus arteriosus, there is a left-to-right shunt, with blood flowing from the aorta to the pulmonary arteries during both systole and diastole (1). This shunt leads to volume overload (recirculation) of the blood within the pulmonary vessels, the left atrium, and left ventricle (2). Eventually, because of the increased blood flow to the pulmonary circulation, pulmonary hypertension may develop as well as Eisenmenger syndrome, which involves a shunt reversal. The left-to-right-shunt without cyanosis becomes a right-to-left shunt with cyanosis (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Pink: structures that contain mixed blood

answers.explanation_why: Atrial septal defects (ASDs) are among the most common congenital heart defects and are commonly associated with fetal alcohol syndrome and trisomy 21. Although ASD occurs in approx. 15% of patients with Down syndrome, it is not the most common congenital cardiac anomaly seen in this condition.

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in atrial septal defect
images.description: An atrial septal defect causes blood to flow from the left to the right atrium (left-to-right shunt; white arrow), resulting in volume overload of the right atrium and ventricle (1). As a result, there is dilation and compensatory hypertrophy (double-headed white arrows) of the right atrium and ventricle (2). In the late stages, Eisenmenger syndrome with shunt reversal (right-to-left shunt; white arrow) and cyanosis can occur (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

answers.explanation_why: Atrioventricular septal defects (AVSD; also referred to as endocardial cushion defects) are the most common congenital heart defects in patients with Down syndrome, occurring in about 40% of newborns with trisomy 21. AVSDs are usually diagnosed in the prenatal period, and discovery of an AVSD should warrant prompt genetic testing, as there is a strong association with trisomy 21. Down syndrome is diagnosed in approx. 40–50% of children with AVSD.

Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is the most common cause of cyanotic heart disease in children. Most cases arise sporadically, but approx. 15% of patients with TOF have an underlying genetic syndrome (such as Down syndrome or DiGeorge syndrome). Although it occurs in approx. 5% of patients with Down syndrome, it is not the most common congenital cardiac anomaly seen in this condition.

images.title: Tetralogy of Fallot
images.description:
Tetralogy of Fallot is the simultaneous occurrence of:
(a) Pulmonary stenosis
(b) Right ventricular hypertrophy
(c) Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
(d) An overriding aorta (above the VSD)The hemodynamic effects depend on the extent of right ventricular outflow tract obstruction. With mild obstruction (1), a left-to-right shunt is more pronounced and there is mild cyanosis. With severe obstruction (2), a right-to-left shunt is more pronounced, which results in severe cyanosis. Pulmonary circulation may be supplied via a patent ductus arteriosus.

answers.explanation_why: Ventricular septal defects (VSDs) account for approx. 50% of all congenital heart defects, making them the most common cause of congenital heart disease overall. They are commonly associated with fetal alcohol syndrome, intrauterine infections, and many genetic syndromes (including trisomy 13, trisomy 18, and trisomy 21). Although VSD occurs in approx. 30% of patients with Down syndrome, it is not the most common congenital cardiac anomaly seen in this condition.

images.title: Cardiac hemodynamics in ventricular septal defect
images.description: A defect in the ventricular septum leads to a left-to-right shunt, the volume of which is dependent on the size of the defect. Blood flows from the left ventricle to the right ventricle (white arrow) along the pressure gradient (1). This leads to increased RV and LV preload (due to increased end-diastolic volume), ventricular hypertrophy and dilation (double-headed white arrows), and pulmonary hypertension resulting from excessive pulmonary blood flow (2). In end-stage disease, the pressure gradient is reversed because of Eisenmenger syndrome (shunt reversal), leading to the flow of mixed blood to the systemic circulation (white arrow) and subsequent cyanosis (3).Blue: structures that contain deoxygenated blood; Red: structures that contain oxygenated blood; Purple: structures that contain mixed blood

question_text: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine physical examination. He says that he has felt well except for occasional headaches. He has no history of major medical illness. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 155/90 mm Hg. An ultrasound of the kidneys shows a normal right kidney and a left kidney that is 2 cm smaller in length. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine physical examination. He says that he has felt well except for occasional headaches. He has no history of major medical illness. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 155/90 mm Hg. An ultrasound of the kidneys shows a normal right kidney and a left kidney that is 2 cm smaller in length. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: An atrophic kidney in a patient with new-onset hypertension should raise concern for renal artery stenosis, a narrowing of one or both renal arteries that decreases renal perfusion, which then activates the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system and causes secondary hypertension.
learning_objective: Recognize renal artery stenosis, and recall its diagnostic finding.

answers.explanation_why: Elevated urinary metanephrines are diagnostic of pheochromocytoma, which can cause new-onset hypertension and headaches. However, pheochromocytoma appears as a solid or cystic lesion in the adrenal glands on imaging rather than renal atrophy.

An abnormal swishing sound heard on auscultation over a blood vessel is referred to as a bruit. It reflects the turbulence of the blood flow in a stenosed vascular segment. The abdominal bruit of renal artery stenosis is continuous (occurs during systole and diastole) and can be auscultated over the costovertebral angles of the flank and/or over the epigastrium, 2–3 cm lateral to the midline.

Polycythemia (due to production of erythropoietin) and new-onset hypertension (due to production of renin) can develop as paraneoplastic phenomena in patients with renal cell carcinoma (RCC). However, RCC usually appears as a mass on imaging rather than renal atrophy.

Hematuria and new-onset hypertension can develop in patients with renal cell carcinoma (RCC) or nephritic syndrome. However, neither of these conditions causes renal atrophy. RCC appears as a mass on imaging; nephritic syndrome is not associated with specific ultrasound findings.

Varicoceles are classically caused by compression of the venous system that drains the testicle (e.g., due to renal cell carcinoma). RCC can cause new-onset hypertension (due to production of renin) but appears as a mass on imaging rather than renal atrophy.

question_text: A 44-year-old woman with recurrent urinary tract infections is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after sudden onset of severe headache 30 minutes ago. She has a history of occasional, mild headaches in the morning. There is no other history of serious illness. Both her father and her paternal grandmother died of chronic kidney disease. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.1°F) and blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows neck stiffness. When her hip is flexed, she is unable to fully extend her knee because of pain. Lumbar puncture performed 12 hours after headache onset yields 10 mL of yellow-colored fluid with no leukocytes. Which of the following is the most likely predisposing factor for this patient's current condition?
content_preview: A 44-year-old woman with recurrent urinary tract infections is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after sudden onset of severe headache 30 minutes ago. She has a history of occasional, mild headaches in the morning. There is no other history of serious illness. Both her father and her paternal grandmother died of chronic kidney disease. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.1°F) and blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg. Physical examination shows neck stiffness. When her hip is flexed, she is unable to fully extend her knee because of pain. Lumbar puncture performed 12 hours after headache onset yields 10 mL of yellow-colored fluid with no leukocytes. Which of the following is the most likely predisposing factor for this patient's current condition?
hint: Signs of arterial hypertension (e.g., morning headaches), frequent UTIs, and a family history of renal failure should raise concern for autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD), whereas a positive Kernig sign indicates meningeal or nerve root irritation.
learning_objective: Recognize autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, and recall its complications.

answers.explanation_why: While chronic kidney disease (e.g., polycystic kidney disease) increases the risk of atherosclerosis, which in turn is a risk factor for ischemic stroke, this patient does not have focal neurologic findings suggestive of a stroke. Ischemic stroke typically manifests with sudden painless neurological impairments that may be accompanied by a mild headache, unlike this patient who presented with a sudden severe headache. A sudden-onset severe headache indicates subarachnoid hemorrhage, which can cause hemorrhagic stroke instead of ischemic stroke.

While this patient has meningismus, she does not have a fever or leukocytes on CSF suggestive of meningitis. She is also not in a high-risk group for contracting meningitis (unvaccinated, college age and living in close quarters, or immunocompromised). In addition, there is no association between polycystic kidney disease and meningitis.

While a hypercoagulable state can increase the risk of a thromboembolic stroke, this patient does not have focal neurologic findings suggestive of a stroke. Ischemic stroke typically presents with sudden painless neurological impairments that may be accompanied by a mild headache, unlike this patient who presented with a sudden severe headache. A sudden-onset severe headache indicates subarachnoid hemorrhage, which can cause hemorrhagic stroke instead of ischemic stroke. In addition, polycystic kidney disease does not increase the risk of hypercoagulability.

Cerebral atrophy increases the risk of a subdural hemorrhage (SDH), which can manifest with worsening headache. This patient, however, has no risk factors for cerebral atrophy (advanced age, dementia, preceding trauma), and there is no link between polycystic kidney disease and cerebral atrophy or SDH. Moreover, SDH usually does not have a sudden onset. Instead, it tends to manifest with headache and confusion over hours to weeks that is possibly accompanied by impaired consciousness and focal neurological deficit.

Patients with ADPKD have an increased risk of developing saccular aneurysms. This patient presented with symptoms of a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) resulting from the rupture of one of these aneurysms. The sudden onset of a severe headache (patients typically report having the worst headache of their life) should raise suspicion for SAH. Other signs of SAH include fever, xanthochromia (yellow-colored CSF), and meningismus (neck stiffness and Kernig sign) caused by irritation of the meninges by blood.

images.title: Subarachnoid hemorrhage
images.description: A nontraumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage is most commonly caused by the rupture of a cerebral aneurysm.

question_text: A 71-year-old man with hypertension is taken to the emergency department after the sudden onset of stabbing abdominal pain that radiates to the back. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. His pulse is 120/min and thready, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 82/54 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a periumbilical, pulsatile mass and abdominal bruit. There is epigastric tenderness. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's current condition?
content_preview: A 71-year-old man with hypertension is taken to the emergency department after the sudden onset of stabbing abdominal pain that radiates to the back. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years. His pulse is 120/min and thready, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 82/54 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a periumbilical, pulsatile mass and abdominal bruit. There is epigastric tenderness. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's current condition?
hint: Abdominal pain radiating to the back, a pulsatile abdominal mass, and new-onset hypotension in a man with a history of smoking and hypertension should raise concerns for a certain pathology.
learning_objective: Recognize a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm, and recall its pathophysiology.

answers.explanation_why: Coronary atherosclerosis resulting in narrowing of the vessel lumen is involved in the pathophysiology of angina pectoris and myocardial infarction (MI). Coronary atherosclerosis leads to narrowing of the arterial lumen, which decreases the blood flow to the myocardium. During exercise, myocardial flow is unable to meet increased myocardial demand, which causes myocardial ischemia and symptoms of angina. While smoking increases the risk for MI, this man's history of acute onset, stabbing abdominal pain with an umbilical mass and hypotension suggest a different disease process.

This patient most likely has a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). The pathophysiology of AAA is not fully understood, but numerous genetic and environmental factors, such as smoking, are believed to cause inflammation and proteolysis of connective tissue within the aortic wall. This leads to loss of structural integrity and weakening of the aorta. Other risk factors for AAA include advanced age and male sex. When high aortic wall stress is applied, as in hypertension, further weakening, widening, and rupture of the aortic wall can occur. AAAs are most commonly located below the renal arteries (infrarenal).

images.title: Ruptured aortic aneurysm
images.description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT abdomen (with contrast; arterial phase; axial plane)An infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm is measured as 8 cm in transverse diameter. Contrast extravasation (dashed outline) is seen on the left side at the site of rupture (arrowhead). A large left retroperitoneal hematoma (yellow overlay) extends inferiorly into the inguinal canal. Additional intraperitoneal fluid is seen in the pelvis and right upper quadrant (red overlay).

answers.explanation_why: Mesenteric atherosclerosis is involved in the pathophysiology of chronic mesenteric ischemia, in which intestinal blood flow is reduced. In the postprandial period, there is a mismatch between low splanchnic blood flow and high intestinal metabolic demand, which leads to postprandial ischemia and abdominal pain within one hour of eating. Bloating, nausea, and weight loss due to food aversion are common symptoms. This patient has acute-onset, stabbing abdominal pain with an umbilical mass and hypotension, features that suggest a different, more emergent disease process.

Gastric mucosal ulceration is involved in the pathophysiology of peptic ulcer disease. One of the complications of this disease is gastric or duodenal perforation, which manifests with sudden onset, stabbing abdominal pain, and distention that can progress to peritonitis. This patient's periumbilical mass, abdominal bruit, and hypotension are inconsistent with a perforated duodenal or gastric ulcer.

Abdominal wall defects can predispose patients to hernia formation. Uncomplicated hernias are typically asymptomatic and occur when intraabdominal contents protrude through congenital defects or areas of weakness in the abdominal wall. Complicated hernias include incarcerated hernias (irreducible), strangulated hernias (disrupted blood supply), or obstructed hernias (kinked intestine), and typically manifest with acute pain at the site of the hernia and possible bowel obstruction. Although this patient has a periumbilical mass, he also has an abdominal bruit and hypotension, suggesting a different etiology for his symptoms.

Portal vein stasis predisposes patients to the formation of acute portal vein thrombosis, which manifests with right upper quadrant or generalized abdominal pain. Portal vein thrombosis often arises as a complication of cirrhosis, but this patient lacks symptoms of chronic liver disease (jaundice, pruritus, hepatosplenomegaly, telangiectasias, caput medusae, gynecomastia). Furthermore, this patient's periumbilical mass and abdominal bruit suggest a different cause for his symptoms.

question_text: A 63-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of difficulty swallowing, low-grade fever, and weight loss. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. An esophagogastroduodenoscopy shows an esophageal mass just distal to the upper esophageal sphincter. Microscopic examination confirms the diagnosis of locally invasive squamous cell carcinoma. A surgical resection is planned. Which of the following structures is at greatest risk for injury during this procedure?
content_preview: A 63-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of difficulty swallowing, low-grade fever, and weight loss. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. An esophagogastroduodenoscopy shows an esophageal mass just distal to the upper esophageal sphincter. Microscopic examination confirms the diagnosis of locally invasive squamous cell carcinoma. A surgical resection is planned. Which of the following structures is at greatest risk for injury during this procedure?
hint: This patient presents with squamous cell carcinoma in the cervical portion of the esophagus.
learning_objective: Recall the blood supply of the cervical esophagus.

answers.explanation_why: The esophageal branch of thoracic aorta supplies the thoracic portion of the esophagus, which extends between the thoracic inlet and the gastroesophageal junction. A different structure is at higher risk of injury given the location of the mass.

The left inferior phrenic artery originates from the aorta and supplies the abdominal portion of the esophagus, which is located below the esophageal hiatus of the diaphragm. A different structure is at higher risk of injury given the location of the mass.

images.title: Branches of the abdominal aorta
images.description:
There are:
- 3 single anterior branches: celiac artery, superior mesenteric artery, and inferior mesenteric artery
- 8 paired lateral branches (right and left): inferior phrenic arteries, middle suprarenal arteries, renal arteries, gonadal (testicular/ovarian) arteries, and 4 pairs of lumbar arteries
- 3 terminal branches: right and left common iliac arteries and the median sacral artery (the latter is not shown in the image)Note that the superior suprarenal artery originates from the inferior phrenic artery, while the inferior suprarenal artery originates from the renal artery.

answers.explanation_why: The inferior thyroid artery originates from the thyrocervical trunk, a branch of the subclavian artery. It supplies the cervical portion of the esophagus, which is 6–8 cm long and extends between the hypopharynx (lower border of the cricoid cartilage) and the thoracic inlet (suprasternal notch). Since this tumor is located in the cervical portion of the esophagus, care should be taken to avoid injuring this artery during the surgery.

images.title: Blood supply of the esophagus
images.description: The three different portions of the esophagus are supplied and drained by different vessels:The cervical esophagus is supplied by esophageal branches of the inferior thyroid artery and drains via esophageal veins into the inferior thyroid vein.The thoracic esophagus is supplied by esophageal branches from the thoracic aorta and drains via esophageal veins into the azygos and hemiazygos veins.The abdominal esophagus is supplied by esophageal branches of the left gastric artery and drains via the esophageal veins into the left gastric vein.

answers.explanation_why: The left gastric artery originates from the celiac trunk and supplies the abdominal portion of the esophagus, which is located below the esophageal hiatus of the diaphragm.

images.title: Branches of the celiac trunk
images.description: The celiac trunk and its three major branches: the left gastric artery, the splenic artery, and the common hepatic artery

answers.explanation_why: The bronchial branch of the thoracic aorta supplies parts of the trachea, bronchi, and thoracic portion of the esophagus, which extends between the thoracic inlet and the gastroesophageal junction. A different structure is at higher risk of injury given the location of the mass.

question_text: A 78-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 4-hour history of abdominal pain. Abdominal examination shows guarding with diffuse rebound tenderness. A CT scan of the abdomen shows an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm that extends down to the level of the L4 vertebra and a partial filling defect in the anterior wall of the aneurysm. Which of the following bowel regions is at greatest risk for requiring resection?
content_preview: A 78-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 4-hour history of abdominal pain. Abdominal examination shows guarding with diffuse rebound tenderness. A CT scan of the abdomen shows an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm that extends down to the level of the L4 vertebra and a partial filling defect in the anterior wall of the aneurysm. Which of the following bowel regions is at greatest risk for requiring resection?
hint: The renal arteries originate from the lateral surface of the aorta at the level of the L2 vertebra. The inferior mesenteric artery (IMA) arises from the anterior surface of the aorta at the level of the L3 vertebra. Occlusion at the opening of the IMA by a thrombus within an aortic aneurysm (suggested by the filling defect) would cause acute mesenteric ischemia and, potentially, necrosis of the bowel segments supplied by this artery.
learning_objective: Recognize acute mesenteric ischemia, and recall the vascular supply of the colon.

answers.content: Splenic flexure, descending colon, and sigmoid colon
answers.explanation_why: The splenic flexure, descending colon, and sigmoid colon, which are supplied by the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA), are most at risk for requiring surgical resection in this patient's case. The IMA also supplies the rectum and the region of the anal canal above the pectinate line via the superior rectal artery.

images.title: Watershed areas in colon ischemia
images.description: The watershed areas of the colon are the splenic flexure (Griffiths point) and the rectosigmoid junction (Sudeck point).The splenic flexure is supplied by the ascending branch of the left colic artery (from the inferior mesenteric artery) and the marginal artery of Drummond (an anastomosis between terminal branches of the superior and the inferior mesenteric arteries).The rectosigmoid junction is supplied by an anastomosis between the last sigmoid branch of the inferior mesenteric artery and the terminal branches of the superior rectal artery (also from the inferior mesenteric artery).

answers.content: Hepatic flexure, transverse colon, and splenic flexure
answers.explanation_why: The hepatic flexure, transverse colon, and splenic flexure are predominantly supplied by the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) via the middle colic artery and the left colic branch of the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA). The SMA arises anteriorly at the level of the L1 vertebra, above the level of the renal arteries. Although this patient is likely to have an occlusion of the IMA, the SMA would not be affected because his aneurysm and filling defect are infrarenal. Therefore, this combination of bowel regions is less likely to be affected in this patient's case.

The cecum, ileum, and distal jejunum are supplied by the superior mesenteric artery (SMA), which arises anteriorly from the aorta at the level of the L1 vertebra, above the level of origin of the renal arteries. As this patient's aneurysm and filling defect are infrarenal, this combination of bowel regions would not be affected.

answers.content: Cecum, ascending colon, and hepatic flexure
answers.explanation_why: The cecum, ascending colon, and hepatic flexure are supplied by the right colic branch of the superior mesenteric artery (SMA). The SMA arises anteriorly from the aorta at the level of the L1 vertebra, above the origin of the renal arteries. As this patient's aneurysm and filling defect are infrarenal, this combination of bowel regions would not be affected.

answers.content: Ascending colon, cecum, and distal ileum
answers.explanation_why: The ascending colon, cecum, and distal ileum are supplied by the ileocolic and right colic branches of the superior mesenteric artery (SMA), which arises anteriorly from the aorta at the level of the L1 vertebra, above the level of origin of the renal arteries. As this patient's aneurysm and filling defect are infrarenal, this combination of bowel regions would not be affected.

question_text: A 65-year-old woman with atrial fibrillation comes to the emergency department because of sudden-onset severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting for the past 2 hours. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 25 years. Her pulse is 110/min and blood pressure is 141/98 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows diffuse abdominal tenderness without guarding or rebound. A CT angiogram of the abdomen confirms an acute occlusion in the inferior mesenteric artery. Which of the following structures of the gastrointestinal tract is most likely to be affected in this patient?
content_preview: A 65-year-old woman with atrial fibrillation comes to the emergency department because of sudden-onset severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting for the past 2 hours. She has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 25 years. Her pulse is 110/min and blood pressure is 141/98 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows diffuse abdominal tenderness without guarding or rebound. A CT angiogram of the abdomen confirms an acute occlusion in the inferior mesenteric artery. Which of the following structures of the gastrointestinal tract is most likely to be affected in this patient?
hint: Given this patient's acute presentation, history of atrial fibrillation, and severe abdominal pain, she most likely has colonic ischemia due to an embolism. Ischemia is most likely to occur in the watershed areas of the colon.
learning_objective: Recognize that the rectosigmoid colon is affected by inferior mesenteric artery occlusion.

answers.explanation_why: The rectosigmoid colon is supplied by the sigmoid artery and the superior rectal artery, which are branches of the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA). The effects of reduction or cessation of blood flow to the colon are particularly prominent at the watershed areas of the colon (i.e., rectosigmoid colon and splenic flexure), where collateral blood flow is limited. During acute ischemic events, the lack of collateral blood supply renders these regions particularly prone to ischemia.

images.title: Watershed areas in colon ischemia
images.description: The watershed areas of the colon are the splenic flexure (Griffiths point) and the rectosigmoid junction (Sudeck point).The splenic flexure is supplied by the ascending branch of the left colic artery (from the inferior mesenteric artery) and the marginal artery of Drummond (an anastomosis between terminal branches of the superior and the inferior mesenteric arteries).The rectosigmoid junction is supplied by an anastomosis between the last sigmoid branch of the inferior mesenteric artery and the terminal branches of the superior rectal artery (also from the inferior mesenteric artery).

answers.explanation_why: The terminal ileum is predominantly supplied by the ileocolic artery (a branch of the superior mesenteric artery) and would, therefore, not be affected by occlusion in the inferior mesenteric artery.

The hepatic flexure, which is located between the ascending and the transverse colon, is supplied by branches of the superior mesenteric artery (SMA). It would therefore not be affected by an occlusion in the inferior mesenteric artery (IMA).

The lower rectum (below the pectinate line) has an extensive blood supply by the middle rectal artery (arises from the internal iliac artery) and inferior rectal artery (arises from the internal pudendal artery). The lower rectum would not be affected by occlusion in the inferior mesenteric artery.

The ascending colon is predominantly supplied by the right colic artery (a branch of the superior mesenteric artery) and would, therefore, not be affected by occlusion in the inferior mesenteric artery.

The transverse colon is predominantly supplied by the middle colic artery (a branch of the superior mesenteric artery) and would, therefore, not be affected by occlusion in the inferior mesenteric artery.

question_text: A 62-year-old woman with a history of subarachnoid hemorrhage is brought to the emergency department because of shortness of breath and sharp chest pain that worsens on inspiration. She underwent surgery for a hip fracture 3 weeks ago. Her pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 112/74 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. The lungs are clear to auscultation and there is no jugular venous distention. A ventilation and perfusion scan shows a small perfusion defect in the left lower lung. A drug with which of the following mechanisms of action is most appropriate for this patient?
content_preview: A 62-year-old woman with a history of subarachnoid hemorrhage is brought to the emergency department because of shortness of breath and sharp chest pain that worsens on inspiration. She underwent surgery for a hip fracture 3 weeks ago. Her pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 112/74 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 92%. The lungs are clear to auscultation and there is no jugular venous distention. A ventilation and perfusion scan shows a small perfusion defect in the left lower lung. A drug with which of the following mechanisms of action is most appropriate for this patient?
hint: This patient's presentation of chest pain and dyspnea in combination with her recent surgery (suggestive of immobilization) and perfusion defect makes the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism very likely.
learning_objective: Recognize pulmonary embolism, and choose the most appropriate anticoagulant mechanism of action.

answers.content: Inhibition of vitamin K epoxide reductase
answers.explanation_why: Inhibition of vitamin K epoxide reductase prevents any further γ-carboxylation of vitamin K-dependent coagulation factors and is the mechanism of action of warfarin. Because previously γ-carboxylated factors are still present, the anticoagulative effect does not occur immediately. Therefore, warfarin is the drug given for long-term anticoagulation (e.g., post-MI, heart valve damage, atrial fibrillation, arrhythmias). However, anticoagulation therapy of pulmonary embolism must be started immediately.

Irreversible inhibition of COX 1 and 2 decreases synthesis of thromboxane A2, which in turn inhibits platelet aggregation. This is the mechanism of action of acetylsalicylic acid (ASA). In higher dosage, it has also an antipyretic and analgesic effect. Low-dose aspirin is used in the management of cardiovascular events (e.g., acute MI, angina) and for primary/secondary prophylaxis of cardiovascular disease. However, it is not used for initial treatment of pulmonary embolism.

Irreversible inhibition of ADP receptors (P2Y12), which prevents the expression of glycoproteins IIb/IIIa on the surface of the platelets and thereby inhibits platelet aggregation, is the mechanism of some ADP receptor inhibitors such as clopidogrel, prasugrel, and ticlopidine (not ticagrelor, which is reversible). These drugs are used in the treatment of acute coronary syndrome and peripheral arterial disease as well as in the prevention of ischemic stroke. However, they are not used for initial treatment of pulmonary embolism.

The activation of plasminogen is its conversion to plasmin, which is the main enzyme responsible for clot breakdown. This is the mechanism of action of recombinant tissue plasminogen activators (e.g., alteplase, reteplase, tenecteplase). They are used in patients with acute coronary syndrome, pulmonary embolism, or ischemic stroke. Fibrinolysis might be necessary for massive, life-threatening pulmonary embolism (causing hypotension or hemodynamic instability). However, this patient does not present with signs of severe pulmonary embolism. In addition, her history of subarachnoid hemorrhage is an absolute contraindication to treatment with tPA.

Antithrombin III is a non-vitamin K-dependent protease that cleaves factors IIa, IXa, Xa, thereby inhibiting the coagulation cascade. The activity of this enzyme is potentiated by heparin, which is indicated as initial anticoagulation therapy in patients with pulmonary embolism, thrombosis, unstable angina pectoris, and disseminated intravascular coagulation. Two forms of heparin in clinical use are low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) and unfractionated heparin (UFH). LMWH is preferred as it binds selectively to antithrombin III and has lower risk of side effects.
