question_text: A 41-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 10-day history of generalized weakness. He has also had headaches and night sweats and is a known user of illicit intravenous drugs. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 127/78 mm Hg. There are several track marks on his forearms. A holosystolic murmur that increases on inspiration is heard along the left sternal border. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 13,900/mm^3 and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 58 mm/h. Which of the following is the most likely consequence of this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 41-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 10-day history of generalized weakness. He has also had headaches and night sweats and is a known user of illicit intravenous drugs. His temperature is 39.1°C (102.4°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 127/78 mm Hg. There are several track marks on his forearms. A holosystolic murmur that increases on inspiration is heard along the left sternal border. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 13,900/mm3 and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 58 mm/h. Which of the following is the most likely consequence of this patient's condition?
hint: The patient uses illicit IV drugs and presents with fever, tricuspid regurgitation, and leukocytosis. This combination is highly suggestive of acute right-sided infective endocarditis (IE).
learning_objective: Recognize acute right-sided infective endocarditis, and recall its complications.

answers.explanation_why: Hematuria is caused by a wide range of conditions, including trauma, infections, malignant tumors, and ischemia. Renal damage in IE is primarily caused by two mechanisms: Septic embolization can lead to renal artery occlusion with subsequent ischemia and renal damage, while immunoglobulin and complement deposition in the glomerulus can lead to glomerulonephritis. Although a septic embolism can cause renal injury in IE, this complication is more common in left-sided involvement.

answers.content: Painless macules and papules on palms and soles
answers.explanation_why: In IE, painless macules and papules on the palms and soles are known as Janeway lesions. These occur more commonly in left-sided IE than right-sided IE.

images.title: Janeway lesions
images.description: Multiple erythematous macules are visible on the thenar eminence and the base of the thumb.These Janeway lesions are typically caused by septic microembolisms secondary to infective endocarditis.

answers.explanation_why: Splinter hemorrhages are caused by the rupture of capillaries in the nail bed and are seen in various conditions, including trauma, IE, antiphospholipid antibody syndrome, and trichinosis. Patients with left-sided endocarditis are more likely to have splinter hemorrhages than those with right-sided endocarditis.

images.title: Splinter hemorrhages in endocarditis
images.description: The vertical hemorrhages (arrowheads) underneath this patient's fingernails are most commonly caused by trauma but can also occur as a result of immune complex deposition or microthrombosis in subacute, infective endocarditis, SLE, or rheumatoid arthritis.

answers.explanation_why: Retinal hemorrhages occur in a variety of diseases, including central retinal vein occlusion, malignant hypertension, retinal detachment, subarachnoid hemorrhage, and IE (where they are known as Roth spots). However, peripheral manifestations such as retinal hemorrhages are not commonly observed in patients with right-sided IE.

IV drug users such as this patient are at increased risk of IE because the use of nonsterile syringes can lead to bacteremia. Bacterial colonization of the heart valves can lead to the formation of thrombi and subsequent bacterial emboli. While right heart involvement is rare in IE, IV drug users are at an increased risk of tricuspid or multiple valvular involvement. Thrombi from the right heart most frequently dislodge into the lung, which puts the patient at risk of pulmonary embolism. Patients with left-sided (aortic valve or mitral valve) endocarditis more commonly present with emboli to the retina (i.e., Roth spots), extremities (e.g., Janeway lesions, Osler nodes, splinter hemorrhages), kidney, brain, and spleen.

answers.content: Painful nodules on pads of the fingers
answers.explanation_why: Painful nodules on the pads of the fingers (also known as Osler nodes), which are caused by the deposition of immune complexes in the skin, are a rare but highly suggestive finding in IE. However, peripheral manifestations such as Osler nodes are not commonly observed in patients with right-sided endocarditis. Moreover, Osler nodes typically occur in protracted cases of IE, whereas this patient presents with acute IE.

images.title: Osler nodes
images.description: There are multiple raised nodular lesions on the palm and palmar aspects of the first and second digits. The lesions appear dark brown, indicating subcutaneous hemorrhages.This is the typical appearance of Osler nodes.

question_text: Three hours after undergoing a total right hip replacement, a 71-year-old woman has tingling around the lips and numbness in her fingertips. Her surgery was complicated by unintentional laceration of the right femoral artery that resulted in profuse bleeding. She appears uncomfortable. Examination shows an adducted thumb, extended fingers, and flexed metacarpophalangeal joints and wrists. Tapping on the cheeks leads to contraction of the facial muscles. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: Three hours after undergoing a total right hip replacement, a 71-year-old woman has tingling around the lips and numbness in her fingertips. Her surgery was complicated by unintentional laceration of the right femoral artery that resulted in profuse bleeding. She appears uncomfortable. Examination shows an adducted thumb, extended fingers, and flexed metacarpophalangeal joints and wrists. Tapping on the cheeks leads to contraction of the facial muscles. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient's numbness of her fingers and perioral region, carpopedal spasm, and positive Chvostek sign are indicative of hypocalcemia.
learning_objective: Recognize hypocalcemia due to calcium chelation.

answers.explanation_why: Acute kidney injury (AKI) is unlikely to cause the acute hypocalcemia seen in this patient even though profuse bleeding and subsequent systemic hypotension puts her at risk for AKI (or a clinical prerenal azotemia). However, secondary hyperparathyroidism resulting in normal to decreased serum calcium levels is often seen in patients with chronic kidney disease.

The chelation of calcium by citrate is the cause of hypocalcemia following massive blood transfusion. Citrate is an anticoagulant that is central to the storage of blood products. During transfusion, citrate prevents activation of the clotting cascade by chelating free extracellular calcium (a necessary cofactor for many steps in the coagulation cascade), resulting in transient hypocalcemia post-transfusion. In patients with symptomatic hypocalcemia, as seen here, calcium replacement therapy must be administered.

Because about half of the total serum calcium is bound to proteins, hypoalbuminemia will decrease the total calcium levels. However, ionized (or free) calcium concentrations are regulated hormonally and thus will not be affected. Since only ionized calcium is biologically active, hypocalcemia due to hypoalbuminemia usually is asymptomatic (pseudohypocalcemia) and would not explain this patient's symptoms.

Intravascular hemolysis following massive blood transfusion is concerning for an acute hemolytic transfusion reaction due to ABO incompatibility. Affected patients will present within 1 hour of transfusion with hyperkalemia and hyperphosphatemia, caused by destruction of donor RBCs by recipient antibodies. Symptoms include fever, flushing, pruritus, flank pain, dyspnea and a burning pain at the IV site; none of which are present in this patient. Hemoglobinuria and subsequent renal tubular necrosis may follow. Hypocalcemia, however, does not typically occur as part of an acute hemolytic transfusion reaction.
answers.explanation_but: An acute hemolytic transfusion reaction requires immediate cessation of transfusion and supportive care.

answers.explanation_why: Parathyroid ischemia leads to hypocalcemia due to decreased release of parathyroid hormone. The most common cause is damage to the parathyroid glands during anterior midline surgeries or thyroidectomies. Although this patient's profuse bleeding and subsequent systemic hypotension may have caused tissue ischemia, a selective affection of the parathyroid glands is unlikely, as watershed areas in the GI tract and brain are far more susceptible to ischemia.

Metabolic acidosis reduces the affinity of albumin to bind calcium in the serum, resulting in increased serum levels of ionized (or free) calcium levels, i.e. hypercalcemia. Unlike this patient's presentation, hypercalcemia manifests with symptoms such as bone pain, myalgia, abdominal pain, constipation, polyuria, and neuropsychiatric abnormalities. Symptomatic hypocalcemia could, however, be caused by metabolic alkalosis leading to an increased albumin-calcium binding.

question_text: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe dyspnea, cough, and pleuritic chest pain for 20 minutes. Three weeks ago, she underwent surgery for a total right knee replacement. The patient appears distressed. Her pulse is 112/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 88/55 mm Hg. Examination shows jugular venous distention. There is a mildly tender surgical scar on her right knee. A CT scan of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
content_preview: A 57-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe dyspnea, cough, and pleuritic chest pain for 20 minutes. Three weeks ago, she underwent surgery for a total right knee replacement. The patient appears distressed. Her pulse is 112/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 88/55 mm Hg. Examination shows jugular venous distention. There is a mildly tender surgical scar on her right knee. A CT scan of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
hint: Orthopedic surgeries, such as a total knee replacement, often cause prolonged immobilization. This is a significant risk factor for venous stasis.
learning_objective: Recognize massive pulmonary embolism, and choose the most appropriate treatment.

answers.explanation_why: Endovascular stent-grafting can be used in the treatment of type A (proximal) aortic dissection. Patients typically present with severe, tearing chest pain, hypertension, and asymmetric pulses. Hypotension, severe dyspnea, and cough are less common manifestations of type A aortic dissection. The patient's CT scan also shows a vascular filling defect consistent with a pulmonary embolism rather than a tear in the aortic intima, which would be typical in a case of dissection.

images.title: Aortic dissection (Stanford A)
images.description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT angiography (chest; ECG-gated; venous and arterial phases; axial plane) of a patient with a history of recent weakness, vertigo, and facial swellingThe ascending aorta is dilated and a Stanford type A (DeBakey type II) aortic dissection is seen. The aortic arch and descending aorta are not affected. The right and left coronary, the innominate, the left common carotid, and the subclavian arteries originate from the true lumen (green overlay; false lumen is red overlay). Facial swelling is the result of venous congestion from compression of the superior vena cava (blue overlay) by the dilated ascending aorta. Bilateral small pleural effusions are seen.Additional findings include sternotomy wires, a prosthetic aortic valve, atherosclerotic calcifications, pancreatic calcifications, and a small hiatal hernia.LCA: left coronary artery; RCA: right coronary artery; yellow overlay: azygos vein

answers.explanation_why: Tube thoracostomy is used in the treatment of tension pneumothorax, which can manifest with dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, cough, jugular venous distension, and hypotension. However, her CT scan shows a vascular filling defect consistent with a pulmonary embolism rather than air in the pleural space with tracheal deviation, which is typical in cases of tension pneumothorax.

This patient's CT scan shows evidence of a large pulmonary embolism (PE). In cases of massive PE with hemodynamic instability (e.g., SBP < 90 mm Hg), thrombolysis with recombinant tissue plasminogen activators (tPA) such as alteplase is indicated. Because of the associated significant risk of bleeding, there are several relative and absolute contraindications to thrombolytic therapy. Surgery within the past 10 days is a relative contraindication, but this patient underwent surgery 3 weeks ago. Therefore, alteplase would be the most appropriate treatment. Anticoagulation with heparin, rivaroxaban, warfarin, or apixaban is also appropriate treatment for patients with PE. However, these agents are typically used in patients who remain hemodynamically stable.

Piperacillin/tazobactam can be used in the treatment of pneumonia. Pneumonia can manifest with dyspnea and cough, and, in the setting of sepsis, even hypotension. However, jugular venous distension would not be expected in pneumonia. In addition, this patient's CT scan shows a vascular filling defect consistent with a pulmonary embolism rather than parenchymal infiltrates and/or consolidation, which would be typical in a case of pneumonia.

Coronary angioplasty is used in the treatment of myocardial infarction (MI). MI can manifest with chest pain, jugular venous distension, and hypotension. However, her CT scan shows a vascular filling defect consistent with a pulmonary embolism. In addition, a CT scan is typically not diagnostic in cases of myocardial infarction.

Bumetanide is a diuretic used in the treatment of pulmonary edema. Pulmonary edema can manifest with dyspnea, cough, tachypnea, and jugular venous distension. However, her CT scan shows a vascular filling defect that is consistent with a pulmonary embolism rather than the findings typically seen in pulmonary edema (i.e., ground-glass opacities and peribronchovascular interstitial thickening). In addition, administering a diuretic could be detrimental to a patient with hypotension.

Pericardiocentesis is a procedure used to treat patients with pericardial effusion and cardiac tamponade. Cardiac tamponade can manifest with dyspnea, chest pain, hypotension, and jugular venous distension. However, her CT scan shows a vascular filling defect consistent with PE, as opposed to a fluid-filled pericardial sac, which would be typical in a patient with tamponade. Furthermore, pericardiocentesis would pose a risk of myocardial or endocardial injury in a patient who does not have pericardial effusion.

images.title: Saddle pulmonary embolism
images.description: CT chest (with contrast; axial plane)A large embolism burden is seen (green overlay), with extension across the bifurcation of the pulmonary trunk into the right and left pulmonary arteries.Straddling of the pulmonary trunk bifurcation by pulmonary embolism is sometimes referred to as saddle embolism.AA: ascending aorta; DA: descending aorta; E: esophagus; LMB: left main bronchus; LPA: left pulmonary artery; PT: pulmonary trunk; RMB: right main bronchus; RPA: right pulmonary artery; SVC: superior vena cava

question_text: A 29-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0 at 11 weeks' gestation comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of left lower extremity pain and swelling. Her temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F). Physical examination shows a tender, palpable cord on the lateral aspect of the left lower leg. The overlying skin is erythematous and indurated. Duplex ultrasound shows vascular wall thickening and subcutaneous edema. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
content_preview: A 29-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0 at 11 weeks' gestation comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of left lower extremity pain and swelling. Her temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F). Physical examination shows a tender, palpable cord on the lateral aspect of the left lower leg. The overlying skin is erythematous and indurated. Duplex ultrasound shows vascular wall thickening and subcutaneous edema. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
hint: A variant of this patient's condition is Trousseau syndrome, in which palpable, tender cords recur at different locations on the body.
learning_objective: Recognize superficial thrombophlebitis.

answers.explanation_why: DVT manifests with diffuse swelling, tenderness, and redness of the affected extremity. There is a higher risk of DVT during pregnancy because of an increase in coagulability and venous stasis. However, DVT would not show signs of inflammation (a tender, palpable cord with local erythema and induration or elevated temperature), and duplex ultrasound would not show vascular wall thickening or subcutaneous edema.

images.title: Deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
images.description: There is diffuse edema and erythema of the right leg and foot. The diameter of the right calf is visibly greater than that of the left.These features are typical of DVT. Clinical history and investigations (e.g., Doppler ultrasonography, D-dimer levels) help distinguish between DVT and cellulitis, which also manifests with a painful, warm, erythematous, and edematous leg.

answers.explanation_why: Erysipelas is a superficial skin infection typically caused by group A streptococci (S. pyogenes). Patients present with fever and localized, tender streaks on the skin. However, these streaks manifest as sharply-demarcated, bright-red patches, and not as a palpable cord. Additionally, duplex ultrasound might show inflammation of lymphatic vessels but not vascular wall thickening.

images.title: Erysipelas
images.description: Extensive, sharply demarcated erythema with swelling, bullae, and necrosis is visible on the right anterior distal forearm and wrist.

answers.explanation_why: Erythema nodosum is an inflammation of subcutaneous fat leading to the formation of painful nodules on the lower extremities and possibly an elevated temperature. It can occur during pregnancy, likely due to a delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction. However, erythema nodosum usually manifests with skin nodules on the shins, not with a palpable cord on the lateral aspect of the left lower leg. Additionally, duplex ultrasound would not show vascular wall thickening.

images.title: Erythema nodosum on legs
images.description:
Multiple erythematous maculonodular lesions of varying shapes and sizes (green overlay) distributed on both pretibial surfaces.Those findings, especially when seen on the anterior leg, are typical of erythema nodosum.
The erythematous appearance indicates that those lesions have likely developed within the last 7 days (afterwards, erythema nodosum lesions usually turn bluish and then yellow-brownish).

answers.explanation_why: Varicose veins are common during pregnancy because the growing uterus places increased pressure on pelvic veins. However, they manifest as dark purple or blue, twisted, bulging, soft, nontender cords and usually show no signs of inflammation. Additionally, duplex ultrasound might show subcutaneous edema but not vascular wall thickening.

Lymphedema is caused by insufficient lymphatic drainage and can occur during pregnancy (pregnancy hormones induce changes in vascular permeability, promoting extravasation of fluids). Lymphedema is typically diffusely localized over the toes and feet; it would not manifest as a tender, palpable cord on the lateral aspect of the left lower leg. Additionally, duplex ultrasound would show subcutaneous edema but not vascular wall thickening.

Superficial thrombophlebitis is usually a benign inflammation of veins and overlying tissue due to thrombosis. The inflamed veins, impacted with thrombotic material, manifest as palpable, nodular cords that remain visible when the limb is raised. There is a greater risk of thrombosis during pregnancy due to a combination of hypercoagulability (increased circulating clotting factors and RBCs) and elevated venous stasis (compression of enlarged uterus on pelvic veins).

question_text: A 50-year-old man undergoes parathyroidectomy for treatment-resistant hyperparathyroidism. The procedure is complicated by brisk bleeding from an artery that travels along the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve. To stop the bleeding, the artery is ligated at its origin. Which of the following is most likely the origin of the artery that was injured in this patient?
content_preview: A 50-year-old man undergoes parathyroidectomy for treatment-resistant hyperparathyroidism. The procedure is complicated by brisk bleeding from an artery that travels along the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve. To stop the bleeding, the artery is ligated at its origin. Which of the following is most likely the origin of the artery that was injured in this patient?
hint: The superior thyroid artery travels along the superior laryngeal nerve.
learning_objective: Recall the anatomy of the superior thyroid artery, and recall its origin.

answers.explanation_why: The subclavian artery gives rise to the inferior thyroid artery via the thyrocervical trunk. The inferior thyroid artery pierces the lower pole of the thyroid gland and is closely associated with the recurrent laryngeal nerve. This patient has an injury of a vessel traveling with the superior laryngeal nerve rather than with the RLN.

The cervical portion of the internal carotid artery (ICA) has no branches and neither of the thyroid arteries arise from the ICA. As a result, ligation of the ICA would not affect this patient's bleeding. The first branches of the internal carotid arise in the petrous segment of the ICA. Before it terminates in the brain, the major branches include the ophthalmic artery and the superior hypophyseal artery, along with several smaller branches.

The superior thyroid artery is a direct branch of the external carotid artery. After the carotid artery bifurcates in the carotid triangle, the superior thyroid artery arises as the first branch of the external carotid artery and supplies the cranial half of the thyroid gland before forming an anastomotic network with the inferior thyroid artery. The artery travels with the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve and pierces the thyroid gland at the superior pole. Therefore, bleeding from the superior thyroid artery would be controlled by ligating it at its origin from the external carotid artery.

images.title: Blood supply of the thyroid gland
images.description:
Arterial supply: two paired arteries and a third inconsistent artery
- The superior thyroid artery (paired) originates from the external carotid artery and enters the thyroid gland at the superior pole.
- The inferior thyroid artery (paired) originates from the thyrocervical trunk (a branch of the subclavian artery) and enters the thyroid gland posteriorly.
- The solitary thyroidea ima artery (unpaired) is present in < 5% individuals. It may arise directly from the subclavian artery (as shown here) or from the aortic arch or the brachiocephalic artery. It enters the thyroid at the inferior border of the isthmus.Venous drainage occurs via a venous plexus on the anterior surface of the thyroid (plexus thyroideus impar) that is drained by three paired veins:
- The superior thyroid veins drain into the internal jugular vein.
- The middle thyroid veins also drain into the internal jugular vein.
- The inferior thyroid veins drain into the brachiocephalic veins.

answers.explanation_why: The thyrocervical trunk originates from the subclavian artery and gives rise to the inferior thyroid artery. The inferior thyroid artery pierces the lower pole of the thyroid gland and is closely associated with the recurrent laryngeal nerve. This patient has an injury of a vessel traveling with the superior laryngeal nerve rather than with the RLN.

The ascending pharyngeal artery arises from the external carotid artery and gives rise to a pharyngeal and neuromeningeal trunk. Branches of the ascending pharyngeal artery supply the pharyngeal constrictor muscles, tympanic cavity, and meninges but they do not travel along the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve. Bleeding from the ascending pharyngeal artery or one of its branches would be unlikely during a parathyroidectomy.

question_text: Three days after undergoing laparoscopic colectomy, a 67-year-old man reports swelling and pain in his right leg. He was diagnosed with colon cancer 1 month ago. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F). Physical examination shows swelling of the right leg from the ankle to the thigh. There is no erythema or rash. Which of the following is likely to be most helpful in establishing the diagnosis?
content_preview: Three days after undergoing laparoscopic colectomy, a 67-year-old man reports swelling and pain in his right leg. He was diagnosed with colon cancer 1 month ago. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F). Physical examination shows swelling of the right leg from the ankle to the thigh. There is no erythema or rash. Which of the following is likely to be most helpful in establishing the diagnosis?
hint: This patient has swelling and pain in his right lower extremity and fever with no erythema. Using the Wells score for deep vein thrombosis (DVT), his pretest probability of a DVT is at least 3 points (i.e., major surgery within 4 weeks, malignancy, leg swelling), which indicates a high probability of DVT.
learning_objective: Recognize deep vein thrombosis, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why: D-dimer level testing is frequently used to rule out DVT. However, it should only be used when pretest probability is low (i.e., Wells score ≤ 1) rather than high, which is seen here. In addition, D-dimer testing is not recommended in postoperative patients because the concentration of D-dimer is rarely normal in this state (leading to frequent false positives)

Transthoracic echocardiography would help in the diagnosis of right heart failure due to a massive pulmonary embolism (PE), which could also result in a high Wells score. However, a massive PE typically manifests with severe dyspnea, chest pain, hypotension, and shock, none of which are seen in this patient. A TTE would not be helpful in the diagnosis of this patient's DVT.

CT pulmonary angiography is the test of choice for the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism (PE), for which the pretest possibility can also be calculated using the Wells score. However, PE typically presents with chest pain, shortness of breath, and/or tachycardia, none of which this patient has. A CT pulmonary angiography would not be helpful in diagnosing this patient's likely DVT.

Blood cultures are useful in diagnosing bacteremia, which can be caused by cellulitis. Cellulitis typically manifests with fever as well as local swelling and pain. However, it also manifests with erythema, which is not seen in this patient. Moreover, cellulitis does not have a high Wells score.

Compression ultrasonography is the test of choice for diagnosing DVT. It is affordable, reliable, and safe, making it an ideal first-line test. Sonographic findings that suggest a thrombus include a noncompressible vein, visible hyperechoic mass, and/or absent or abnormal venous flow.

question_text: A 61-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of crushing substernal chest pain at rest for the past 2 hours. She is diaphoretic. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 115/65 mm Hg. An ECG shows ST elevation in I, aVL, and V2–V4. Coronary angiography shows an 80% stenosis in the left anterior descending artery. Which of the following is the most likely initial step in the pathogenesis of this patient's coronary condition?
content_preview: A 61-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of crushing substernal chest pain at rest for the past 2 hours. She is diaphoretic. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 115/65 mm Hg. An ECG shows ST elevation in I, aVL, and V2–V4. Coronary angiography shows an 80% stenosis in the left anterior descending artery. Which of the following is the most likely initial step in the pathogenesis of this patient's coronary condition?
hint: This patient's symptoms (acute, crushing substernal chest pain, diaphoresis) and ECG changes indicate a diagnosis of acute coronary syndrome (ACS). The angiography showing a stenosis of the left anterior descending artery confirms the diagnosis. ACS is caused primarily by atherosclerosis.
learning_objective: Recognize acute coronary syndrome, and recall the initial step in atherosclerosis pathogenesis.

answers.explanation_why: The development of atherosclerosis begins with an external factor (e.g., hypertension, smoking, advanced glycation end-products) damaging the endothelium, which increases adhesiveness and leads to local inflammation and invasion of smooth muscle cells into the tunica intima. Inflammatory cytokines attract macrophages, which then form foam cells by taking up cholesterol from oxidized low-density lipids. These foam cells accumulate to form fatty streaks (early atherosclerotic lesions). Finally, collagen production by lipid-laden macrophages and smooth muscle cells form these fatty streaks into a fibrous plaque.

Intimal monocyte infiltration is one of the first steps in the pathogenesis of atherosclerosis. After adhesion to the endothelium, the monocytes emigrate through the endothelium into the intima. As the endothelium is physiologically impermeable to monocytes, monocyte infiltration is not the initial step of atherosclerosis.

Intimal smooth muscle cells migration is mediated by macrophages producing platelet-derived growth factor (PDGF) and fibroblast growth factor (FGF). However, intimal smooth muscle cell migration is not the initial step of atherosclerosis.

Intimal foam cell accumulation is a consequence of macrophages infiltrating the intima and ingesting cholesterol from oxidized LDL. These foam cells accumulate and form fatty streaks. However, intimal foam cell accumulation is not the initial step of atherosclerosis.

Fibrous plaque formation is mediated by macrophages, lymphocytes, and smooth muscle cells. Together with deposited extracellular matrix (e.g., collagen), these cell types form the fibrous plaque in atherosclerosis. However, fibrous plaque formation is not the initial step of atherosclerosis.

Platelet activation releases a variety of inflammatory mediators and thereby recruits inflammatory cells towards the site of the atherosclerotic lesion. However, platelets are only activated after adhesion to the endothelium of affected vessels. Therefore, platelet activation is not the initial step of atherosclerosis.

Low-density lipoprotein (LDL) oxidation releases cholesterol, which is then ingested by macrophages, inducing foam cell formation. However, attraction and activation of macrophages happen before the formation of foam cells. Therefore, LDL oxidation is not the initial step of atherosclerosis.

question_text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 5-day history of swelling in his left arm. Two months ago, he was diagnosed with a deep venous thrombosis in the left calf. He has had a 7-kg (15-lb) weight loss in the last 3 months. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 25 years. His only medication is warfarin. Physical examination shows warm edema of the left forearm with overlying erythema and a tender, palpable cord-like structure along the medial arm. His lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Duplex sonography shows thrombosis of the left basilic and external jugular veins. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to confirm the underlying diagnosis?
content_preview: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 5-day history of swelling in his left arm. Two months ago, he was diagnosed with a deep venous thrombosis in the left calf. He has had a 7-kg (15-lb) weight loss in the last 3 months. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for the past 25 years. His only medication is warfarin. Physical examination shows warm edema of the left forearm with overlying erythema and a tender, palpable cord-like structure along the medial arm. His lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. Duplex sonography shows thrombosis of the left basilic and external jugular veins. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to confirm the underlying diagnosis?
hint: This patient presents with a history of thrombosis and current superficial thrombophlebitis involving different anatomical locations, which is consistent with migratory thrombophlebitis. The presence of this sign should always raise suspicion for an underlying hypercoagulable state.
learning_objective: Recognize migratory thrombophlebitis, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why: 24-hour electrocardiography monitoring is useful for detecting paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. Affected patients may present with seemingly inexplicable arterial thromboembolism (manifesting as transient ischemic attack/stroke, bowel infarction, or acute limb ischemia). The diagnosis is often delayed because electrocardiogram at the time of presentation may demonstrate normal sinus rhythm, thus obscuring the need for further workup of a cardiogenic cause of the clotting. This patient has venous thromboses, however, which would not be explained by paroxysmal atrial fibrillation so 24-hour electrocardiography monitoring is not appropriate.

A chest x-ray can be used to identify potential lung malignancies, which could result in a hypercoagulable state. This patient's pulmonary exam is unremarkable and he lacks concerning respiratory signs/symptoms, making a lung malignancy less likely. Finally, chest x-ray is no longer a recommended screening tool for patients at high risk for lung cancer. Instead, a low-dose helical CT scan is the imaging modality of choice. Chest x-ray is less likely to help confirm the underlying diagnosis.

Transesophageal echocardiography is useful for diagnosing a cardiogenic etiology of arterial thrombosis (e.g., atrial thrombus or valvular vegetations). Atrial thrombi most often arise in the setting of atrial fibrillation and manifest with recurrent arterial thromboses, not venous thromboses as seen here. Bacterial valvular vegetations can also cause recurrent arterial thrombosis due to septic microemboli, manifesting with Osler nodes, Janeway lesions, and nail bed hemorrhages, all of which are absent in this man. This patient presents with DVT and superficial thrombophlebitis, making a cardiogenic etiology unlikely.

A CT scan of the abdomen is most likely to confirm the diagnosis of Trousseau syndrome, a condition that is characterized by recurrent venous thrombosis in different veins with evidence of simultaneous thrombophlebitis (warm, red, swollen skin with tender cord-like structures) as seen here. This patient's older age, smoking history, and weight loss raise concern for a malignancy-induced hypercoagulable state. Trousseau syndrome is most often seen in the setting of a visceral malignancy (classically, pancreatic adenocarcinoma) due to the production of procoagulants by the malignant cells.

Serum antiphospholipid antibody levels are elevated in patients with antiphospholipid syndrome. Patients with APS are at significantly increased risk of developing recurrent venous thromboses, as seen in this man. However, other common manifestations of APS include recurrent arterial thrombosis (possibly causing transient ischemic attack or stroke) and livedo reticularis, neither of which are reported or observed here. Finally, significant weight loss and the presence of simultaneous superficial thrombophlebitis are not typical of APS, making this diagnosis unlikely.

Serum D-dimer level is most useful in determining whether or not a patient is experiencing a thrombotic event. Because the D-dimer value reflects the extent to which fibrinolysis is occurring, it can serve as indirect evidence of a venous thrombosis. In patients with a low pretest probability for DVT, the D-dimer is considered especially useful as a screening tool. In this patient with a confirmed history of DVT, the D-dimer would add no useful information in confirming the underlying diagnosis.

question_text: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 10-month history of crampy left lower extremity pain that is exacerbated by walking and relieved by rest. The pain is especially severe when he walks on an incline. He has a 20-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, for which he takes metformin. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. His blood pressure is 140/92 mm Hg. Physical examination shows dry and hairless skin over the left foot. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 65-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 10-month history of crampy left lower extremity pain that is exacerbated by walking and relieved by rest. The pain is especially severe when he walks on an incline. He has a 20-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus, for which he takes metformin. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years. His blood pressure is 140/92 mm Hg. Physical examination shows dry and hairless skin over the left foot. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: Ankle-brachial index (ABI) is a common test used to diagnose this condition.
learning_objective: Recognize peripheral arterial disease (PAD) as the cause of claudication.

answers.content: Osteophytic compression of the lumbar spinal canal
answers.explanation_why: Osteophytic compression of the lumbar spinal canal may lead to neurogenic claudication, causing lower leg pain on exertion. However, neurogenic claudication is relieved by flexion at the waist, so classically it is less severe when walking uphill. Moreover, this condition does not cause trophic skin changes such as hairlessness of the foot.

answers.content: Thrombosing vasculitis of the popliteal artery
answers.explanation_why: Thrombosing vasculitis of the popliteal artery could be seen in thromboangiitis obliterans (TAO). TAO is one of the possible causes of lower extremity claudication, and smoking is strongly associated with this condition. However, the symptoms of TAO are commonly bilateral, whereas this patient's symptoms are unilateral. Moreover, the condition classically manifests with superficial thrombophlebitis, Raynaud phenomenon, and early ischemic ulceration, none of which are present in this case. Finally, TAO typically manifests in patients < 45 years of age, making the diagnosis less likely in this 65-year-old man.

answers.content: Intimal plaque in the posterior tibial artery
answers.explanation_why: An intimal plaque in the posterior tibial artery is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation, which is consistent with peripheral arterial disease (PAD). PAD is strongly associated with diabetes, hypertension, and smoking, all of which are present in this case. The disease begins with the buildup of lipids and fibrous material beneath the tunica intima in peripheral arteries. With time, focal accumulation of these substances can cause stenosis and reduced blood flow to downstream tissues, manifesting as episodic ischemia (in this case, claudication). Typical physical exam findings include decreased or absent peripheral pulses, atrophic skin changes (i.e., dry, shiny, or hairless skin), or chronically non-healing foot wounds. The diagnosis is confirmed via ankle-brachial index.

images.title: Multilevel peripheral arterial disease of the lower limbs
images.description: MR angiography lower limbsNumerous stenoses (examples indicated by arrows) are present. Portions of several bilateral pelvic, femoral, and lower limb arteries are not visible.

answers.content: Fibrin clot in the left popliteal vein
answers.explanation_why: A fibrin clot in the left popliteal vein would manifest as a deep venous thrombosis (DVT). Although smoking and diabetes are risk factors for the development of DVT, this condition manifests with acute onset unilateral leg pain, swelling, and erythema. There is most often a history of surgery or inactivity as well that causes venous stasis, neither of which are present in this case. Furthermore, DVT does not cause claudication, pedal alopecia, or the foot to turn pale on elevation.

answers.content: Microvascular compromise of the superficial peroneal nerve
answers.explanation_why: Microvascular compromise of the superficial peroneal nerve (or any other sensory nerve of the distal lower extremity) occurs with long-standing diabetes. Through a complex series of pathways, chronic hyperglycemia induces microvascular damage in the vessels of the perineurium, causing axonal damage that manifests as diabetic neuropathy. This patient is at significant risk to develop neuropathy as a complication of his diabetes. However, he presents with intermittent unilateral lower extremity pain and evidence of skin changes, neither of which are consistent with diabetic neuropathy. Moreover, he does not report pain, burning, tingling, or numbness in the dorsal foot and toes (the dermatome of the superficial peroneal nerve), all of which are characteristic symptoms of diabetic neuropathy.

Systemic hyperplastic arteriosclerosis is a form of small vessel disease that typically arises in the setting of severe hypertension (≥ 180/120 mmHg). The intimal response to sustained blood pressures in this range results in a characteristic “onion skin” appearance on histological examination of vascular tissue. This process classically causes ischemic damage in the kidneys, but it is not implicated in cases of vascular insufficiency in the extremities. Moreover, this patient's blood pressure is only 140/92 mm Hg, which is much lower than what is necessary to cause hyperplastic arteriosclerosis.

question_text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician for gradual worsening of her vision. Her father died at 40 years of age. She is 181 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 69 kg (152 lb); BMI is 21 kg/m^2. A standard vision test shows severe myopia. Genetic analysis shows an FBN1 gene mutation on chromosome 15. This patient is at greatest risk of mortality due to which of the following causes?
content_preview: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician for gradual worsening of her vision. Her father died at 40 years of age. She is 181 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 69 kg (152 lb); BMI is 21 kg/m2. A standard vision test shows severe myopia. Genetic analysis shows an FBN1 gene mutation on chromosome 15. This patient is at greatest risk of mortality due to which of the following causes?
hint: Other abnormal morphometric features of this condition include thoracic wall deformities (e.g., pectus carinatum, pectus excavatum), long extremities, arachnodactyly, subluxation of the lens, and hypermobile joints.
learning_objective: Recognize Marfan syndrome, and recall its cardiovascular complications.

answers.explanation_why: Left ventricular outflow tract obstruction is an important cause of mortality in patients with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM). Hereditary HCM can be caused by an autosomal dominant defect in genes responsible for the synthesis of certain sarcomeric proteins (e.g., MYH7, MYBPC3) or by an autosomal recessive trinucleotide repeat mutation on the frataxin gene on chromosome 9 (Friedreich ataxia). A mutation in the FBN1 gene is not associated with an increased risk of HCM.

images.title: Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy
images.description: Hypertrophy of the myocardium results in reduced diastolic compliance and filling of the left ventricle (sometimes also of the right ventricle). Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy can occur with or without left ventricular outflow tract obstruction. Hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM) occurs when hypertrophy of the interventricular septum and systolic anterior movement (SAM) of the mitral valve leaflet results in the left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction.

answers.content: Obstruction of the superior vena cava lumen
answers.explanation_why: SVC syndrome is most commonly seen in patients with a mediastinal mass (e.g., lymphoma), Pancoast tumor, or thrombosis due to an indwelling venous catheter. FBN1 gene defects are not associated with an increased risk of SVC syndrome.

answers.content: Increased pressure in the pulmonary arteries
answers.explanation_why: Chronic pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH) can lead to cor pulmonale and right ventricular failure, resulting in death. Genetic causes of PAH include inactivating mutations on the BMPR2 gene on chromosome 2 and connective tissues disease such as systemic sclerosis. However, mutations on the FBN1 gene are not associated with the development of pulmonary hypertension.

Eccentric ventricular hypertrophy is the underlying disease process in dilated cardiomyopathy. Genetic causes of dilated cardiomyopathy include certain sarcomeric protein mutations (e.g., TTN gene), Duchenne muscular dystrophy, and hereditary hemochromatosis. Mutations in the FBN1 gene are not associated with an increased risk of dilated cardiomyopathy.

Supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) refers to any tachyarrhythmia that originates above or within the Bundle of His. Causes include a dysfunctional AV node, the presence of an additional electrical pathway (AVNRT), and the presence of an accessory pathway between the atria and ventricles (AVRT, WPW). This patient's condition is not associated with an increased risk of supraventricular tachycardia.

answers.content: Intimal tear of the aortic root
answers.explanation_why:
An autosomal dominant defect in the FBN1 gene on chromosome 15 is responsible for Marfan syndrome, which can cause tall stature and myopia, as seen in this patient. Marfan syndrome is associated with cystic medial necrosis of the aorta, which can result in aortic root dissection (e.g., intimal tear), aortic root dilation, and aortic regurgitation. Aortic root disease is the most common cause of morbidity and mortality in patients with Marfan syndrome.

Severe mitral valve prolapse is another common cause of early mortality in patients with Marfan syndrome.

question_text: A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician with a 6-month history of pain and swelling of both legs. The symptoms are worst at the end of the day and are associated with itching of the overlying skin. Physical examination shows bilateral pitting ankle edema. An image of one of the ankles is shown. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
content_preview: A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician with a 6-month history of pain and swelling of both legs. The symptoms are worst at the end of the day and are associated with itching of the overlying skin. Physical examination shows bilateral pitting ankle edema. An image of one of the ankles is shown. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
hint: The varicose veins, brown skin discoloration, and corona phlebectatica in this patient are signs of chronic venous insufficiency (CVI).
learning_objective: Recognize chronic venous insufficiency, and recall its complications.

answers.explanation_why: Thrombosis of a deep vein is associated with increased age, a history of smoking, inherited thrombophilias, OCP use, and malignancy. While superficial thrombophlebitis and thrombosis are common in CVI, deep vein thrombosis is rare.

Sepsis with gram-positive bacteria (e.g., Staphylococcus aureus, Group A streptococcus) can occur following skin or soft tissue infections (e.g., cellulitis, necrotizing fasciitis), which would manifest with pain and swelling in the affected region. However, the symptoms of skin or subcutaneous tissue infection would occur acutely, unlike this patient who had symptoms for the past 6 months, and erythema would be evident on inspection. Although CVI is itself a risk factor for developing cellulitis, a different complication of CVI is much more likely than sepsis.

Malignant transformation of lymphatic endothelium causes lymphangiosarcoma, a rare malignancy that is due to chronic lymphedema rather than CVI. While squamous cell cancer can be seen in some cases of CVI at the site of the chronic ulcer, lymphangiosarcoma would not be seen.

Accumulation of biliverdin in the epidermis is responsible for the hyperpigmentation seen following subcutaneous hematoma formation. However, in CVI, hyperpigmentation is due to the dermal deposition of hemosiderin, which occurs over time as extravasated RBCs are broken down.

answers.content: Osmotic injury to the peripheral nerves
answers.explanation_why: Patients with untreated diabetes mellitus (DM) are at increased risk of osmotic injury to the peripheral nerves (diabetic neuropathy). Patients with untreated DM often develop pathologies in the lower extremities (e.g., skin and soft tissue infections, ischemic or neuropathic ulcers) but the dilated veins seen in the photograph suggest CVI, which does not result in peripheral nerve injury.

images.title: Diabetic foot infection (cellulitis)
images.description: Left foot of a patient with diabetes and a history of having stepped on a nailThe big toe appears severely swollen and erythematous with a large ulcer on the medial side of the first metatarsophalangeal joint and a second ulcer more distally. Cellulitis extends to the black line. HbA1c of > 10% confirmed the diagnosis of diabetic foot infection.

answers.explanation_why: In CVI defective venous valve leaflets lead to reflux of venous blood back into the periphery, resulting in increased venous pressure (hydrostatic pressure) and subsequent extravasation of venous blood into the interstitium. Plasma proteins in the interstitium, in turn, cause edema and tissue hypoperfusion, which results in stasis dermatitis, lipodermatosclerosis, and, in some cases, ulcer formation. Venous ulcers tend to occur over the shin and medial malleolus and are shallow, tender, and surrounded by hyperpigmented skin.

images.title: Venous leg ulcer in chronic venous insufficiency
images.description: Medial aspect of the right footAn ulcer with surrounding erythema is visible on the medial malleolus of the right foot.These findings are characteristic of venous ulcer secondary to chronic venous insufficiency.

images.title: Varicose veins
images.description:
Photograph of the medial aspect of the ankleMultiple dilated and tortuous veins are visible around the medial malleolus.
Numerous bluish telangiectasias can be seen toward the inferior spect, while reddish-brown pigmentation can be seen adjacent to the Achilles tendon.

These are typical features of chronic venous insufficiency due to varicose veins.

question_text: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of intermittent dull abdominal pain that radiates to the back. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 50 years. His blood pressure is 145/80 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows generalized tenderness and a pulsatile mass in the periumbilical region on deep palpation. Further evaluation of the affected blood vessel is most likely to show which of the following?
content_preview: A 72-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of intermittent dull abdominal pain that radiates to the back. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 50 years. His blood pressure is 145/80 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows generalized tenderness and a pulsatile mass in the periumbilical region on deep palpation. Further evaluation of the affected blood vessel is most likely to show which of the following?
hint: The presence of chronic dull abdominal pain and a pulsatile abdominal mass suggests an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).
learning_objective: Recognize abdominal aortic aneurysm, and recall its pathological process.

answers.content: Accumulation of foam cells in the tunica intima
answers.explanation_why: Accumulation of foam cells in the tunica intima is the pathological process underlying atheroma formation (atherosclerosis), which is the most common cause of aortic wall weakening and formation of an AAA. This patient's history of smoking, hypertension, and advanced age are all risk factors for atherosclerosis.

images.title: Atheroma
images.description:
Photomicrograph of a section of an arterial wall depicting an atheroma (H&E, highly magnified)The inner layer of an atheroma is the single layer of endothelial cells of the tunica intima (the superior-most layer in this image).
The second layer is a fibrous cap, which is composed of lipid-laden macrophages or foam cells (the white arrowheads point to a few examples), a few smooth muscle cells, neutrophils, and lymphocytes.
The core of the atheroma (green overlay) is composed of anuclear necrotic cells and cholesterol clefts (empty unstained spaced indicated with white arrows).A collection of foam cells and cholesterol clefts with a fibrous cap and a necrotic core are the characteristic histological features of an atheroma.

answers.content: Obliterative inflammation of the vasa vasorum
answers.explanation_why: Obliterative inflammation of the vasa vasorum is characteristic of syphilitic aortitis, which can result in an aortic aneurysm. However, syphilitic aortitis affects the ascending aorta, whereas this patient presents with a mass in the abdominal portion of the descending aorta.

answers.content: Necrotizing inflammation of the entire vessel wall
answers.explanation_why: Necrotizing inflammation of all the layers of the vessel wall is characteristic of polyarteritis nodosa (PAN), which can cause microaneurysms in medium-sized arteries (e.g., mesenteric arteries and renal arteries), episodic abdominal pain (due to mesenteric ischemia), and hypertension (due to renal involvement). However, PAN would not cause a pulsatile periumbilical mass because it spares large arteries like the aorta. Other clinical features of vasculitis, such as fever, malaise, weight loss, and cutaneous lesions (e.g., livedo reticularis, distal ulcerations), would be expected instead.

images.title: Polyarteritis nodosa
images.description: Photomicrograph of a muscle biopsy sample with a medium-sized arterial vessel (H&E stain; low magnification)There is transmural inflammation of the arterial wall with leukocytic infiltration and fibrinoid necrosis.These findings are characteristic of polyarteritis nodosa.

answers.content: Formation of giant cells in the tunica media
answers.explanation_why: Formation of giant cells in the tunica media is characteristic of giant cell arteritis (GCA) and Takayasu arteritis, both of which are large vessel vasculitides and can result in an AAA. However, neither condition is the most common cause of AAA, and this patient does not report any symptoms that would otherwise suggest an increased likelihood of GCA (e.g., headache, scalp tenderness, or jaw claudication) or Takayasu arteritis (e.g., limb claudication or onset of symptoms before the age of 40 years), so a different pathological process is more likely.

images.title: Polymyalgia rheumatica and giant cell arteritis fact sheet

answers.content: Fragmentation of elastic tissue in the tunica media
answers.explanation_why: Fragmentation of elastic tissue in the tunica media is the pathological process underlying cystic medial necrosis (CMN), which occurs in certain connective tissue disorders such as Marfan syndrome. However, for reasons that are not completely understood, CMN typically affects the thoracic aorta rather than the abdominal aorta. A different pathological process is the most common cause of an AAA. Furthermore, this patient does not have features of Marfan syndrome (e.g., tall stature, long extremities, joint hypermobility, ectopia lentis).

question_text: A 65-year-old man with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after the onset of severe anterior chest pain and shortness of breath. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. He appears distressed. His pulse is 116/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 156/88 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. A grade 3/6, high-pitched, blowing, diastolic murmur is heard over the right upper sternal border. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 65-year-old man with hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after the onset of severe anterior chest pain and shortness of breath. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. He appears distressed. His pulse is 116/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 156/88 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 98%. A grade 3/6, high-pitched, blowing, diastolic murmur is heard over the right upper sternal border. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: Dyspnea with a high-pitched, blowing, diastolic murmur at the right upper sternal border suggests aortic regurgitation.
learning_objective: Recognize aortic dissection by a tear in the tunica intima.

answers.explanation_why:
An aortic dissection is typically caused by a tear in the tunica intima and subsequent longitudinal extension of the dissecting hematoma. Hypertension, which increases the risk of endothelial injury, is the most common predisposing factor for aortic dissection. Most aortic dissections begin in the ascending portion of the thoracic aorta because this is the region of maximum hydraulic stress. Patients present with sudden and severe pain in the chest or interscapular region. The pain can migrate as the dissection progresses. Proximal extension of the dissection into the aortic valve ring can cause acute aortic regurgitation (AR), as seen here. Other features of aortic dissection include syncope, diminished distal pulses, and asymmetrical blood pressure and pulse readings between limbs. Unlike the murmur of AR from aortic valve disease, which is prominent along the left sternal border, the murmur of AR from aortic dissection is prominent along the right sternal border.

Nonmodifiable risk factors for aortic dissection include advanced age, male sex, and certain genetic conditions that weaken the tunica media (e.g., Marfan syndrome, vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, Turner syndrome).

images.title: Aortic dissection
images.description: A tear in the tunica intima (entry tear on illustration) allows blood to enter into the tunica media. The column of blood then extends longitudinally, most commonly in the outer half of the tunica media. This creates a false lumen, which may rupture back into the true lumen of the aorta (reentry tear on illustration) or rupture through the tunica adventitia.

answers.content: Fibrofatty plaque in the aortic wall
answers.explanation_why: The formation of a fibrofatty plaque in the aortic wall is characteristic of atherosclerosis, which typically involves the abdominal portion of the descending aorta. Atherosclerosis is implicated in the formation of abdominal aortic aneurysms; atheroma ulceration has been reported in some patients with abdominal aortic dissections and descending thoracic aortic dissections. Although both aortic dissection and atherosclerosis share similar risk factors (e.g., smoking, hypertension, advanced age, and male sex), atherosclerosis is not a major risk factor for most aortic dissections, which tend to occur in the ascending aorta.

Obstruction of the pulmonary arteries is seen in pulmonary embolism, which can manifest with acute-onset dyspnea, chest pain, tachypnea, and tachycardia. However, pulmonary embolism would not explain the AR seen here.

answers.content: Rupture of a bulla in the lung
answers.explanation_why: Rupture of a bulla in the lung causes pneumothorax, which can manifest with dyspnea, chest pain, tachypnea, and tachycardia. However, pneumothorax would not explain the AR seen here. Instead, chest auscultation would reveal decreased breath sounds caused by pneumothorax.

Esophageal rupture can manifest with chest pain, tachycardia, tachypnea, and dyspnea (due to mediastinitis and/or pleural effusion). However, esophageal rupture would not cause a murmur. Instead, chest auscultation might reveal a crunching sound over the precordium that is synchronous with each heartbeat (Hamman sign) due to a pneumomediastinum and/or decreased breath sounds due to a pleural effusion. Furthermore, esophageal rupture usually has a distinct precipitating cause (e.g., retching or forceful vomiting).

Infarction of the ventricular wall (myocardial infarction) can cause acute-onset chest pain, dyspnea, tachypnea, tachycardia, and a murmur due to mitral regurgitation that is caused by papillary muscle rupture. However, the murmur due to mitral regurgitation is systolic rather than diastolic and heard best at the cardiac apex, not the right upper sternal border. Moreover, papillary muscle rupture typically occurs 2–7 days after infarction, not at the outset.

question_text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 12-hour history of a severe headache. She does not smoke or use illicit drugs. Her blood pressure at admission is 180/125 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a bruit in the epigastric region. Fundoscopy shows bilateral optic disc swelling. Which of the following investigations is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
content_preview: A 32-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 12-hour history of a severe headache. She does not smoke or use illicit drugs. Her blood pressure at admission is 180/125 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a bruit in the epigastric region. Fundoscopy shows bilateral optic disc swelling. Which of the following investigations is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?
hint: In a young patient with a hypertensive emergency (blood pressure of 185/125 mm Hg, papilledema, severe headache) and an epigastric or flank bruit on examination, fibromuscular dysplasia (FMD) is the most likely diagnosis.
learning_objective: Recognize fibromuscular dysplasia, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic study.

answers.explanation_why: Serum IGF-I levels are used in the evaluation of acromegaly. Although acromegaly can cause secondary hypertension, it is also associated with other clinical features, such as a large skull, coarse facies, and widened hands, fingers, and feet. In addition, acromegaly would not explain this patient's abdominal bruit.

Urinary catecholamine metabolites confirm the diagnosis of pheochromocytoma. Although pheochromocytoma can manifest with episodic hypertension and headaches, it would not explain this patient's abdominal bruit.

Echocardiography with Doppler is used e.g., to confirm coarctation of the aorta. Although coarctation of the aorta can lead to hypertension, other symptoms are also typically present, such as hypotension and claudication of the lower extremities, or a continuous murmur below the left clavicula and between the shoulder blades. An abdominal bruit, however, would not be expected. Echocardiography has no role in diagnosing fibromuscular dysplasia.

Serum 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels are used to screen for congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). Although congenital adrenal hyperplasia can cause secondary hypertension, it is often associated with precocious puberty and electrolyte abnormalities and would not explain this patient's abdominal bruit. In addition, all newborns in the US are screened for CAH; therefore, a delayed diagnosis at the age of 32 years would be unlikely.

Serum PTH levels are used in the diagnostic evaluation of hyperparathyroidism. Primary hyperparathyroidism can lead to hypertension due to progressive calcification of the arteries and heart muscle. However, this condition is typically associated with other findings, such as nephrolithiasis, constipation, gastric ulcers, psychological symptoms (e.g., depression, fatigue), and/or bone, muscle, and joint pain. In addition, primary hyperparathyroidism would not explain this patient's abdominal bruit.

A high-dose dexamethasone suppression test is used to confirm Cushing syndrome. While Cushing syndrome is a common cause of secondary hypertension, it is usually accompanied by other symptoms, such as obesity, hirsutism, and easily bruisable skin with stretch marks. In addition, Cushing syndrome would not explain this patient's abdominal bruit.

Oral sodium loading test is used to confirm primary hyperaldosteronism. Although primary hyperaldosteronism is a common cause of secondary hypertension in young people, symptoms of hypokalemia, such as fatigue or muscle weakness, are also typically present. In addition, primary hyperaldosteronism would not explain this patient's abdominal bruit.

CT angiography is a noninvasive imaging method that has a high accuracy in confirming the diagnosis of fibromuscular dysplasia (FMD), which most commonly affects the renal and carotid arteries. Renal artery stenosis due to FMD leads to hypertension, as seen here. Imaging typically shows a so-called “string of beads” appearance of the renal arteries due to segmental hyperplasia of the tunica media. Other imaging methods that can be used to diagnose FMD are duplex ultrasonography and magnetic resonance angiography.

images.title: String of beads sign in fibromuscular dysplasia
images.description: Angiography abdomen (right renal artery)The caliber of the renal artery alternates between stenoses and aneurysms, creating a string of beads appearance that is characteristic of medial fibromuscular dysplasia.

question_text: A previously healthy 36-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a progressively worsening headache for 5 days. She vomited twice after waking up this morning. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses an oral contraceptive. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg. Examination shows tearing of the right eye. The pupils are equal and reactive to light; right lateral gaze is limited. Funduscopic examination shows bilateral optic disc swelling. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An MR venography of the head shows a heterogeneous intensity in the left lateral sinus. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A previously healthy 36-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a progressively worsening headache for 5 days. She vomited twice after waking up this morning. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses an oral contraceptive. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg. Examination shows tearing of the right eye. The pupils are equal and reactive to light; right lateral gaze is limited. Funduscopic examination shows bilateral optic disc swelling. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. An MR venography of the head shows a heterogeneous intensity in the left lateral sinus. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's progressive worsening headache, chemosis, cranial nerve VI palsy (impaired right-sided lateral gaze), increased intracranial pressure (evidenced by headache and bilateral papilledema), and the occlusive lesion in a cerebral sinus on imaging indicate cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT).
learning_objective: Recognize cerebral venous thrombosis, and choose the most appropriate initial management.

answers.explanation_why:
Administration of low molecular weight heparin (LMWH), such as dalteparin, is the most appropriate next step in the management of a patient with acute (aseptic) CVT because LMWH prevents the formation of a new clot while allowing the body to dissolve the existing thrombus. The typical duration is two weeks, after which treatment is switched to an extended duration oral anticoagulant (e.g., warfarin). The specific agent and exact duration of treatment, however, are variable as no consensus guidelines exist to guide this therapy. In the rare event of progressive neurological compromise despite adequate anticoagulation, local thrombolysis may also be required.

Risk factors for CVT include oral contraceptive use (as seen here), pregnancy, coagulation disorders, and malignancy.

Measuring D-dimer levels is useful in the workup of any thrombosis. In patients who present with headache, vomiting, bilateral optic disc swelling on ophthalmoscopy or cranial nerve palsies, elevated D-dimer levels can support the diagnosis of CVT. However, MR imaging has already confirmed the diagnosis of CVT in this patient, and, accordingly, measurement of D-dimers would not provide any more useful information.

Endovascular thrombolysis is a procedure used to restore blood supply in emergency cases of CVT. This intervention may be necessary for patients with significant symptoms (e.g., coma, altered mental status) who do not respond to medical therapy or for whom medical therapy is contraindicated. A different step should be performed before endovascular intervention or surgery is considered.

Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis is an important part of the diagnostic approach to several conditions that can affect the brain and spine, including meningitis, which should be considered in a patient with headache, vomiting, and signs of neurological dysfunction. However, the absence of fever and neck stiffness in this patient makes meningitis unlikely. Therefore, CSF analysis would not be helpful diagnostically.

Treatment with intravenous antibiotics is indicated in the treatment of infectious cerebral venous thrombosis, a possible complication of a local (e.g., otogenic, rhinogenic, facial) or meningeal infection. This patient presents with neither history nor clinical signs of infection.

Surgical clipping of a cerebral aneurysm can be performed to treat acute aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). This patient presents with characteristic features of SAH, which include a headache, nausea/vomiting, and cranial nerve palsies. However, symptoms of SAH typically develop more acutely (“thunderclap headache”). In addition, MR imaging in a patient with SAH would show intracranial bleeding. Angiography would show a cerebral aneurysm. This patient's MR venography, however, shows occlusion of the left lateral sinus.

question_text: A 34-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 3, comes to the physician because of left ankle swelling for 2 months. She notes that the swelling is present throughout the day and decreases when she goes to sleep. One year ago, she had an episode of deep venous thrombosis after the delivery of her third child. Her prepregnancy BMI was 34 kg/m^2. Examination shows distended, tortuous veins in the legs bilaterally and pitting edema of the left ankle. There are erythematous scaling patches on the medial side of the left ankle. Duplex ultrasonography is performed. Which of the following directions of blood flow would most likely confirm the diagnosis?
content_preview: A 34-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 3, comes to the physician because of left ankle swelling for 2 months. She notes that the swelling is present throughout the day and decreases when she goes to sleep. One year ago, she had an episode of deep venous thrombosis after the delivery of her third child. Her prepregnancy BMI was 34 kg/m2. Examination shows distended, tortuous veins in the legs bilaterally and pitting edema of the left ankle. There are erythematous scaling patches on the medial side of the left ankle. Duplex ultrasonography is performed. Which of the following directions of blood flow would most likely confirm the diagnosis?
hint: Distended and tortuous veins in both legs, ankle edema, and skin changes on the medial ankle indicate chronic venous disease.
learning_objective: Recognize chronic venous disease, and recall the direction of blood flow that confirms the diagnosis.

answers.content: Anterior tibial vein to popliteal vein
answers.explanation_why: Venous blood flowing from the anterior tibial vein to the popliteal vein indicates normal blood flow from a peripheral deep vein to a deep vein. Chronic venous disease, however, is characterized by retrograde blood flow, or venous reflux from the deep veins into the superficial veins.

answers.content: Popliteal vein to small saphenous vein
answers.explanation_why: Venous blood flowing from the deep popliteal vein to the superficial small saphenous vein indicates retrograde blood flow and confirms the diagnosis of chronic venous disease. Normally, the small saphenous vein would arise from the dorsal venous arch and drain into the popliteal vein at the saphenopopliteal junction. In a patient with chronic venous disease, however, incompetence of the venous valves caused by elevated venous pressure (e.g., due to pregnancy, increased BMI, prior thrombosis) leads to blood reflux from deep into superficial veins. This results in the formation of varicose veins, and ultimately edema and skin changes (e.g., stasis dermatitis), as seen in this patient. First-line treatment consists of conservative measures such as leg elevation, compression therapy, and application of topical dermatologic agents.

images.title: Veins of the leg (ventral aspect)
images.description:
The superficial veins are depicted in the right leg:
- Great saphenous vein: arises from the medial end of the dorsal venous arch, courses in front of the medial malleolus, up the medial aspect of the leg, behind the medial border of the patella, and up the medial aspect of the thigh. It terminates by draining into the femoral vein at the saphenofemoral junction, which is typically located ~4 cm inferolateral to the pubic tubercle.
- Short saphenous vein: arises from the lateral end of the dorsal venous arch, courses behind the lateral malleolus, and up the posterior aspect of the leg. It terminates by draining into the popliteal vein at the saphenopopliteal junction, which usually lies in the popliteal fossa (not shown here).The deep veins are depicted in the left leg:
- Peripheral deep veins: anterior tibial, posterior tibial, and fibular (peroneal) veins
- Popliteal vein: formed by the confluence of the peripheral deep veins
- Femoral vein: continuation of the popliteal vein. It begins at the adductor hiatus and accompanies the femoral artery throughout its course. The deep femoral vein (profunda femoris) is the main tributary of the femoral vein.
- External iliac vein: continuation of the femoral vein. It begins behind the inguinal ligament and drains into the common iliac vein.

answers.content: Femoral vein to external iliac vein
answers.explanation_why: Venous blood flowing from the femoral vein to the external iliac vein indicates normal blood flow from a deep vein to a proximal deep vein. Chronic venous disease, however, is characterized by retrograde blood flow, or venous reflux from the deep veins into the superficial veins.

answers.content: Great saphenous vein to femoral vein
answers.explanation_why: Venous blood flowing from the great saphenous vein to the femoral vein indicates normal blood flow from a superficial to a deep vein. Chronic venous disease, however, is characterized by retrograde blood flow, or venous reflux from the deep veins into the superficial veins.

answers.content: Dorsal venous arch to great saphenous vein
answers.explanation_why: The dorsal venous arch is a superficial vein that gives rise to the great saphenous vein and small saphenous vein, which are superficial veins that originate from the medial and lateral sides of the dorsal venous arch, respectively. Therefore, blood normally flows from the dorsal venous arch to the great saphenous vein. Chronic venous disease, however, is characterized by retrograde blood flow, or venous reflux from the deep veins into the superficial veins.
