question_text: Two days after admission to the hospital for elective coronary angiography and stent placement in the left anterior descending artery for treatment of stable angina pectoris, a 63-year-old man develops a rash on his left foot. Prior to the angiography, he received a heparin bolus. He has hypertension and steatohepatitis. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years and drinks one to two beers weekly. His medications include simvastatin, aspirin, and atenolol. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Skin examination shows a tender, reticulated blue-red discoloration of the left calf without swelling and several nonblanching reddish maculae on the lateral foot and the toes. Pedal pulses are 1+ bilaterally. Sensation to touch and temperature is normal over the lower extremities. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's rash?
content_preview: Two days after admission to the hospital for elective coronary angiography and stent placement in the left anterior descending artery for treatment of stable angina pectoris, a 63-year-old man develops a rash on his left foot. Prior to the angiography, he received a heparin bolus. He has hypertension and steatohepatitis. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 40 years and drinks one to two beers weekly. His medications include simvastatin, aspirin, and atenolol. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 140/85 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Skin examination shows a tender, reticulated blue-red discoloration of the left calf without swelling and several nonblanching reddish maculae on the lateral foot and the toes. Pedal pulses are 1+ bilaterally. Sensation to touch and temperature is normal over the lower extremities. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's rash?
hint: This condition also frequently leads to acute kidney injury.
learning_objective: Recognize atheroembolism as a cause of rash post-angiography.

answers.explanation_why: Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) of the lower limb can lead to tenderness and discoloration of the skin in a patient with multiple risk factors for DVT (age > 60 years, smoking, immobilization). However, DVT typically manifests with swelling, warmth, and erythema of the affected limb, none of which are seen in this patient. In addition, distal pulses are typically normal in DVT.

Cryoglobulinemia can lead to cryoglobulinemic vasculitis and manifest with skin discoloration. However, most cases of cryoglobulinemic vasculitis are associated with hepatitis C infection and characterized by fatigue, arthralgias, vasomotor symptoms (e.g., Raynaud phenomenon), and polyneuropathy, none of which are seen here.

Atheroembolism is the embolization of multiple cholesterol crystals and atherosclerotic debris, usually to small and medium-sized arteries, following endovascular interventions (e.g., coronary angiography with stent placement), after the initiation of anticoagulant therapy, or spontaneously. Atheroembolism most commonly occurs in older individuals with multiple risk factors for atherosclerosis (e.g., hypertension, coronary artery disease, steatohepatitis, smoking). The embolization of microscopic cholesterol crystals into small arterioles affects many organs, and affected individuals can present with skin changes (e.g., livedo reticularis, blue toe syndrome), gastrointestinal ischemia, pancreatitis, CNS symptoms (transient ischemic attack, stroke), or acute kidney injury.

Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT; formerly called type 2 HIT), a severe complication of heparin therapy that can cause skin necrosis due to arterial thrombosis, would explain this patient's lower extremity skin changes. However, HIT usually develops 5 to 10 days after continuous heparin therapy, whereas this patient received a single heparin bolus 2 days ago.

Acute lower limb ischemia can manifest with sudden onset of unilateral tenderness and skin discoloration of the lower extremity. Nevertheless, other features of acute limb ischemia (6 Ps), such as absent peripheral pulses (pulselessness), decreased lower limb sensation (paresthesia), and paralysis, are absent here.

question_text:
A 59-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 3-hour history of severe midabdominal pain. She describes the pain as aching and continuous, localized to the periumbilical region, and rates it as an 8 in intensity on a 10-point scale. Over the past 2 years, she has had occasional episodes of abdominal pain after meals, but the pain was mild and would resolve spontaneously. She does not have fever, vomiting, or diarrhea. She has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and peripheral artery disease. Her medications include lisinopril, metformin, atorvastatin, and 81-mg aspirin. She smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years but quit 5 years ago. She drinks three glasses of wine weekly. She appears restless. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min and regular, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 148/90 mm Hg. Examination shows a soft abdomen without tenderness to palpation or guarding. Laboratory studies show:

Hematocrit
45%

Leukocyte count
13,500/mm^3

Platelet count
210,000/mm^3

Serum

Ca^2+

9.1 mg/dL

Glucose
142 mg/dL

Amylase
156 U/L

Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows:

pH
7.30

PCO_2

29 mm Hg

HCO_3^-

14 mEq/L

An x-ray of the abdomen shows no abnormalities. Administration of intravenous fluids and analgesics is begun. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 59-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 3-hour history of severe midabdominal pain. She describes the pain as aching and continuous, localized to the periumbilical region, and rates it as an 8 in intensity on a 10-point scale. Over the past 2 years, she has had occasional episodes of abdominal pain after meals, but the pain was mild and would resolve spontaneously. She does not have fever, vomiting, or diarrhea. She has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and peripheral artery disease. Her medications include lisinopril, metformin, atorvastatin, and 81-mg aspirin. She smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years but quit 5 years ago. She drinks three glasses of wine weekly. She appears restless. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 98/min and regular, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 148/90 mm Hg. Examination shows a soft abdomen without tenderness to palpation or guarding. Laboratory studies show: Hematocrit 45% Leukocyte count 13,500/mm3 Platelet count 210,000/mm3 Serum Ca2+ 9.1 mg/dL Glucose 142 mg/dL Amylase 156 U/L Arterial blood gas analysis on room air shows: pH 7.30 PCO2 29 mm Hg HCO3- 14 mEq/L An x-ray of the abdomen shows no abnormalities. Administration of intravenous fluids and analgesics is begun. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: In a patient with a history of episodic postprandial pain (suggestive of chronic mesenteric ischemia), the hyperacute onset of severe midabdominal pain out of proportion to examination findings indicates acute mesenteric ischemia (AMI). Considering her risk factors for atherosclerosis, AMI is most likely due to arterial thrombosis. Metabolic acidosis, leukocytosis, and increased activity of certain enzymes (e.g., amylase, lactate dehydrogenase, aspartate transaminase) are nonspecific findings often associated with AMI.
learning_objective: Recognize acute mesenteric ischemia, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic test in a hemodynamically stable patient.

answers.explanation_why: Upper gastrointestinal series (UGI) can be used to diagnose structural or functional abnormalities of the esophagus (e.g., achalasia), stomach (e.g., gastric outlet obstruction), or proximal small intestine (e.g., duodenal atresia), all of which can manifest with acute abdominal pain. However, UGI is contraindicated in suspected AMI because the introduction of barium and air into the small bowel can increase intraluminal pressure and worsen ischemia. Furthermore, barium in the gastrointestinal tract interferes with subsequent imaging studies and can cause peritonitis in patients with bowel perforation.

answers.content: Test the stool for occult blood
answers.explanation_why: Although patients with AMI may present with blood in stools that can be detected with a fecal occult blood test, bloody stools are a late, inconsistent, and unspecific finding in AMI. A different test is more appropriate for confirming a diagnosis of AMI.

Ultrasound can be used to diagnose some conditions that manifest with acute abdominal pain, such as gallstone disease, appendicitis in certain groups (e.g., children), and certain structural abnormalities (e.g., intussusception). In the context of suspected AMI, color duplex ultrasound is able to detect proximal arterial occlusions and might show signs of perforation (e.g., distended intestinal loops, free fluid in the abdominal cavity). However, color duplex ultrasound is poor at detecting distal arterial occlusions, and picture quality is often limited because of overlying bowel gas, abdominal fat, and vascular calcifications. A different test is more appropriate for confirming a diagnosis of AMI.

Emergency exploratory laparotomy is indicated in patients with suspected AMI who present with features of bowel perforation and peritonitis (e.g., diffuse abdominal guarding, rigidity, rebound tenderness), and/or hemodynamic instability (e.g., tachycardia, hypotension). This procedure permits direct evaluation of the abdominal viscera (e.g., for the extent of ischemia, perforation, bleeding) and allows simultaneous surgical therapy (e.g., bowel resection, surgical revascularization). However, this patient is hemodynamically stable and shows no signs of peritonitis, so a different, less invasive test is more appropriate.

High-resolution CT angiography (CTA) of the abdomen and pelvis is the diagnostic test of choice for suspected AMI in hemodynamically stable patients without signs of peritonitis (e.g., diffuse abdominal guarding, rigidity, rebound tenderness) because it is fast, noninvasive, and accurate in detecting disrupted blood flow and vascular stenosis. This test can differentiate embolic from thrombotic arterial occlusion and provides further information about the vasculature and surrounding structures, all of which are necessary for the planning of subsequent therapy. Furthermore, CTA images can be used to exclude most differentials of acute abdominal pain (e.g., pancreatitis, appendicitis, nephrolithiasis).

Catheter-based arteriography of the abdominal arteries, which is able to show disrupted arterial blood flow and arterial occlusions, was the diagnostic modality of choice for suspected AMI in the past. However, a less invasive test is now available, so catheter angiography is only recommended for diagnosis of AMI if that test is inconclusive.

question_text: A high-resolution CT angiography is obtained, which shows distal thrombotic occlusion and proximal atherosclerotic narrowing of the superior mesenteric artery with good collateral blood flow and no evidence of bowel ischemia. The patient is admitted to the hospital for continuous observation and serial imaging. She is prescribed complete bowel rest, and treatment with unfractionated heparin, pantoprazole, cefixime, and metronidazole is initiated. Nasogastric intubation is performed, and intravenous fluids and analgesic therapy are continued. Despite treatment, the patient does not experience pain relief. On repeat abdominal examination 12 hours after admission, there is diffuse tenderness to palpation, rebound, and guarding. Bowel sounds are decreased. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A high-resolution CT angiography is obtained, which shows distal thrombotic occlusion and proximal atherosclerotic narrowing of the superior mesenteric artery with good collateral blood flow and no evidence of bowel ischemia. The patient is admitted to the hospital for continuous observation and serial imaging. She is prescribed complete bowel rest, and treatment with unfractionated heparin, pantoprazole, cefixime, and metronidazole is initiated. Nasogastric intubation is performed, and intravenous fluids and analgesic therapy are continued. Despite treatment, the patient does not experience pain relief. On repeat abdominal examination 12 hours after admission, there is diffuse tenderness to palpation, rebound, and guarding. Bowel sounds are decreased. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: The findings of the CT angiography (CTA) are consistent with thrombotic acute mesenteric ischemia (AMI). This patient now has features of peritonitis (e.g., rebound, guarding, paralytic ileus).
learning_objective: Recognize thrombotic acute mesenteric ischemia with peritonitis, and choose the most appropriate surgical intervention.

answers.explanation_why:
Open mesenteric bypass surgery to restore arterial perfusion is the treatment of choice in patients with thrombotic AMI who have signs of peritonitis, bowel perforation (e.g., pneumoperitoneum on CTA), advanced bowel ischemia (e.g., thickening of the bowel wall segment on CTA), and/or hemodynamic instability (e.g., tachycardia or hypotension). Open surgery not only allows restoration of perfusion but also inspection of bowel segments for signs of severe ischemia and/or perforation, as well as removal of nonviable segments.

While surgical embolectomy can be used to treat embolic AMI, it is not likely to provide long-term treatment for thrombotic AMI because this condition is characterized by long-segment atherosclerotic plaques, which cannot be treated with removal of singular thrombi.

answers.content: Observation and escalation of analgesic therapy
answers.explanation_why: Observation and escalation of analgesic therapy are appropriate for hemodynamically stable patients with AMI and no evidence of peritonitis, perforation, or advanced bowel ischemia, or for hemodynamically unstable patients with venous AMI or nonocclusive mesenteric ischemia. This patient with thrombotic AMI presents with signs of peritonitis, so treatment should be initiated immediately.

Endovascular thrombectomy is a type of endovascular revascularization, which is the treatment of choice in hemodynamically stable patients with embolic AMI who do not have signs of peritonitis, bowel perforation, and/or advanced bowel ischemia. This patient presents with signs of peritonitis, and she has thrombotic AMI. While thrombectomy can be used to treat embolic AMI, it is not likely to provide long-term treatment for thrombotic AMI because this condition is characterized by long-segment atherosclerotic plaques, which cannot be treated with removal of singular thrombi.

Balloon angioplasty and stenting is an example of endovascular revascularization, which can be used to restore mesenteric blood flow in patients with thrombotic AMI who are hemodynamically stable and do not have signs of peritonitis, bowel perforation, and/or advanced bowel ischemia. This patient presents with signs of peritonitis, which warrants different treatment.

Intravenous fibrinolytic therapy is a revascularization strategy that can be used in some cases of ischemia, like ischemic stroke, ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (i.e., when percutaneous coronary intervention is not available), and pulmonary embolism. It is not routinely used in the treatment of AMI.

question_text: A 72-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, carotid artery stenosis, vascular dementia, and recurrent episodes of transient visual loss is admitted to the hospital for carotid endarterectomy. Duplex ultrasonography and CT angiography of the carotid arteries had shown an 80% stenosis on the right and 50% stenosis on the left. A shared decision to perform right-sided carotid endarterectomy was made with consent from the patient's medical power of attorney, and the management plan was documented in the patient records as “CEA right.” The surgical intern meets the patient on the ward on the day of surgery and, using a permanent marker, circles the surgical site and marks “X” on the nonsurgical site. The patient is brought to the operating room and the circulating nurse confirms that all relevant patient documents and findings are available. While the surgical team is scrubbing, the anesthetist asks the patient to verify her surgery site by pointing to it. Regional anesthesia is performed, and the patient is draped. The surgery is subsequently performed without any complications. While filling out the signout checklist after the surgery, the circulating nurse notices that the surgery was performed on the left carotid artery instead of the right. Which of the following actions would most likely have prevented this never event?
content_preview: A 72-year-old woman with a history of hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, carotid artery stenosis, vascular dementia, and recurrent episodes of transient visual loss is admitted to the hospital for carotid endarterectomy. Duplex ultrasonography and CT angiography of the carotid arteries had shown an 80% stenosis on the right and 50% stenosis on the left. A shared decision to perform right-sided carotid endarterectomy was made with consent from the patient's medical power of attorney, and the management plan was documented in the patient records as “CEA right.” The surgical intern meets the patient on the ward on the day of surgery and, using a permanent marker, circles the surgical site and marks “X” on the nonsurgical site. The patient is brought to the operating room and the circulating nurse confirms that all relevant patient documents and findings are available. While the surgical team is scrubbing, the anesthetist asks the patient to verify her surgery site by pointing to it. Regional anesthesia is performed, and the patient is draped. The surgery is subsequently performed without any complications. While filling out the signout checklist after the surgery, the circulating nurse notices that the surgery was performed on the left carotid artery instead of the right. Which of the following actions would most likely have prevented this never event?
hint: The Universal Protocol should be followed to prevent never events such as wrong-site surgery. This protocol consists of a series of steps based on the human factors engineering strategy of redundancy and standardization and should be performed before invasive medical procedures. In this scenario, the surgeon did not follow the protocol for one of these steps correctly and a subsequent step was missed entirely. If this subsequent step had been performed, it could have reduced the likelihood of the error occurring by acting as an additional safety measure (i.e., a Swiss cheese model).
learning_objective: Recognize the importance of conducting a time-out immediately prior to surgery to prevent wrong-site surgery.

answers.content: Performing surgical site marking in the operating room
answers.explanation_why: It is generally recommended that surgical site marking be performed in the preoperative area, where there are fewer distractions compared to the operating room. Marking may be performed by the attending surgeon after verbal confirmation from the patient, although it is acceptable to delegate to another person who will also be present during the procedure (e.g., the surgical intern in this scenario), or by the patient directly in front of the surgeon, but the site marking protocol should be standardized for each institution.

answers.content: Providing the patient with a radiofrequency identification wrist band
answers.explanation_why: Radiofrequency identification wrist bands can be used to verify a patient's identity and prevent errors caused by patient misidentification (e.g., wrong patient surgery). However, they are not typically used to identify surgical sites and it is unlikely that they would have prevented this patient's wrong-site surgery.

answers.content: Avoiding the use of abbreviations in patient records
answers.explanation_why: The use of nonstandardized abbreviations in documentation should be avoided to minimize errors. However, in this scenario, the procedure was documented as “CEA right” and correctly identified the laterality of the procedure.

answers.content: Conducting a time-out immediately prior to surgery
Using adhesive tape for surgical site marking
answers.explanation_why: The Joint Commission recommends making permanent surgical site markings to ensure that they are still visible following surgical preparation (e.g., antiseptic skin preparation and draping). Therefore, adhesive tape is not recommended because it can easily be rubbed off or transferred to a different site, which can result in wrong-site surgery.

question_text: A 59-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of pain, swelling, and redness of her right arm. Two months ago, she underwent a left-sided mastectomy for breast cancer and she is currently receiving chemotherapy through a right-sided implanted port. Medical history is remarkable for irritable bowel syndrome and hypertension. Current medications include paclitaxel and trastuzumab. She appears fatigued. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 114/72 mm Hg. Physical examination shows diffuse swelling, warmth, and erythema of the right upper extremity. Radial pulses are palpable. Her surgical incisions appear well-healed. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
content_preview: A 59-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 1-day history of pain, swelling, and redness of her right arm. Two months ago, she underwent a left-sided mastectomy for breast cancer and she is currently receiving chemotherapy through a right-sided implanted port. Medical history is remarkable for irritable bowel syndrome and hypertension. Current medications include paclitaxel and trastuzumab. She appears fatigued. Her temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 114/72 mm Hg. Physical examination shows diffuse swelling, warmth, and erythema of the right upper extremity. Radial pulses are palpable. Her surgical incisions appear well-healed. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?
hint: This patient's findings are consistent with impaired venous return from the right upper extremity.
learning_objective: Recognize catheter-related thrombosis.

answers.explanation_why: Thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) can manifest with pain and swelling of the affected arm due to compression of the subclavian vein. However, this patient does not have other common features of TOS, such as symptoms of brachial plexus compression (e.g., paresthesias, weakness). Isolated compression of the subclavian vein without compression of parts of the brachial plexus is rare. Moreover, TOS is typically caused by repetitive arm lifting, trauma, or surrounding structural abnormalities (e.g., anomalous cervical rib, Pancoast tumors), none of which has been reported by this patient.

Compartment syndrome can manifest with findings of venous congestion of the affected extremity. However, 24 hours after the onset of symptoms, findings of arterial compromise (e.g., absent or weak pulses, pallor) and other neurological findings (e.g., muscle weakness, paresthesias) would already be expected. Moreover, compartment syndrome is typically associated with trauma, which has not been reported by this patient.

Arterial embolism can manifest with unilateral pain in an extremity in a patient with risk factors for atherosclerosis (e.g., hypertension). However, in contrast to what is seen here, patients with arterial embolism typically present with absent peripheral pulses and decreased skin temperature in the affected extremity; swelling of the extremity is also not expected.

Erysipelas can manifest with erythema, edema, warmth, and tenderness of the affected location. Furthermore, patients receiving chemotherapy are at increased risk of developing an infection. However, erysipelas typically manifests with a sharply demarcated lesion rather than a diffuse one.

Catheter-related thrombosis should be suspected in any patient with an indwelling catheter who presents with findings of deep venous thrombosis (DVT) on the same side as the catheter. DVT is more common in patients with risk factors that enhance the pathophysiological mechanisms of the Virchow triad: hypercoagulability (e.g., active cancer, thrombophilias), endothelial injury (e.g., intravascular devices), and venous stasis (e.g., immobilization). The diagnostic approach to DVT should be based on pretest probability (PTP), which can be determined using the Wells criteria for DVT. Individuals with low PTP should be screened with D-dimer to rule out DVT while individuals with a high PTP or a positive D-dimer should receive a venous compression ultrasound. Primary treatment consists of oral anticoagulation therapy.

question_text: A 66-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 5-day history of increasing malaise, headache, fever, and pain in his left foot. He reports that his left big toe has looked “weird” for several weeks but was not painful until now. He has not seen a physician in the past 15 years. Family history is remarkable for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years and drinks two 12-oz beers daily. He takes no medications. He appears distressed. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 112 kg (246 lb); BMI is 35 kg/m^2. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 118/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 94/50 mm Hg. Examination of the left foot shows erythema and edema up to the level of the midfoot. The left first toe appears moist and enlarged, with grayish-black discoloration and blistering. The right foot shows dry, shiny, bluish skin with brittle nails. Dorsalis pedis pulses are not palpable and posterior tibial pulses are weak bilaterally. Sensation to pinprick is decreased in both feet up to the level of the ankle. Leukocyte count is 17,000/mm^3. In addition to intravenous fluids and antibiotics, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 66-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a 5-day history of increasing malaise, headache, fever, and pain in his left foot. He reports that his left big toe has looked “weird” for several weeks but was not painful until now. He has not seen a physician in the past 15 years. Family history is remarkable for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years and drinks two 12-oz beers daily. He takes no medications. He appears distressed. He is 178 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 112 kg (246 lb); BMI is 35 kg/m2. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 118/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 94/50 mm Hg. Examination of the left foot shows erythema and edema up to the level of the midfoot. The left first toe appears moist and enlarged, with grayish-black discoloration and blistering. The right foot shows dry, shiny, bluish skin with brittle nails. Dorsalis pedis pulses are not palpable and posterior tibial pulses are weak bilaterally. Sensation to pinprick is decreased in both feet up to the level of the ankle. Leukocyte count is 17,000/mm3. In addition to intravenous fluids and antibiotics, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: In a patient with findings consistent with peripheral artery disease (PAD), such as absent pulses, decreased sensation, and trophic changes, a moist and edematous left first toe with grayish-black discoloration and blistering raises concern for wet gangrene.
learning_objective: Recognize wet gangrene in the context of peripheral artery disease, and choose the most appropriate surgical management.

answers.explanation_why: Percutaneous transluminal angioplasty is a revascularization procedure that can be used in the treatment of PAD. This patient's wet gangrene of the left first toe, however, requires immediate management before proceeding to treatment of any underlying condition.

answers.content: Amputation of the left first toe
answers.explanation_why: This patient with suspected PAD most likely developed wet gangrene of the left first toe that was further complicated by sepsis. In wet gangrene, emergency amputation and debridement of infected and necrotic tissue are indicated. Broad-spectrum antibiotics should be administered promptly after obtaining blood cultures and later adjusted based on the results. In addition, this patient requires a workup and treatment for PAD and any other conditions (e.g., diabetes mellitus) that may have contributed to the development of wet gangrene.

Hemoglobin A_1c levels can be measured to screen for diabetes mellitus (DM), which this patient might have given his risk factors for type 2 DM (increased BMI, a family history of diabetes, older age). Type 2 DM can manifest with distal symmetric polyneuropathy, which, in combination with the immunosuppressive state associated with type 2 DM, can contribute to nonhealing foot ulcers and consequent infection. Although this patient requires future screening for DM, he first requires urgent management for the wet gangrene of the first left toe.

MRI can be used in the evaluation of patients with suspected osteomyelitis, which this patient most likely has in the left first toe as a result of wet gangrene. However, the wet gangrene requires urgent management, which does not include an MRI of the foot.

Measurement of the ankle-brachial index is the first step in the workup for PAD. Before proceeding to a workup for PAD, however, this patient requires urgent management for the wet gangrene of the first left toe.

question_text:
A 38-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 2, is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of acute abdominal and left shoulder pain, nausea, vomiting, and hiccups. She has no history of trauma to the region and has been well until the onset of the current episode. Her last menstrual period was 1 week ago. She has had two miscarriages but otherwise has no history of serious illness. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. She appears to be in acute distress. She is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 65 kg (143 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m^2. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg. There is left upper quadrant tenderness with localized guarding. There is no rigidity or rebound tenderness. The spleen tip is palpated 3 cm below the left costal margin. The liver edge cannot be palpated. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
15 g/dL

Leukocyte count
14,000/mm^3

Platelet count
270,000/mm^3

Prothrombin time
12 seconds

Partial thromboplastin time
45 seconds

Serum

Urea nitrogen
16 mg/dL

Creatinine
0.9 mg/dL

Lactate dehydrogenase
250 U/L

A transverse section of a contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen is shown. Treatment with intravenous fluids and analgesics is initiated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
content_preview: A 38-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 2, is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-hour history of acute abdominal and left shoulder pain, nausea, vomiting, and hiccups. She has no history of trauma to the region and has been well until the onset of the current episode. Her last menstrual period was 1 week ago. She has had two miscarriages but otherwise has no history of serious illness. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. She appears to be in acute distress. She is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 65 kg (143 lb); BMI is 22 kg/m2. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 145/90 mm Hg. There is left upper quadrant tenderness with localized guarding. There is no rigidity or rebound tenderness. The spleen tip is palpated 3 cm below the left costal margin. The liver edge cannot be palpated. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 15 g/dL Leukocyte count 14,000/mm3 Platelet count 270,000/mm3 Prothrombin time 12 seconds Partial thromboplastin time 45 seconds Serum Urea nitrogen 16 mg/dL Creatinine 0.9 mg/dL Lactate dehydrogenase 250 U/L A transverse section of a contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen is shown. Treatment with intravenous fluids and analgesics is initiated. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
hint: The CT scan shows a wedge-shaped noncontrast enhancing lesion in the spleen. This patient's condition also occurs repeatedly in children with sickle cell disease (SCD) before 4 years of age, albeit by a different mechanism (secondary to vasoocclusion from sickle cell buildup).
learning_objective: Recognize splenic infarction, and choose the most appropriate next step in treatment.

answers.explanation_why: Splenectomy is indicated in the treatment of splenic infarction if complications develop (e.g., hemorrhage, atraumatic rupture, aneurysm formation, pseudocysts) or if symptoms persist despite adequate treatment. While this patient's features (e.g., left upper quadrant pain, vomiting, splenomegaly) and CT findings are consistent with splenic infarction, there is no evidence of a complication.

CT-guided aspiration can be used in the treatment of unilocular splenic abscess and nonparasitic splenic cysts (e.g., epidermoid cyst, lymphangioma), both of which can manifest with left upper quadrant pain and splenomegaly. On a CT scan, splenic abscesses appear as round cavitary lesions with central hypodensity, sometimes with peripheral contrast enhancement, and nonparasitic splenic cysts typically appear as round hypodense lesions with thin, smooth, well-defined walls and no peripheral enhancement. This patient's CT findings indicate a different diagnosis, which requires another treatment.

Broad-spectrum antibiotics are indicated in the management of splenic abscess, which typically results from septic embolization (e.g., due to infective endocarditis) or superinfection of a preexisting splenic infarction. While a splenic abscess can manifest with left upper quadrant pain, nausea, vomiting, splenomegaly, and leukocytosis, a CT scan would show a round cavitary lesion that has a central hypodensity and, occasionally, peripheral contrast enhancement. This patient's CT findings indicate another diagnosis, for which antibiotic therapy is not indicated.

images.title: Splenic abscess
images.description:
CT abdomen (with IV contrast; axial plane) of a patient with a splenic abscessA solitary low attenuation lesion (green overlay) in the region of the spleen contains small collections of gas (arrowheads) and a gas-fluid level.The presence of gas in a splenic lesion is an uncommon but characteristic finding of abscess.

A: aorta; Arrow: transverse diameter; G: gas; GB: gallbladder; IVC: inferior vena cava; K: kidney; L: liver; P: pancreas; S: spleen

answers.explanation_why: The CT scan findings in this patient are consistent with splenic infarction, which can manifest with left upper quadrant pain, features of ipsilateral diaphragmatic irritation (e.g., Kehr sign, hiccups), vomiting, splenomegaly, leukocytosis, and elevated LDH. In patients < 40 years of age, the underlying cause of the infarction is most commonly a hypercoagulable state, whereas the etiology in patients > 40 years of age is most often thromboembolic. Thrombophilia testing, including serology for antiphospholipid antibodies, should be performed to identify the underlying cause of nontraumatic splenic infarction. This woman's history of miscarriages and her prolonged partial thromboplastin time suggest antiphospholipid syndrome. The use of oral contraceptives further increases the risk of developing thrombi. If the patient has an underlying hypercoagulable state, anticoagulant therapy is required in addition to hydration, analgesics, and close monitoring. Symptoms typically resolve within 1–2 weeks in uncomplicated cases. Follow-up imaging is required to screen for complications (e.g., hemorrhage, pseudocyst, abscess). If complications develop or symptoms persist, splenectomy may be required.

images.title: Splenic infarction
images.description: CT abdomen (left upper quadrant; with IV contrast; axial plane) of patient with history of atrial fibrillation and acute left upper quadrant painA sharply demarcated hypodense area (green overlay) is seen in the medial spleen (S). Capsular enhancement is preserved.The finding represents a splenic infarction. Infarctions may be single or multiple and typically appear as hypoenhancing or nonenhancing lesions, often wedge-shaped. Imaging features can vary with stage. Acute infarctions may appear heterogeneous and contain sites of hemorrhage. Chronic infarctions may disappear or liquify and become cystic. They may also result in parenchymal scarring, seen as splenic volume loss and distortion.A: aorta; C: colon; L: liver; red overlay: splenic artery

answers.explanation_why: Angiographic embolization of the splenic artery is used in the treatment of hypersplenism if severe symptoms (e.g., pancytopenia) are present. This patient has splenomegaly, but the acute onset of symptoms and the lack of cytopenia are not consistent with hypersplenism. Moreover, she has no medical history of conditions associated with increased splenic activity (e.g., liver disease, malaria, leukemia).

images.title: Splenic infarction
images.description: CT abdomen (with contrast; axial plane)Well-demarcated, nonenhancing, low attenuation areas in the splenic parenchyma extend to the periphery. The larger lesion (green overlay) has the typical wedged shape of a splenic infarction. A small enhancing vessel (arrowhead) is seen within the area of infarction.L: liver

question_text:
A 78-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by ambulance 30 minutes after she fainted during a morning walk. Her husband says that she regained consciousness after a couple of minutes. The patient reports a 12-hour history of sharp back pain. She is now experiencing dull abdominal pain. She also notes that her legs have felt strange since she woke up this morning. Her medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus controlled through diet. She smoked a half pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years but stopped 8 years ago. She does not drink alcohol. Her only medication is lisinopril. She appears in mild distress and is oriented to person, place, and time. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 103/min, and blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows diffuse tenderness. Femoral pulses are decreased bilaterally. ECG shows sinus tachycardia; chest x-ray shows a left-sided pleural effusion. Laboratory studies show:

Hemoglobin
12.1 g/dL

Leukocyte count
9000/mm^3

Platelet count
250,000/mm^3

D-Dimer
550 ng/mL

Serum

 Creatinine
0.8 mg/dL

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
content_preview: A 78-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by ambulance 30 minutes after she fainted during a morning walk. Her husband says that she regained consciousness after a couple of minutes. The patient reports a 12-hour history of sharp back pain. She is now experiencing dull abdominal pain. She also notes that her legs have felt strange since she woke up this morning. Her medical history is significant for hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus controlled through diet. She smoked a half pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years but stopped 8 years ago. She does not drink alcohol. Her only medication is lisinopril. She appears in mild distress and is oriented to person, place, and time. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 103/min, and blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows diffuse tenderness. Femoral pulses are decreased bilaterally. ECG shows sinus tachycardia; chest x-ray shows a left-sided pleural effusion. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 12.1 g/dL Leukocyte count 9000/mm3 Platelet count 250,000/mm3 D-Dimer 550 ng/mL Serum Creatinine 0.8 mg/dL Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
hint: This patient's presentation should raise concern for aortic dissection, most likely involving the aortic arch and descending aorta. Syncope, a history of sharp back pain migrating to the abdomen, and evidence of perfusion deficit in the lower extremities (bilaterally decreased femoral pulses, leg paresthesia) are consistent with an aortic dissection that extends downward with successive occlusion of branching vessels (e.g., carotid arteries, abdominal arteries, femoral arteries).
learning_objective: Recognize aortic dissection, and choose the most appropriate diagnostic test in a hemodynamically stable patient.

answers.explanation_why: Emergency open surgery is indicated for patients with aortic dissection involving the ascending aorta (Stanford type A); urgent surgery may be indicated in patients with aortic dissection involving only the descending aorta (Stanford type B) if there is evidence of malperfusion (e.g., hypotension). However, before proceeding to surgery, the diagnosis must be established and imaging is required.

Beta blockers (e.g., labetalol) may be used for hypertensive and/or tachycardic patients with confirmed aortic dissection if they are managed conservatively. Although these drugs can be administrated simultaneously while establishing the diagnosis in the case of a hypertensive emergency, this patient is hemodynamically stable and requires a definitive diagnosis first. Administering beta blockers prematurely before differential diagnoses have been ruled out may be harmful; e.g., it could lead to severe hypotension in a patient with a ruptured aortic aneurysm. Administration of beta blockers would also not be recommended if the patient required emergency surgery. A different step in management is indicated first.

Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE) is the diagnostic test of choice for patients with suspected aortic dissection and hemodynamic instability because of its rapidness, high accuracy, and ability to be performed at the bedside. However, this woman is hemodynamically stable and a different imaging modality can rule out or confirm aortic dissection (and other differentials) with even greater sensitivity and specificity; it also can assess the extension of dissections below the diaphragm, which TEE cannot.

images.title: Transesophageal echocardiography of aortic dissection
images.description: Echocardiography (transesophageal; transverse view)The descending thoracic aorta shows a crescentic false lumen and rounded true lumen.

answers.explanation_why: Diagnostic thoracocentesis is indicated for patients with pleural effusion if the etiology is unknown. However, this patient's presentation is consistent with aortic dissection as the underlying cause of her pleural effusion. Aortic dissection can lead to transudation of fluid to the pleural space, which is a nonspecific finding seen on chest x-ray.

Contrast-enhanced CT angiography (CTA) is the definitive diagnostic test of choice for aortic dissection in hemodynamically stable patients because of its high sensitivity and specificity, the speed and ease with which it can be conducted, and its widespread availability. A false lumen detected on imaging is consistent with aortic dissection. Further, nonspecific findings of aortic dissection in this patient include an elevated D-dimer level due to clot formation in the lumen and pleural effusion on chest x-ray. In this woman, CTA can also be used to rule out pulmonary embolism (which can lead to nonspecific symptoms and a high D-dimer level) and acute aortic occlusion (which can cause leg paresthesia and decreased femoral pulse).

For hemodynamically unstable patients or patients with contraindications to contrast agents (e.g., renal insufficiency), transesophageal echocardiography should be performed instead of CTA.

images.title: Aortic dissection (Stanford A)
images.description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT angiography (chest; ECG-gated; venous and arterial phases; axial plane) of a patient with a history of recent weakness, vertigo, and facial swellingThe ascending aorta is dilated and a Stanford type A (DeBakey type II) aortic dissection is seen. The aortic arch and descending aorta are not affected. The right and left coronary, the innominate, the left common carotid, and the subclavian arteries originate from the true lumen (green overlay; false lumen is red overlay). Facial swelling is the result of venous congestion from compression of the superior vena cava (blue overlay) by the dilated ascending aorta. Bilateral small pleural effusions are seen.Additional findings include sternotomy wires, a prosthetic aortic valve, atherosclerotic calcifications, pancreatic calcifications, and a small hiatal hernia.LCA: left coronary artery; RCA: right coronary artery; yellow overlay: azygos vein

question_text:
Patient Information
Age: 57 years
Gender: F, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: emergency department 
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “It feels like I'm running out of air.” 
History of Present Illness:

dyspnea, cough, and pleuritic chest pain for 20 minutes

pain is rated 9/10
was watching TV when symptoms suddenly started
underwent surgery for total right knee replacement 3 weeks ago

Past Medical History:
osteoarthritis
Medications:
ibuprofen for knee pain
Vaccinations:
up-to-date
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Psychosocial history:

lives with husband
has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 20 years

does not drink alcohol

Physical Examination 

Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI

38.2°C
(100.8°F)

112/min
24/min
88/55 mm Hg
92% on 4LNC

165 cm
(5 ft 5 in)
78 kg
(170 lb)
28.7 kg/m^2

Appearance: in acute distress, unable to lay back; feels lightheaded 

Neck: jugular venous pressure of 8 cm H_2O above the sternal angle; trachea is midline

Pulmonary: decreased breath sounds bilaterally; productive cough with blood-tinged sputum
Cardiac: tachycardia; split S2
Abdominal: obese; nontender to palpation; normoactive bowel sounds; no hepatosplenomegaly 
Extremities: mildly tender surgical scar on the right knee, no edema; tenderness and erythema of the right calf; radial and femoral pulses intact bilaterally
Neurologic: alert, fully oriented

Diagnostic Studies

ECG: sinus tachycardia; QRS duration 140 ms, rSR' waves in leads V1-V2, ST-segment depression and T-wave inversion in leads V1-V2

bedside echocardiography: mid-segment dilatation of the right ventricle, tricuspid regurgitation, increased pulmonary artery systolic pressure

CT scan of the chest: shown

Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?

hint: Orthopedic surgeries, such as a total knee replacement, often cause prolonged immobilization. This is a significant risk factor for venous stasis.
learning_objective: Recognize massive pulmonary embolism with hemodynamic instability, and choose the most appropriate treatment.

answers.explanation_why: This patient's CT scan shows evidence of a large pulmonary embolism (PE). In cases of massive PE with hemodynamic instability (e.g., SBP < 90 mm Hg), thrombolysis with recombinant tissue plasminogen activators (tPA) such as alteplase is indicated. Because of the associated significant risk of bleeding, there are several relative and absolute contraindications to thrombolytic therapy. Surgery within the past 10 days is a relative contraindication, but this patient underwent surgery 3 weeks ago. Therefore, alteplase would be the most appropriate treatment. Anticoagulation with heparin, rivaroxaban, warfarin, or apixaban is also appropriate treatment for patients with PE. However, these agents are typically used in patients who remain hemodynamically stable.

Bumetanide is a diuretic used in the treatment of pulmonary edema. Pulmonary edema can manifest with dyspnea, cough, tachypnea, and jugular venous distension. However, her CT scan shows a vascular filling defect that is consistent with a pulmonary embolism rather than the findings typically seen in pulmonary edema (i.e., ground-glass opacities and peribronchovascular interstitial thickening). In addition, administering a diuretic could be detrimental to a patient with hypotension.

Pericardiocentesis is a procedure used to treat patients with pericardial effusion and cardiac tamponade. Cardiac tamponade can manifest with dyspnea, chest pain, hypotension, and jugular venous distension. However, her CT scan shows a vascular filling defect consistent with PE, as opposed to a fluid-filled pericardial sac, which would be typical in a patient with tamponade. Furthermore, pericardiocentesis would pose a risk of myocardial or endocardial injury in a patient who does not have pericardial effusion.

Endovascular stent-grafting can be used in the treatment of type A (proximal) aortic dissection. Patients typically present with severe, tearing chest pain, hypertension, and asymmetric pulses. Hypotension, severe dyspnea, and cough are less common manifestations of type A aortic dissection. The patient's CT scan also shows a vascular filling defect consistent with a pulmonary embolism rather than a tear in the aortic intima, which would be typical in a case of dissection.

images.title: Aortic dissection (Stanford A)
images.description:
Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

CT angiography (chest; ECG-gated; venous and arterial phases; axial plane) of a patient with a history of recent weakness, vertigo, and facial swellingThe ascending aorta is dilated and a Stanford type A (DeBakey type II) aortic dissection is seen. The aortic arch and descending aorta are not affected. The right and left coronary, the innominate, the left common carotid, and the subclavian arteries originate from the true lumen (green overlay; false lumen is red overlay). Facial swelling is the result of venous congestion from compression of the superior vena cava (blue overlay) by the dilated ascending aorta. Bilateral small pleural effusions are seen.Additional findings include sternotomy wires, a prosthetic aortic valve, atherosclerotic calcifications, pancreatic calcifications, and a small hiatal hernia.LCA: left coronary artery; RCA: right coronary artery; yellow overlay: azygos vein

answers.explanation_why: Tube thoracostomy is used in the treatment of tension pneumothorax, which can manifest with dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, cough, jugular venous distension, and hypotension. However, her CT scan shows a vascular filling defect consistent with a pulmonary embolism rather than air in the pleural space with tracheal deviation, which is typical in cases of tension pneumothorax.

Piperacillin/tazobactam can be used in the treatment of pneumonia. Pneumonia can manifest with dyspnea and cough, and, in the setting of sepsis, even hypotension. However, jugular venous distension would not be expected in pneumonia. In addition, this patient's CT scan shows a vascular filling defect consistent with a pulmonary embolism rather than parenchymal infiltrates and/or consolidation, which would be typical in a case of pneumonia.

Coronary angioplasty is used in the treatment of myocardial infarction (MI). MI can manifest with chest pain, jugular venous distension, and hypotension. However, her CT scan shows a vascular filling defect consistent with a pulmonary embolism. In addition, a CT scan is typically not diagnostic in cases of myocardial infarction.

images.title: Saddle pulmonary embolism
images.description: CT chest (with contrast; axial plane)A large embolism burden is seen (green overlay), with extension across the bifurcation of the pulmonary trunk into the right and left pulmonary arteries.Straddling of the pulmonary trunk bifurcation by pulmonary embolism is sometimes referred to as saddle embolism.AA: ascending aorta; DA: descending aorta; E: esophagus; LMB: left main bronchus; LPA: left pulmonary artery; PT: pulmonary trunk; RMB: right main bronchus; RPA: right pulmonary artery; SVC: superior vena cava

question_text:
Patient Information
Age: 65 years
Gender: M, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: emergency department
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: "I have a sudden crushing pain in my chest.”
History of Present Illness:

sudden-onset anterior chest pain and lightheadedness for 20 minutes

pain rated 10/10
patient was gardening when symptoms started

Past Medical History:

hypertension
diabetes mellitus

Medications:

lisinopril
amlodipine
metformin

Vaccinations:
up-to-date
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family History:
father: deceased at age 51 years from myocardial infarction
Psychosocial History:

lives with his wife
drinks one beer daily
does not smoke or use nonprescribed medications or other substances

Physical Examination

Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O_2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI

36.8°C
(98.2°F)

110/min
20/min
80/50 mm Hg
97% on RA

185 cm
(6 ft 1 in)
87 kg
(192 lb)
25.4 kg/m^2

Appearance: agitated; in acute distress
Skin: diaphoretic
HEENT: PERRLA; ocular movements are intact
Neck: no jugular venous distention
Pulmonary: clear to auscultation; shallow breath sounds
Cardiac: tachycardia; S_1 and S_2 with no murmurs
Abdominal: nondistended; normoactive bowel sounds; soft, nontender
Extremities: radial pulses 1+; femoral pulses 1+ bilaterally 
Neurologic: fully oriented; cranial nerves grossly intact; no focal deficits

Diagnostic Studies

Blood

Hemoglobin
13.9 g/dL

 WBC count
6100/mm^3

Platelet count
210,000/mm^3

Serum

Lactate dehydrogenase
424 U/L

Troponin I
1.94 μg/L

D-dimer
570 ng/mL

ECG: sinus tachycardia; diffuse ST-segment depressions 

CT angiography of the chest: shown

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

hint: This patient has a Stanford type A aortic dissection, which has a high risk of rupture and requires immediate intervention.
learning_objective: Recognize Stanford A aortic dissection, and choose the most appropriate management.

answers.explanation_why: Labetalol is first-line medical therapy for patients with aortic dissection with hypertension. Labetalol is contraindicated in hypotensive shock.

Endovascular aortic stent implantation is indicated in patients with Stanford type B aortic dissection who develop complications (e.g., aortic rupture, renal failure, abdominal pain due to intestinal ischemia) and have a high risk of complications during open surgery. Endovascular stent grafts are not approved for Stanford type A aortic dissections.

Cardiac catheterization may be indicated before aortic graft replacement surgery in stable patients with Stanford type A aortic dissection and known or suspected coronary artery disease (CAD) to plan for possible concomitant coronary artery bypass surgery. Although this patient has risk factors for CAD (i.e., diabetes mellitus, hypertension, family history), he has hypotensive shock and is therefore unstable, so he needs immediate surgery instead of additional imaging.

Dobutamine is an inotropic medication with vasodilatory properties (inodilator). In patients with aortic dissection, inotropes should be avoided as they can increase shear stress on the aortic wall through increased force of ventricular contraction. Moreover, vasodilation can worsen this patient's hypotension. In patients with aortic dissection and hypotension, vasopressor support with norepinephrine or phenylephrine is recommended if the mean arterial pressure is < 70 mm Hg despite IV fluid therapy.

Emergency open aortic repair surgery with graft placement is critical in the management of ascending aortic dissections (Stanford type A) because of the high risk of complications such as aortic rupture, acute aortic regurgitation, myocardial infarction, and cardiac tamponade. Simultaneously to surgery, this patient requires management of hypotensive shock with IV fluids and, if necessary, vasopressors, as well as supportive care for pain and anxiety. Patients with uncomplicated dissections of the descending aorta (Stanford type B) can be treated conservatively with observation, blood pressure control, and analgesia unless complications develop (e.g., aortic rupture, renal failure, abdominal pain due to intestinal ischemia).

Elevated troponin I and lactate dehydrogenase levels indicate myocardial stress due to involvement of the coronary arteries, while D-dimer levels are commonly elevated in aortic dissection and may have prognostic value.

images.title: Classifications of aortic dissection
images.description:
Stanford classification
– Type A: dissection involves the ascending aorta or aortic arch
– Type B: dissection involves only the descending aorta (distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery)DeBakey classification
– Type I: dissection involves the ascending and descending aorta
– Type II: dissection involves only the ascending aorta (up to the brachiocephalic artery)
– Type III: dissection involves only the descending aorta (distal to the origin of the left subclavian artery)Surgical management is recommended for aortic dissections involving the ascending aorta (i.e., Stanford A and DeBakey types I and II). Medical management is recommended for aortic dissections involving only the descending aorta (i.e., Stanford B and DeBakey type III).

answers.explanation_why: Mechanical circulatory support with an intraaortic balloon pump (IABP) or extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) is indicated as bridging therapy in conditions with acutely reduced cardiac output (e.g., cardiogenic shock and refractory heart failure). IABP is contraindicated in Stanford type A aortic dissection and ECMO does not improve outcomes.
